PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received through His Excellency the Governor-General from the Governor of the State of South Australia a certificate of the choice by the Houses of Parliament of South Australia of Alan Baird Ferguson to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator John Wayne Olsen. I table a copy of the certificate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alan Baird Ferguson made and subscribed the oath of allegiance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Did the Attorney-General's office contact the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands last week regarding the case of Mr Greg Symons? Was the purpose of that call to discuss extradition arrangements relating to Mr Symons? On what basis was that call made? Is this the usual practice with regard to the arrest of Australian nationals overseas? Finally, did the Minister consult with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade regarding the protocol for such a call and the appropriateness of the request made to a foreign government?

—I am not aware of any phone call from the Attorney-General's office to the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands. I understand that the Attorney-General in another place last week, in answer to a question, referred to the fact that the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands had contacted the Attorney-General's Department concerning some of these matters, and no doubt Senator Kemp has had an opportunity to read the Hansard report of the answer to that question. As to whether there was any further communication initiated from the Attorney-General's office to the Marshall Islands Attorney-General, I will have to seek further information for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Associated Pulp and Paper Mills: Dispute

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the current industrial dispute at APPM, Burnie, and ask: in view of the intense media speculation surrounding the calling of and the supposed outcome of the meeting of all parties in Hobart last night, can the Minister confirm that he and the Tasmanian Premier called that meeting in an endeavour to settle the dispute; and can he advise what the results of the meeting were?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —On the weekend the Premier of Tasmania and I called the parties to the APPM dispute to a meeting in Hobart. I table the press release we issued in our joint names summoning the parties there. Both parties attended the meeting; APPM attended reluctantly and issued a press statement before going in, I understand, saying that it would not change its position irrespective of the talks.

PARA.TAB: When we met with the parties we put a joint proposition, which was that the agreement between APPM and the ACTU, reached between them last week without interference of any third parties, be abided by; that the orders of Munro J. of the Industrial Relations Commission be accepted; that if there is a conflict between the agreement and the orders, the orders prevail; that we acknowledge that the issue concerning logging contractors has been settled and is to one side; and in the face of the parties agreeing to their own terms and accepting the order of the Commission, there be a return to work.
I now read the joint press statement issued by the Premier of Tasmania and me at about midnight last night:

ANSWER.PARA: We met with representatives of the ACTU and APPM late today.
The discussions lasted for more than 6 hours.
Regrettably no agreement was reached.

In our view the principal reasons for this were APPM's refusal to forgo their right to appeal the Order handed down by Munro J on Friday and the company's refusal not to proceed with legal actions under Sections 45D and 45E.
We put a proposal to the parties at the beginning of the discussions.
The ACTU accepted that proposal. The company did not accept it.
Further, the company no longer accepts the Understandings of Workplace Reform which it reached with the ACTU last week.
I table the rest of the press statement.

PARA.TAB: The Munro order falls into two parts. One part of it is a direction to the workers on strike at Burnie to return to work and, if they do not do so by 4 o'clock today, the penalties of the Industrial Relations Act will be applied to them. The other part is that, upon a return to work, the records about employees' conduct that have been kept by the company since this dispute began will be wiped clear; that there will be introduced a `no victimisation' regime in the workplace; and that the parties will be enjoined to negotiate to create an enterprise agreement within a given time span.

The company says of that order that it will reserve its right to appeal all of the conditions about the slates being wiped clean, the no victimisation part and the enterprise bargaining injunction; that it will be the beneficiary of an order directing people to return to work with the penalties being provided to them; and that, as to the agreement reached voluntarily with the ACTU not to proceed with and support actions for trespass by its own employees on its own plant and legal actions against union officials and employees of its mill, those actions will be waived. I now understand that those actions will go ahead and that, further, today APPM will issue more writs against union officials and workers at its plant under section 45D. That is an act of escalation in this dispute.

Actions by joint governments in this country—between a Federal government and a State government—are unusual, to say the least. Joint action by a Liberal government and a Labor government in an industrial dispute, in which we assume a united position and act together in the public interest and in the interests of the citizens of Burnie to bring this matter to a speedy conclusion, is unprecedented in my knowledge of industrial life in this country. This sort of joint action between Liberal and Labor governments has not happened before. When we do take that action in the public interest, we believe as joint governments that the parties are bound to listen to us because, combined, we represent 99.9 per cent of the Australian community. The ACTU said it would abide by it. APPM told us, in so many words, to go jump in the lake.

It is interesting that today John Howard has bought into this dispute. A few weeks ago he said that politicians should butt out of this dispute, and I agree with him. He should keep out and Dr Hewson should keep out. But it is an entirely different thing for governments to keep out and, as a government, we have responsibility to the public interest and we will not surrender that responsibility to the public interest, no matter how convenient it might be to the Opposition.

There are a number of questions that the conduct of the company raises. One question is: why will not John Howard now support the Liberal Premier of Tasmania? Where do Tasmanian senators stand—on the side of the Australian and Tasmanian governments or on John Howard's side? In the case of APPM, Mr Howard says that all it wants to do is talk to its work force. APPM made it clear to us last night that it is not prepared to talk to the governments of this country and that State without getting legal advice on everything it says. One assumes, therefore, that it will only talk to its work force through lawyers. That raises the question of what is fair; how do those workers have equal representation; and can we expect the outcome in those proceedings to be reasonable. Or is it a case that APPM wants to turn Burnie into an industrial relations gulag and the type of discussion is that sort of discussion that goes on between the warders and inmates in an industrial relations gulag?

The other question is: is this the sneak preview of the big bang in industrial relations that the Opposition preaches? Of course, APPM needs to be more efficient as a company. Why does it not seek the cooperative way, the model way, the way that Australian Newsprint Mills at Boyer outside Hobart, in the same industry as APPM, has sought, and introduce the changes to make it world competitive by agreement with its workplace, because the unions are exactly the same?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Minister, this is becoming a very long answer.

—I will conclude my answer now. I am afraid that, because of the company's intransigence and arrogance, there will now be conflict in Burnie some time today. The possibility of bloodshed is now real. The possibility of further trauma in that community is now real. If that occurs—and I do not want it to occur—
—Why talk it up?

—I will take that interjection from Senator Hill. Why am I talking it up? I have heard interjections from Senator Hill's side of the chamber during this answer. We, as governments, tried to avert this situation by our actions last night; that is exactly what we tried to avert. This company's intransigence in standing by its own agreements prevents that. If it occurs, let it be on the head of APPM and on the head of John Howard, who is its little poodle and acolyte in this dispute.

—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: was he, his office or his Department consulted by the Attorney-General about information received by the Attorney-General relating to charges faced by Mr Symons in the Marshall Islands? If so, when was he, his office or his Department consulted and what action was taken, if any?

—I am aware of some consultation on consular aspects, again, of this particular matter—the applicability of extradition clauses, or the lack thereof and so on—in the early stages of this matter, back in April. I am not aware of any more recent contact. I will check that matter and advise the honourable senator accordingly as soon as I can.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister table any documents relevant to the question?

—I have already said to the Senate that my Department is presently actively involved in assessing documents by reference to FOI criteria. As I said last week, I hope to be in a position to table a schedule and those documents which are releasable in whole or part quite soon, and my consideration of Senator Durack's request will be in that context.

—My question is addressed to Senator Button as Minister representing the Treasurer. The Minister will be aware of Australian Bureau of Statistics data published last week about company profits and manufacturers' sales. What do these data suggest about the current state of the economy and the manufacturing sector in particular?

—Mr President, there is a bit of good news in all of this; so it will be unpalatable to the people on the Opposition benches. The data made available last week, and also that made available today, do not enable one to draw profound conclusions about the state of the Australian economy, but they do entitle one to draw certain conclusions which are important in terms of the community as a whole.

PARA.TAB: For example, the current account deficit published today was $897m in seasonally adjusted terms, which is an improvement of nearly $100m on last month's result. So far, the average monthly deficit for 1991-92 is $938m, which is a 29 per cent improvement on the first 10 months of last year. I mention that because at Budget time the Opposition always wants to debate these issues and the Budget forecast which was brought down last year, as revised in the One Nation statement, is very much on track. The better current account deficit in April derived from an increase in merchandise trade surplus of $201m in March to $435m. Manufacturing exports are up 7 per cent in the three months to April, compared with the same period a year earlier. The March quarter current account deficit was published last Friday and net exports of goods and services are expected to take 0.5 percentage points from the expenditure estimate of GDP for the March quarter.

Mr President, it is important to make the point that manufacturing export volumes continued to improve, rising 2.5 per cent in the quarter to be up 9 per cent on the equivalent quarter a year earlier. Another very important statistic is company profits, which rose significantly in the March quarter. Company profits before income tax rose 13 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms in March. That is not a one-off aberration; it follows a trend line. It is the third successive quarter of increases in company profits. The increase in profits is partially due to reduced interest costs, of course, as interest rates have fallen and some firms have been able to significantly reduce their debt levels.

The manufacturing sector is showing a relatively strong and sustained improvement in profitability. Manufacturing profits have increased for the fourth successive quarter. Manufacturing company profits rose 21 per cent in the March quarter compared with 13 per cent for companies generally. I am pleased to say that manufacturing profits are 53 per cent higher than the level recorded 12 months ago. The improvement in manufacturing profits was accompanied by improvements in manufacturing sales, which rose by 1.1 per cent in the March quarter, equivalent to an annual rate of a 4.3 per cent increase in manufacturing sales.

These are all statistics. Nonetheless, they were not the sorts of statistics which were available to us last year. They are encouraging statistics. Nobody is pretending that everything is rosy with the Australian economy. Many of the indicators in an economy such as ours are lagged ones. But the news is good and positive and shows that things are on the improve and will, I believe, continue to get better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on 19 May this year that the additional training component of the formal training allowance was payable to an unemployed young person under 21, despite its being Government policy not to do so. As the Minister is aware, the extra $30 of the training component is paid to an unemployed young person who is undertaking additional training and is designed to cover the costs associated with that training. I ask the Minister: firstly, is he aware that, as late as last week and in direct contradiction of the AAT decision, young people were still being refused the additional training component and were being advised by CES officers that they were not eligible for the payment? Secondly, is the Government planning to continue to act unlawfully and deny young people access to the component? Finally, as the Government has been actively discouraging young people from applying for it for some time, will the Minister be looking at back paying those young people who can demonstrate that they had previously applied and had their application rejected or who were advised by DEET not to apply because they were ineligible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the decision of the AAT. I thank Senator Lees for all the other advice and her questions. I will refer those questions to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, obtain a full answer to them all and advise Senator Lees in due course.

—Can the Minister for Justice indicate how the report of the National Committee on Violence is providing a blueprint for changing the culture of violence in Australian society? Can he indicate what steps the Australian Police Ministers Council is taking in coordinating a range of national crime prevention and community safety programs?

—I am pleased to say that the National Committee on Violence report set the foundations for tackling the subculture, or even the prevalence, of violence in some areas of the Australian community. Of course, that Committee report was endorsed by the Prime Minister and all the Premiers in a non-partisan way.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators will recall that the Chair of that Committee was Professor Duncan Chappell, the head of the Institute of Criminology. It is rather a paradox that the Opposition, which claims to be interested in violence in Australian society, has determined to abolish that Institute as the foundation for its Fightback approach to the question of violent crime in our society.

It is also worth commenting that the Opposition, which has put out a scurrilous pamphlet concerning law and order matters, proposes to put a 15 per cent GST on security doors, locks, security lighting and all those things which sensible people would want to purchase in order to protect their homes against the distressing possibility of burglary.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the sales tax on them now?

—Nought on security doors and locks; so there we are. The National Committee on Violence was also very interested in indicating that it is not the elderly who are most at risk from violent crime in our society. That has to be emphasised because the anxiety and the fears of elderly people can be very easily aroused by propaganda which is designed to unsettle them for some cheap political advantage. Young adult males are most at risk of violence in our society, though the age group which is most likely to be killed in our society are infants between nought and one year of age—certainly not the elderly.

PARA.TAB: The question of societies dealing with violence and crime is a very complex one. It has to be approached on a non-partisan basis. That is why the police Ministers have asked me to chair a special meeting in Melbourne on 15 July to set up a national community safety council in order to try to coordinate all those community activities which can assist a local community to itself help to prevent crime in the community. I believe that crime prevention community safety programs, under the auspices of this particular council, will assist in that regard.

I think it is also very encouraging that, again in a non-partisan way, the Police Ministers Council has been able to shepherd through very strict rules relating to the availability of firearms and weapons in the Australian community, building on decades of very stringent controls relating to hand guns and pistols. Once again, the Opposition's pamphlet with a pistol on the front completely misleads the Australian public. Out of 350 homicides last year only 10 were committed with hand guns or pistols. It is not the weapon which is used by those who commit violent crimes in our society; it is part of the misleading, deceptive propaganda in this respect by the Opposition.

I believe that there has to be a non-partisan approach to dealing with crime in our society. I am prepared to pay tribute to the New South Wales police Minister, Ted Pickering, who has done a tremendous amount of good work in this regard. I am quite happy to pay that compliment to him because I believe that we have to put partisan politics behind us in this regard and, on behalf of the whole Australian community, deal with the problem of crime and violence in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the call made by Mr Holthouse from the Australian Embassy in Fiji in late March to the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands, Mr McPhillips, in his investigations of the Multiplex letters referring to Mr Chang's consultancy to the Marshall Islands project. With which other Embassy staff did Mr Holthouse consult before making that contact with the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands? Did the post in Suva consult with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra or with the Minister's office on the protocol of such contact? Will the Minister table all documentation relating to the involvement of the Australian Embassy in Fiji in this matter?

—I will have to take that question on notice. I do not know who contacted whom in the context of the Suva matter. It was essentially an immigration matter. I have already said that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade officer was only very marginally involved at the request of the post's migration officer—it was a DILGEA matter—because of his police liaison responsibilities. I will answer that question as fully as I can. Again, any documentation that is kept in DFAT files in relation to this matter is subject to the same exercise that I described earlier, and will be in the public domain as soon as my Department has had an opportunity to review it against FOI criteria.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the appalling carnage in parts of Bosnia-Herzegovina and, in particular, in and around Sarajevo. What is the Australian Government's response to this violence and to the deliberations in the United Nations regarding the need for sanctions to be imposed? Does the Australian Government have a definitive position?

—It is clear that the authorities in Serbia and Montenegro are overwhelmingly responsible for the horrific conflict which continues in Bosnia-Herzegovina with its very devastating toll of innocent human life. On 15 May 1992, a couple of weeks ago, in response to this situation, the UN Security Council, through resolution 752, called on all parties to the conflict to immediately cease the fighting and to withdraw from Bosnia and Herzegovina. As the demands of resolution 752 were not complied with, the UN Security Council adopted unanimously resolution 757 at its meeting a couple of days ago, on 30 May, implementing a comprehensive list of mandatory sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro.

PARA.TAB: The UN resolution comprises a trade embargo, excluding foodstuffs and humanitarian goods; an arms embargo; prohibitions on the flow of funds; an air embargo on flights to and from Serbia and Montenegro; a reduction in Yugoslav diplomatic representation; and suspension of sporting, cultural, technical and scientific links.

The Government is well aware that sanctions will hurt not only the governments of Serbia and Montenegro but also their people. None of us take any joy in the hurt that these sanctions will inflict. But I think that all Australians now accept that the tough measures embodied in the UN sanctions are required from the international community in order to bring to an end once and for all the enormous suffering that has been created by this conflict throughout the region.

The resolution places mandatory obligations on member states to implement measures which put this tough sanctions regime into effect. The Australian Government is moving very expeditiously to implement the UN decision. Ministers and departments are now working on the details of implementation, with decisions expected to go before the Executive Council tomorrow.

The Australian Government's measures will include the following: the Yugoslav national airline, JAT, which flies out of Australia twice a week, will have its services suspended from this week; Australia has already downgraded its diplomatic representation in Belgrade and cuts to the Yugoslav diplomatic and consular presence in Australia will be introduced; and Australia will enforce a trade ban. Statistics for trade with the former individual Yugoslav republics are not readily available. However, we are aware that imports from Serbia and Montenegro in the first three months of this year totalled only $3.2m. So it cannot be suggested that this will involve a major impact on either side. Measures will become fully operative over the next few days as the necessary regulations and measures are introduced.

Finally, by acting under Chapter 7 of the UN Charter, the UN Security Council has opened the possibility of further action against Serbia and Montenegro, or any other party failing to abide by the earlier Security Council resolution, if sanctions do not bring an end to the violence. We can all simply hope that they will.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given that Mr Holthouse became aware of Mr Chang senior's application for business migration to Australia through the consulate in Hong Kong on about 20 March last, what efforts did Mr Holthouse undertake to establish the bona fides of Mr Chang junior's application? Did Mr Holthouse contact the post in Hong Kong? Did he also contact the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra or the Minister's office? Will the Minister table all relevant communications?

—I do not think that the Opposition has quite got the message. Mr Holthouse is not a Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade officer but a Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs officer. His activities are essentially the responsibility of that Department and its Minister, not of me or my Department. To the extent that the Department of Foreign Affairs has in its records any evidence of Mr Holthouse's activities—and to the extent that they bear upon DFAT responsibilities—as I have said, I will be reviewing that documentation with regard to its releasability.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister seriously telling the Senate that he has not been briefed and has not sought any advice in relation to these matters in the weeks since they first surfaced in the media, particularly in relation to any dealings which might have transpired between the Suva immigration office and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade?

—My understanding is that there were no particularly substantive communications between the Suva immigration office and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of a kind which would have justified my attention. To the extent that there has been and I am wrong about that—I am not sure—I will review it, but I do not think there has been anything of any substance. As I said, any documentation which bears upon this will be looked at. The point is: anything that the Opposition wants to pursue about the immigration application and the handling of it is properly pursued through the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, not through me.

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of suggestions that a number of Telecom offices will be closed in country New South Wales, including those located in Wagga Wagga, Narrandera and Goulburn? I ask the Minister whether these reports are correct.

—AOTC is currently carrying out plans for a major restructuring of its country operations which will significantly improve services to its customers. The aim of the restructuring is to provide for greater efficiency with an increased emphasis on customer service and as part of an overall review of AOTC operations. There will be no reduction in services to the public. The restructuring is looking at establishing a customer service centre for each region which will consolidate staff responsible for telephone inquiries relating to matters such as new phone connection orders, telephone removals and billing inquiries.

PARA.TAB: Operations of centres in some regions will be spread over more than one city or town. At this stage the review is not finalised. When it is, AOTC will publicise the details. Unions representing workers of the AOTC are involved in this consultative process. I did notice that ABC radio and the Canberra Times reported the closure of AOTC facilities in Canberra, which is obviously incorrect. Canberra is just one of the centres under review and no decisions have yet been taken by AOTC.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the fax apparently sent today to parliamentary leaders by Mr Michael Bonney, Australian migration agent, whose clients lost $US1.25m in the Marshall Islands scheme. What steps has the Government taken to restore Australia's international reputation, which has been severely tarnished as a result of Australian involvement in a scheme which appeared to be supported by a senior figure in the Australian Government? Will the Government institute a judicial inquiry into this business migration scam in order that the public interest might be properly protected?

—Any assumption about the character of the particular scheme in which Mr Symons was involved ought not to get comment from me or anybody else until it has been the subject of the judicial inquiry that is proceeding in the Marshall Islands at the moment. I do not make any assumptions on or off the public record about the scam nature of that particular scheme which is the subject of a present judicial inquiry, and I do not think Senator Hill should either in all honesty and decency. Equally, questions as to remedial action that might appropriately be taken by Australia in relation to adverse publicity about business migration schemes—to the extent that that bears upon immigration schemes as they affect Australia—are again the responsibility of the Immigration Minister. I am not trying to duck anything; I am just stating the obvious point that that is a question that ought to be pursued with the Immigration Minister.

PARA.TAB: To the extent that something might have followed adversely internationally in relation to a non-Australia related scheme but involving an Australian citizen, I do not think that is something that should require the efforts of the Department of Foreign Affairs to seek to redress in the event that there were some unhappy consequences flowing from that any more than it is the responsibility of the Department of Foreign Affairs to address other failures or misbehaviour over the years by Australian entrepreneurs which have not helped Australia's international reputation. We have to get on with the task of building a strong and effective economy and demonstrating competence in other ways—overcoming these difficulties by those means, not by slick and quick remedial action of the kind Senator Hill seems to have in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Notwithstanding the fact that the principal of the scheme was Australian and that at least one investor who has lost his money in the scheme was an Australian citizen and suggestions that the money found its way back to Australia, does the Minister believe it is only the concern of another country?

—It has been no part of my ministerial responsibilities to explore the details of any such scheme and I do not think it is any part of anyone's responsibilities to do so while the particular matter in question is the subject of judicial inquiry and criminal court proceedings in the Marshall Islands. To the extent that any of my colleagues think it is appropriate to explore aspects of this, that is a matter for them in their ministerial responsibilities. It is not a matter for me.

—Is the Minister for Justice aware of a press report in Western Australia that there is a nationwide paedophile network? What steps are police Ministers taking to eliminate child pornography and paedophilia within Australia?

—I have seen the article in the Western Australian press concerning allegations of a paedophile network. I would not want to comment on a case that might involve charges being laid in the near future. It is true that State and Territory governments have been extremely concerned over recent weeks about child pornography and paedophile activity and therefore took a decision at the Police Ministers Council only a week or so ago to ensure that possession of child pornography is itself an offence, not merely the possession for sale or further distribution. This is an important step. Some jurisdictions have already made the possession of that sort of pornography an offence. It will now be up to all jurisdictions to adopt that particular principle in their criminal law.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Police Ministers Council also decided to re-emphasise the project being undertaken by the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence to gather information and intelligence from all jurisdictions concerning this sort of activity, not only within Australia domestically, but also using the resources of the Australian Federal Police liaison officers in our embassies overseas, particularly in Manila and Bangkok where, unfortunately, some Australians do prey on the youngsters in those particular areas.

The AFP Commissioner has been instructed to step up the activity of the overseas liaison officers in this regard. The Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence will be holding a conference of all law enforcement agencies and child welfare agencies in July—which I will open—in order to emphasise the importance which is being placed by Ministers in all jurisdictions on identifying this particular problem and attempting to deal with it. I would hope—and I would be absolutely certain—that throughout the community there would be strong support for this attack on child pornography and paedophilia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the Government satisfied that Senator Richardson's report to the Prime Minister in which he said, `Over the past 10 years I have been aware that Mr Symons was involved in business activities without knowing exactly what they entailed', and his statement to the Senate that, `I have no knowledge of Mr Symons's business affairs', were entirely accurate and complete accounts of Senator Richardson's business relationship with Mr Greg Symons?

—Senator Richardson made several statements to the Senate about this issue, some of them quite lengthy. No reason has been advanced anywhere for disbelieving Senator Richardson's version of these events. The Opposition has been at great pains to drag up all sorts of circumstantial evidence but the fact of the matter is that, on the allegations which have been made and Senator Richardson's response to them, there is no material which entitles anyone to believe the allegations that were specifically made.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Button for that answer, saying that there is no reason to disbelieve Senator Richardson. In that case, I ask whether the Minister will inquire into the following facts which indicate a long-standing business relationship between Senator Richardson and Mr Symons: that Senator Richardson organised a meeting between Mr Symons and the New South Wales Government in about May 1983 on the export of Elcom coal to South Australia, which resulted in Mr Symons preparing a private report to the then New South Wales Labor Government Minister, Mr Terry Sheahan; that Senator Richardson then made personal representations to the then New South Wales Premier, Mr Neville Wran, and supplied him with extensive documentation on Mr Symons's affairs and arranged a meeting between Mr Symons and the New South Wales Premier; and that Senator Richardson received extensive briefings about Mr Symons's scheme to obtain an exclusive licence to export coal from Elcom mines. Does the Government have any other evidence of business links between Senator Richardson and Mr Symons? Is the Government still satisfied that Senator Richardson has not misled it or this Parliament on these matters?

—Senator Baume is inviting me to pass judgment on a whole range of matters—many of which are highly circumstantial in terms of the allegations which have been made—and to pass judgment in respect of issues upon which Senator Richardson has already himself passed judgment by his resignation. As I recall it, Senator Richardson answered several questions in this Parliament about the 1983 Elcom matter, to which Senator Baume has referred. I have no further knowledge of the issue than that. I do not think that Senator Baume does and I do not think anybody else has. As I have said, Senator Richardson has answered several questions on that issue. I have no further information about that. To raise an issue from 1983 and say, `Well, there must be something else', is typical of the way the Opposition has behaved in this issue.

—The Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories would be aware that there is a potential new industry developing in Tasmania based on the export of Dicksonia antarctica stems or man ferns and that that industry has the potential to provide many new employment opportunities while, at the same time, protecting the resource. The Minister should also be aware that responsible operators in this environmentally sensitive market are concerned to ensure that any harvesting that is undertaken or licensed is based on measures to ensure sustainable practices. Was the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories aware when she signed a declaration of controlled specimens on 4 May that this plant is on the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species list of endangered species, appendix II? Is the Minister aware that CITES prefers planting by commercial nursery propagation—a practice which would result in the creation of new employment opportunities if managed successfully—rather than relying on unreliable and uncertain natural regeneration? If the Minister is aware of all of this, how could the present harvesting practices being conducted in Tasmania be described as sustainable?

—I confess that, if Senator Bell had not sent me a copy of this question at half past one, I would not have been aware of this. The Minister has provided to me the following information. The Minister is aware that Dicksonia antarctica is included in appendix II of CITES, which allows for commercial trade, subject to appropriate control. With this declaration of material for export as controlled specimens, the Government has ensured that further research will be carried out on regenerating Dicksonia in harvested areas. It is also developing a tagging system to control the legal export of tree ferns. It should be remembered that this particular operation is being carried out in an area subject to timber harvesting and will extend only to the end of this year. It would be unreasonable under these circumstances to place too stringent requirements on the operator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. How is the Minister's Department going to ensure that all the World Environment Day kits are physically withdrawn from Australian classrooms? What action can or will be taken to dissuade teachers from continuing to use this material which the Minister has described as unbalanced, backward-looking, negative and offensive to farmers?
—It sounds like she is talking about you.

—That is all right. Are all schools being told to destroy the material or return it to the Minister's Department? What is the total cost, to date, of this disgraceful waste of taxpayers' funds? What is the estimated total cost of the withdrawal operation?

—I do not have any information in the briefing material provided to me by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories on precisely how this material has been withdrawn from schools. What I do know is that the Minister made a statement that the material will be withdrawn from schools. What I will do—and I will do it immediately—is ask just exactly what is being done physically to ensure that the material has been withdrawn from schools. As I understand it from the statements that have been made in Parliament, the total cost of producing this document was something in excess of $80,000.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister is being hazy about this matter. Will he table in the Senate the material—the very damaging material to farmers—that has been put forward to the schools so that we can judge for ourselves?
—You don't know what you are talking about.

—The Minister should not look nonplussed about it. If he does not know anything about the portfolio he is representing, he should say so. Will the Minister table all of the relevant material so that we can better judge for ourselves what the situation is?
—I have not personally seen a copy of this offensive—
—Why not?

—Because I have been too busy doing other things; because it is not my ministerial responsibility, as a matter of fact. I have not personally seen a copy of this document. However, I have seen published in a newspaper a copy of a cartoon extracted from the material, which no doubt Senator Panizza has seen, that I think is inaccurate and misleading and should not have been included in the material. It casts reflections in a general way on the farming community of which many farmers are not guilty. I will ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories whether copies of the original material can be made available to whichever honourable senators require it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister confirm reports that the Government has given approval for new aviation charter services between northern Australia and Asia?

—The Prime Minister in his One Nation statement announced that we would be pursuing the question of additional charter rights, and we are doing that with some vigour. I am pleased to say that recently we signed a number of important approvals for additional charter rights, which will be of great benefit to the tourist industry of northern Australia. This stands in stark contrast to the Opposition, which wants to torpedo that industry with the imposition of a GST. I might point out, if anybody needed to have it pointed out, because the industry peak bodies themselves have made it clear, that not to exempt—
—More Labor lies.

—I am afraid it is not a lie to say that the only export industry the Opposition has not exempted from the imposition of its GST is the industry that earns Australia the largest amount of export dollars of the lot, and that is tourism, which currently earns us around $7 billion a year.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to advise the Senate that the Government has recently approved new charter flights between Darwin and Ambon and between Japan and Cairns. As I have said, these approvals are in line with the Federal Government's policy to promote new overseas charter services into Australia and also to promote one of the maximum values of charters, and that is to test new markets for scheduled services.

The Government has approved an application from Merpati Airlines to operate a twice-weekly service between the Indonesian island of Ambon and Darwin, to commence next month. Merpati will operate a twice-weekly F28 service on Fridays and Monday mornings. The services will commence on 8 June and continue through until 31 August. This service will coincide with the Darwin-Ambon yacht race, which is one of the main events on the Darwin sailing calendar. Merparti has indicated that it intends to operate the services to test and develop the Darwin-Ambon market, with a view ultimately to operating scheduled services on this route.

The Government has also approved a range of new charter flights between regional centres in Japan and Cairns. Eight charter flights will be operated by World Air Network, a subsidiary of All Nippon Airways, from 25 June to 30 July. The charter program follows on from a series of more than 50 charters operated by Qantas over the past two years between Australia and regional airports in Japan. The new charters will operate between Cairns and nine Japanese cities, including Sendai, Nagoya and Akita.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make a statement after Question Time.
—Senator Kemp might not like it, but it is good news for northern Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. For what purposes did Pacific Design Group receive export market development grants of $128,066 in April 1991 and $129,057 in October 1991? Is it not correct that this company was purportedly a backer of Mr Greg Symons's business activities in the Marshall Islands? I further ask the Minister whether the EMDG received by Mr Symons personally was for consultancy, advisory or representative work undertaken on behalf of an Australian company. If so, what was the identity of that company?

—I do not appear to have any briefing on any EMDG to Pacific Design. The only EMDGs of which I am aware were for two businesses in respect of which Mr Symons had an interest—first of all, Feedtech Pty Ltd and, secondly, Unipac International, in respect of which I am very limited in the amount of information under the relevant provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act that I could give to the Senate anyway. The same constraints no doubt apply in relation to Pacific Design. I will see what information can be elicited on Senator O'Chee's specific question and respond accordingly.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that his junior Minister, Mr Kerin, in fact issued a press release dated 27 May 1992 pointing out that an EMDG was paid to Mr Symons personally. I repeat: for what purpose was that EMDG paid? Was it for consultancy, advisory or representative work undertaken by Mr Symons on behalf of an Australian company? If so, what was the identity of the Australian company, and why can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade not answer a question about which his junior Minister has put out a press release?

—My understanding is that the reference Mr Kerin was making was to Mr Symons trading as Unipac International, in that instance to an individual trading under that particular name rather than under some corporate identity. I do not know whether that has anything to do with this Pacific Design reference that Senator O'Chee is making or whether it is, as I am inclined to believe on the material before me, a completely different matter.

PARA.TAB: All I am able to say about that latter matter—I do not think this is adding anything to what Mr Kerin has already said on the public record—is that that latter grant for the 1990-91 grant year was paid to Mr Symons as a sole trader in December 1991. The grant is unrelated to the Marshall Islands and is also unrelated to business migration services, which do not in any event constitute eligible services under the EMDG legislation. I am informed by Austrade that it has no evidence concerning Mr Symons's activities in the Marshall Islands with payments he has received under the EMDG scheme. If there is anything I can add to that, I will be happy to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My questions is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. The question is very simple. Did the Attorney-General's office contact the Attorney-General in the Marshall Islands last week in connection with Mr Gregory Symons?

—Since Senator Kemp asked his question, I thought it important to put on the record during Question Time the answer I have received from the Attorney-General's office, which is that the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth of Australia did not contact the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands last week, by telephone or any other means, as far as I know, nor did his office contact the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands. An officer of the Attorney-General's Department was phoned by the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands on Friday morning, I think; certainly, the morning of the 29th.

PARA.TAB: It should be emphasised that the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands, despite the noble title, is not an elected Cabinet official. He is a contract legal professional officer, Mr McPhillips, who I think was mentioned in the Attorney-General's answer last week in another place. He contacted an officer of the Attorney-General's Department and held certain discussions relating to prosecution charges and extradition matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Justice. Is it a fact that, out of 14 similar countries, Australia has the highest incidence of assault using force, burglary, stolen vehicles, and sexual incidents; and that it has the third highest incidence of serious sexual assault, following those of the USA and Canada? If the Minister is unaware of this, why did not the Institute of Criminology inform him of this international survey, as it has expressed its deep concern? If he is aware of this, what action is he taking to redeem this horrific reputation that Australia has now acquired?

—I find it quite extraordinary that Senator Walters should be invoking the name of the Institute of Criminology—an authoritative institute which is academically devoted, not in a partisan way or a way open to political influence, to describing the situation in Australia in a way which can provide a sound foundation for policy—when in fact the Opposition intends, according to the Fightback document, to abolish the Institute of Criminology, the one institution which can bring together all the Australia-wide statistics in order to enable sound policy to be made by governments. In relation to various comparisons, international and within the Australian domestic scene, of course there has been an increase in reported crime in some parts of Australia.
—That was not the question I asked you.

—I am trying to explain that the incidence of reported crime is a very important indication of, amongst other things, growing confidence in the community that people can approach their police in relation to the incidence of crime. For example, in New South Wales very recently, a survey was done which showed that the incidence of reported crime had gone up but the incidence of actual crime, by survey of households, had not markedly increased. Because people have greater confidence in a less corrupt police force, they are prepared to report these particular incidents.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Just to clarify the matter, my question was not on reported crime.
—There is no point of order.

—International comparisons are interesting and important and can be a goad to Australian law enforcement agencies doing better than they are at the moment to try to deal with the incidence of crime in Australia. International comparisons, for example, with the United States would indicate the very heavy use of pistols and hand guns in violent crimes and homicides in that society. In Australia, by contrast, out of 351 homicides last year, only 10 were carried out by the use of hand guns or pistols. Yet it is a pistol that appears on the front cover of the scurrilous pamphlet put out by the Opposition in an attempt to scare people to a level of anxiety which is not justified.

PARA.TAB: It is very important that we in Australia take such steps as are required in order to build community structures to prevent the incidence of crime in our community. That includes, in particular, helping to allay the anxiety and fears of the elderly, which I believe have been unduly aroused by the Opposition in this particular campaign over the last few days. Australia will be able, with the assistance of the Institute of Criminology and the full backing of the Police Ministers Council, to help bring Australian crime statistics into line with those in the international community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not know why the Minister is ducking for cover; I have no idea. I asked the Minister a pretty simple question, but he refuses to answer it. I asked whether the Minister was aware that, in comparison with 14 similar countries, Australia has the highest incidence of assault using force and the highest incidence of burglary, stolen vehicles and sexual occurrences. I also asked him whether he was aware that Australia has the third highest incidence of serious sexual assaults. The Minister has not mentioned in his answer that he was aware or that he was not aware. I also asked him what he was going to do about it. He has not answered any of those questions. He has gone on about all sorts of other things but he has not answered my question in any way.

—Of course I am aware of the speech made by Professor Duncan Chappell recently in relation to these international comparisons. Out of interest, Professor Chappell also pointed out some of the social, cultural and even urban structure reasons which lie behind these differences. For example, in relation to breaking and entering into households, the fact that Australians tend to live in isolated houses on small blocks in suburbs expanded out from city centres means that there is less awareness by the surrounding households of a possible break and enter being conducted, whereas in European countries, where people tend to live in apartment blocks and so on, there is a much closer surveillance of those households by the occupants or by neighbours. Professor Chappell pointed out these social and cultural differences which it is very important to take into account when bandying around these very bald statistics.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today I was asked a question by Senator Meg Lees and an answer has now been supplied to me by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. It is a rather long answer and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: FTA TRAINING COMPONENT FOR UNDER 21s
POSSIBLE QUESTION:
What is the Government doing about paying the training component of FTA following the AAT's ruling that the allowance should be paid to jobseekers under 21 years of age?
INFORMATION FOR SUGGESTED RESPONSE:

The AAT has found that the relevant section of the legislation does not allow age to be a criterion in determining whether the training component is to be paid, and that some increase over and above JSA/NSA should be paid to participants in approved training courses irrespective of age.

The government's policy since 1987 has been that persons under 21 should not receive the $30 per week training component to reflect the view that there not be a financial incentive for young persons to forgo long term secondary and tertiary educational opportunities in favour of short term training options. (Separate FTA ancillary allowances can be used to meet the additional costs of training for young people.)

The applicable legislation as it currently stands does not clearly reflect Government policy about the eligibility of under 21's to the training component, resulting in a number of successful appeals to the SSAT by under 21's seeking payment of the training component.
The proposed amendment to the legislation to be introduced is explicit in making under 21 year olds ineligible for the training component.

CES staff have been told to receive claims for the training component from under 21's but not to process them pending the receipt of further instructions from the Department. Ancillary allowances remain payable, where appropriate, for under 21's.
The Department is currently seeking legal advice as to what entitlements participants affected by the AAT decision may receive.

I add that it is my understanding that the Department of Employment, Education and Training is taking advice from the Attorney-General's Department on what to do about the entitlements of participants in this scheme. The Department expects that, within about a fortnight, it will get the answer on that advice and be in a position to say something further.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate last week, on 28 May, Senator Hill asked me whether it was not the case that on a day earlier than 14 May Mr Chris Lamb of the Embassy in Washington offered to forward a copy of the memo from Mr Symons to Senator Richardson to my Department in Canberra and that the Department advised Mr Lamb that it would not be necessary. I told the Senate that I was not aware of any such communication and would check. That check has now been done. I made the results of the check public in a press release last Friday, 29 May, but let me, as is appropriate, advise the Senate accordingly.

PARA.TAB: There is absolutely no basis in fact for the suggestion made by Senator Hill. Mr Lamb, in a conversation with an officer of my Department on 29 May, made the following points: first, it was absolutely not the case that, before 14 May, he had offered to forward a copy of the Symons memo to the Department, nor was there ever any suggestion from the Department that it was not necessary to send the memo; secondly, he had not discussed the Symons memo with anyone before 14 May; and, thirdly, the first mention he had made to DFAT of the memo was in a phone conversation he had with the Department on 15 May, which was in fact late 14 May Washington time. The Department had asked him to send the memo to Canberra immediately. He had gone immediately to the Embassy and faxed it to the Department, together with a note he had written on 14 May and a copy of his letter to Senator Sibraa of 4 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate on 28 May, Senator Alston asked me a question relating to visits to China and Hong Kong by Senator Richardson since September 1988. He asked in particular if I was aware of the nature of the visits, what information my Department had in relation to each visit and what assistance it provided. I took those questions on notice. I have a substantial answer and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson made an official visit to China in his capacity as Vice-President of the Executive Council, acting for and on behalf of the Minister for Social Security from 2 to 10 January of this year. Senator Richardson met various Chinese officials with responsibility for social security issues, including the Chinese Minister for Civil Affairs, and signed a memorandum of understanding with the Chinese Government on training and exchanges in the social security area. The senator visited both Beijing and Shanghai where the Australian Embassy and Consulate-General respectively provided the usual support to him by organising meetings and attending to administrative aspects of the visit.

PARA.TAB: In respect of Hong Kong, my Department has now checked its records which show that Senator Richardson visited or transited Hong Kong in connection with official travel on the following occasions: 13-14 September and 25-28 September 1988, transit to and from Seoul; 29-30 January 1989, transit from the Australia-Japan Ministerial Committee in Tokyo; 2-3 November and 18-19 November 1989, en route to and from the Netherlands, France, USSR and UK; 25-26 September and 7-8 October 1990, en route to and from UK, Greece and Turkey; 27-28 December 1990 and 26-27 January 1991, en route to and from UK, Ireland, Netherlands, Malta and Italy; 22 December 1991 to 2 January 1992 and 10-11 January 1992, en route to and from the Peoples Republic of China, as already described; and 21-22 March 1992, en route to USA, UK and France.

On each of these occasions my Department and the Consulate-General in Hong Kong were notified of Senator Richardson's intended travel to Hong Kong. The Consulate-General assisted in booking hotel accommodation for Senator Richardson and his party, as well as providing transport to and from the airport. The Consulate-General extended the normal courtesies for a senior Cabinet Minister. He was met and seen off at the airport by the Consul-General, or the Consul-General's delegate, and airport VIP facilities were made available.

Departmental records also show that the Consulate-General provided additional assistance in arranging appointments associated with the opening by Senator Richardson of the Australian Tourist Commission, ATC, when Senator Richardson was in Hong Kong from 25 to 28 September 1988. These included a meeting with the Consul-General and a press conference, followed by a reception on the occasion of the opening of the ATC. The Consulate-General also arranged meetings with the Director of Coaching and Technical Services at the Jubilee Sports Centre and with the ATC during Senator Richardson's transit on 29 and 30 January 1989.

Senator Richardson's visit to Hong Kong from 22 December 1991 to 2 January 1992 was a private one before commencing the official visit to the PRC as described above. He returned to Hong Kong on 10 January 1992, departing the next day. During this overnight stop, the Consulate-General arranged a boat trip to Hutchinson International Terminals. This was followed by an official lunch at the Consul-General's residence.

My Department provided general briefing for Senator Richardson for his transit of Hong Kong on 21-22 March 1992. My Department's records indicate that he was scheduled on that occasion to have meetings with Star TV, Hutchinson and Cathay Pacific during this visit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May, Senator Harradine asked about an AIDAB mission to China. I am happy to provide details on that mission. Again, this is a fairly lengthy answer. I do not know whether Senator Harradine would be prepared to allow me to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: 1.On May 27 Senator Harradine asked about an AIDAB Mission to China, and I am happy to provide details on that Mission.

2.The Australian Human Rights Delegation to China last year, which we know had a different view of Chinese population issues to Senator Harradine's, recommended that Australia provide assistance in this area.

—A recommendation to which we gave serious consideration because, as I have said repeatedly, I strongly believe that population is a crucial component in our aid program and in development strategies more generally.
—And because Chinese women deserve better quality family planning services.
3.We discussed possibilities with the PRC Government, and have received several project proposals from them. These include:
—A project on women's income-generating schemes coordinated by the UNFPA.
—And three proposals from the provinces of Ningxia, Guandong, and Hubei in the area of maternal and child health.
4.The AIDAB Mission is making an initial assessment of these proposals and investigating the scope for any future assistance in the area of women's health and family planning.
—We will consider the Mission's recommendations following their return to Australia in early June.

5.The team is led by an AIDAB officer and includes two consultants, Dr Maxine Whittaker of the Tropical Health Program of the University of Queensland and Dr Irene Bain, an Australian Rural Sociologist currently with the Ford Foundation in China.
6.Where the Mission recommends assistance we will consider this sympathetically, in line with our policy.
7.To put potential Australian assistance in context, we should remember that China's Family Planning Program is 99% funded by the Chinese Government itself.
—The activities of external donors, though currently small in magnitude, aim to improve the quality of both services and policies.
—The UNFPA, for example, assists with training, research, better contraceptive methods, and women's literacy and maternal health programs.
8.Clearly if UNFPA programs were withdrawn or if Australia decided not to assist, the situation of the Chinese people would not be any better than it is.
9.The Government has conveyed to the Chinese authorities on a number of occasions its concern that coercive practices are unacceptable.
—This was also raised by the Human Rights Delegation to China last year.
10.The Government strongly believes that the continued presence of multilateral and other donors—far from legitimising authoritarian practices—can help improve the situation by:
—Providing first-hand information of how programs work
—Providing opportunities for policy dialogue on these issues; and
—Improving quality of services, and rational policies, through direct aid projects and training.

11.It's a tall order in China. Reforms may take a long time and perhaps we can only help in a very small way—but we will not be deterred from considering such assistance by the one-sided arguments of Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill on 28 May 1992 relating to Mr Greg Symons.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that the further explanation in the answer that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade gave raises as many questions as it answers.

PARA.TAB: We must bear in mind that this is a critical memorandum; this is the one purportedly written by Greg Symons to Senator Richardson which Senator Richardson said he never saw and which mysteriously turned up in the offices of the Department of Foreign Affairs in Washington. It is a critical memorandum because, within it, Greg Symons asserts that Senator Richardson did know the details of the scheme. The third paragraph on the second page of that memorandum reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: As you know—
this is Symons speaking to Richardson—

a consortium of Australian Companies has been formed to undertake the development of the Technology Park and University Study Centre in the Marshall Islands. In the initial phase this project represents potential export earnings—
and so continues the detail.

PARA.TAB: If this memorandum were delivered to Mr Lamb by Mr Symons between September and November 1991, it seems incredible that Mr Lamb, in the Department's Embassy in Washington, sat on it until the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) asked that the search be made of the departmental records in May this year.

Mr President, why was it that Mr Lamb saw it worth while—important, in fact—to return to the Department's headquarters in Canberra in November last year a copy of your letter on behalf of Mr Symons to Mr Lamb asking for the assistance of the Department, but not a copy of the memorandum from Symons to Richardson which evidences Senator Richardson's knowledge of the scheme? I find that incredible. I trust that the Minister has inquired of Mr Lamb as to why that was the case, in the light of the answer that the Minister has just given to us that the memorandum was not returned.

I wonder whether Mr Lamb has been asked to produce the sort of statutory declaration that Senator Evans sought and obtained from his own personal staff in order to try to keep the Minister's hands clean in this exercise. What opportunity will we have of hearing Mr Lamb's version of this matter as to why he apparently sat on that critical memorandum for all those months, even the month of April when questions were being continually put in this place as to the Department's, and particularly Senator Richardson's, knowledge of the matter?

Why, during that period of questions and answers in this place, did the Department maintain this memorandum in the Embassy in Washington without bringing it to the attention of either the Department's headquarters in Canberra or the Minister concerned? If the Minister has not asked that question of Mr Lamb, I would have thought it should be asked. He should be given the same opportunity to substantiate his course of action in relation to the matter that Senator Evans gave to his personal staff member, Mr Kupa.

That is why it seems to me that the answer the Minister has given today raises as many questions as it answers. In particular, when Mr Lamb did get a copy of that memorandum, we are interested to know what Mr Symons purported to Mr Lamb in relation to it. Did he confirm the factual basis of it? In what circumstances did he give it to Mr Lamb? Was it designed again to demonstrate the role that Senator Richardson was playing, critical to the whole project? We know that he got a letter from you, Mr President, at the request of Senator Richardson. But here is another document that purports the involvement and the knowledge of Senator Richardson. Was that orally put to Mr Lamb as well as the written memorandum?

We deserve answers to those questions, because without them, unfortunately, Mr Lamb is left in a very difficult position. In terms of when the document was handed to Mr Lamb and in what context it was handed, questions arise as to exactly what was sought of Mr Lamb. We heard that there was one conversation over lunch and now we have read in the documentation that Mr Lamb in fact had more than one conversation with Mr Symons. This is the sort of detail which we are entitled to get and which Mr Lamb is entitled to have on the public record in order that his position might be vindicated in the same way that the Minister was so anxious to vindicate the position of his personal staff and himself.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —What Mr Lamb is entitled to is to be treated with a bit of dignity and a bit of decency rather than having his name slurred by Senator Hill in his desire to continue to embark upon this political frolic in which he has been engaged so unproductively for the last week. The circumstances of this matter are perfectly clear and have been perfectly well explained on a number of occasions. Mr Lamb was first contacted for his recollection of the circumstances of the contact with Mr Symons on the morning of 8 May, Australian time. At that stage he was at home without access to his files. He was asked by a departmental officer to give his recollection of the contact with Mr Symons. He did so. That was the subject of the departmental memorandum of 8 May.

PARA.TAB: It was obvious that Mr Lamb had, on his own account, dealt perfectly appropriately and sensibly with the particular situation with which he was confronted—someone, obviously with a commercial interest to pursue, which did not and should not involve the Australian Government as the Australian Government. Mr Lamb's advice, as the Opposition saw from the memorandum of 8 May, which has already been tabled, was to pursue that matter elsewhere, and Mr Symons was given some contacts in that respect.

A few days later, when the matter had been the subject of further consideration back here in Australia, Mr Lamb was contacted again by the Department and asked this time to produce a written memorandum setting out in more detail any further recollections he may have had on this particular matter. It was in the context of that conversation, as the Opposition has just been advised, that mention was made—because in the meantime Mr Lamb had obviously gone back and looked at his files—of the existence of that memo. The Department asked Mr Lamb, under those circumstances, to send the memo as soon as possible, including his own dictated document, to cover it.

That is the course of events. It is no more squalid, it is no more complicated and it is no less easy to understand than that. Under the circumstances, it just does not do Senator Hill or his colleagues any credit at all to pursue the matter in this way. A perfectly sensible explanation has been given and it is quite outrageous for Senator Hill to draw slurring attention to this very well known and very well regarded officer of the Australian Embassy in this particular way. He has answered honestly and frankly. He has put his recollections, firstly orally and subsequently in writing, to the Department. It is Senator Hill who owes this place an apology for the way he has behaved on this matter, not anybody else who has been associated with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill has made no criticisms of and has cast no aspersions upon Mr Lamb. The criticisms are of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and of his failure to fully give to this Senate answers about all the relevant matters. Senator Hill has set out specific questions that we are requiring the Minister to put to Mr Lamb so that the Minister can give frank answers.

PARA.TAB: A number of Australian journalists have approached Mr Lamb over recent weeks. As a senior diplomat of this Government, he, I believe quite properly, has not answered those journalists. I believe that the only way that Mr Lamb would properly answer is to his Minister or to an independent inquiry—whether a Senate inquiry, a judicial inquiry or some other appropriately responsible inquiry. Of course he would answer such an inquiry, and he would answer the Minister.

I believe that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, rather than surmise that there was some inference of criticism towards this senior officer of his Department by members of the Opposition or Senator Hill, ought to give us the assurance that he will pass on the Hansard of Senator Hill's remarks and questions to Mr Lamb, setting out precisely the matters that we would like advice on, and for him to be able to give that through the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

Finally, I note that a number of honourable senators on both sides of this chamber are quite well known to Mr Lamb. I, for one, on a visit to Washington in May last year—just 12 months ago—was very hospitably, courteously and professionally conducted in the inquiries I was making of the State Department and the Pentagon and, indeed, in our Embassy. I could not have wished for better professional advice from our Ambassador and from Mr Lamb. Similarly, when Mr Lamb was visiting Australia on leave, because he is the officer in the Washington Embassy with special responsibility for liaison with Congress on behalf of both the Senate and the House of Representatives and because he has contact with visiting members and senators, he very professionally visited a number of senators of this chamber and, I presume, members of the House of Representatives.

I assure the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that Mr Lamb's reputation is well known to us. It is for that reason that the questions rightly asked by Senator Hill about factual matters to which only Mr Lamb can give us the answers should be referred by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to Mr Lamb so that he can table those answers carefully and as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with my colleague Senator Hill that Senator Evans's answers have in fact raised more questions than they have attempted to answer. I agree thoroughly with him that Mr Lamb ought to be afforded the same opportunity to swear a statutory declaration as did Mr Kupa. As I have said in this chamber previously, if I were Mr Kupa I would have sworn a statutory declaration as well to look after my own interests. I think we can say that Mr Lamb ought to be afforded the same opportunity.

PARA.TAB: One of the things which remains unanswered is the memo and its origin which perhaps holds the key to much of this mystery. This memorandum which did not surface purportedly until 15 May, having been sent from the United States on 14 May—I guess that allows for the time difference and the date line—has to be compared with the statement which Mr Lamb made subsequently, also dated 14 May. Mr Lamb, in his statement, showed that he was aware that the success of the whole scheme depended on Mr Symons getting access to members of the Congress of the United States to change their legislation.

The Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Marshall Islands said that people who were not natural born citizens but subsequently became citizens would get the same privileges as attached to natural born citizens; that is, access to the United States for purposes of work and associated activities. It was indeed a frightful scam. The document between Mr Symons and Senator Richardson which has come to light shows that Senator Richardson had certainly been advised by Mr Symons as to the intent of the scheme. Mr Lamb had obviously been very careful and kept notes. His notes and the written statement are dated 14 May and the meeting took place on or about 25 November. He would not have relied upon his memory to write that note; he must have kept copious notes. We in the Senate would like to see Mr Lamb's notes of the meeting which took place in Washington on or about 25 November.

Further, as there is such discrepancy in what Mr Symons told Mr Lamb, I cannot imagine for a moment that it would not have at least occurred to him to say, `There is a difference in the sorts of things that this man is telling me and what he has apparently told Senator Richardson'. A prudent officer would have made some contact with the Minister's office and notified somebody that there was something very smelly about what was happening between a Minister of this Government and someone who calls him a friend.

Furthermore, we have this other handwritten telex dated 3 December from Mr Peter Stanford to Kylie Oakes of DFAT in Canberra about the South Pacific branch. This is the same branch of which Mr O'Leary is the Assistant Secretary and the same Mr O'Leary who had the conversation with Mr Kupa on 7 May. Miss Kylie Oakes received the fax from Mr Stanford, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We shall try to find out more about Symons and Finch and their mission in Washington, and will let you know when we do.

Where is that report? I am sure Mr Stanford, who kept the note that the Minister let us have last week, would not have done nothing about finding out about Mr Symons's and Mr Finch's mission in Washington, particularly as we have the letter from Mr Lamb to Senator Sibraa dated 4 February, the day after that fax is sent, saying:
We were able to have a useful briefing session in the Embassy—

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean December, not February. Get your facts right.
—It was 4 December after 3 December, which was the date of the fax sent, saying, `We will find out about their mission'. On 4 December there was the letter from Mr Lamb to Senator Sibraa saying:

SPEECH.PARA: We were able to have a useful briefing session—
this is with Mr Finch and Mr Symons—

. . . which aimed at offering them a useful opportunity to size up the possibilities. In subsequent conversations they said they seemed to have met the right people and to have come away with some fresh ideas as to how best to organise their business.

That does not sit very comfortably with Senator Evans's comment to the Senate on 26 May when he said in his answer to me, in explaining how he got this information from Mr Lamb, that a phone call was made from his Department to Mr Lamb in Washington which elicited the information that, yes, indeed, Senator Sibraa's letter had been followed up; that there had been an exchange between Mr Lamb, Mr Symons and Mr Paul Finch a few days afterwards; and that Mr Lamb had, as a result of the exchange, advised them that there was nothing the Australian Government could usefully do to assist them directly and they should pursue the matter themselves. They were given some United States officials' phone numbers to follow up in that respect. Very glib. It does not sit very comfortably with the statement that Mr Lamb, of his own initiative, wrote to Senator Sibraa and said, as I quoted:
We were able to have a useful briefing session . . . offering them a useful opportunity to size up possibilities. In subsequent conversations—
so there was more than one subsequent conversation—
they said they seemed to have met the right people and to have come away with some fresh ideas . . .

More questions need to be answered. Those questions need to be answered by Senator Evans.
