I have previously asked Senator Evans whether he could please give us the report relating to Mr Stanford's investigations. I ask him to inquire of Mr Lamb of his personal notes that related to the statements that he was able to write on 14 May. Further, I ask him to answer the questions I asked him on Wednesday, 27 May relating to some of the matters that were asked here this afternoon concerning activities in Suva. I refer him to pages 2711 and 2712 of the Hansard of 27 May. I ask when we can expect to have the results of those searches, which would in turn be in answer to the questions that were asked in the chamber today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make two further points on the same issue. Firstly I would like to add to the matters raised by my colleague Senator Bishop. Last Wednesday, 27 May, Senator Evans outlined fairly extensively in this chamber the nature of the documents that his Department had. In answer to a follow-up question he promised that, subject to normal FOI criteria, that material would be listed in a schedule for honourable senators to see. Senator Evans came into the chamber again today and promised that this material would be available, but I point out to him that one of the matters which is causing great concern, not only in this chamber but also in the wider community, is the length of time that is being taken for the material to be tabled. We are waiting for it. We are also waiting for other things, such as the communication to Senator Evans's office on 21 April. A question was asked about that last Wednesday. That communication comprises one or two pieces of paper and it has not yet been tabled. We are still waiting anxiously to receive it.

PARA.TAB: There is also another cable, referred to by Senator Evans on Thursday, 28 May, regarding the DFAT record. It was outlined in a consular cable of 13 April regarding the arrest of Mr Symons. We are waiting for that cable of 13 April as well. It is now some days since that matter was raised in this chamber and we are still waiting to receive it.

The other matter which I wish to raise briefly in the context of taking note of Senator Evans's answer is that Senator Hill mentioned the subject of an inquiry into this whole matter. That was pooh-poohed by Senator Evans; he then commenced a somewhat unpleasant attack on Senator Hill. I point out to Senator Evans that calls for an inquiry into this matter are not being raised only in this chamber. If Senator Evans had a chance to view the press reports from last Friday, he would have noted that there were also calls in the media for a full and proper inquiry. If he had read the Australian Financial Review this morning he would have noted an interesting comment from Mr McDiven from Multiplex. He felt that some type of inquiry into this matter would help clear the air and, in particular, give people or companies such as Multiplex a chance to answer questions which have been raised. It is interesting to note that in the Australian Financial Review this morning Mr McDiven was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I'd appreciate the chance for the truth—the full story—to be told.

Also in the context of the matter raised by Senator Hill this morning, I point out that Mr Bonney, whose clients have lost $US1 1/4m in this scam, has also called for a full inquiry into this particular matter. An inquiry might, amongst other things, help him to trace the money which has clearly been misappropriated from his clients. He has expressed the greatest concern that some of this money may have gone back to Australia and is very anxious, for very obvious and proper reasons, that this money be recovered. He believes that one of the things that an inquiry could do would be to focus attention on the matter and possibly provide information as to where this money may have gone.

PARA.TAB: As I said, there were two matters that I wished to raise. The first was the slowness with which Senator Evans is providing the information requested in this chamber. It is taking a long, long time for the material to be provided to us. We appreciate that some of it may be complex but some of it, particularly the matters relating to the cable of 13 April and to the communication from the Minister's Department to his office on 21 April, is, I would think, fairly straightforward, involving pieces of paper which could have been tabled after Question Time today. The other matter that I raised is that there are growing calls within the community for a full and proper inquiry into this matter, particularly from others who have been caught up in the whole unfortunate affair. I would urge Senator Evans to take those calls seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this matter because, as this is a broadcast day, people who may be listening should be clear about what is being called for. There is apparently a call for an inquiry into Multiplex; into Mr Bonney; into the slowness with which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) gets his documents into the House; and into what is happening in the Marshall Islands. It is easy enough for any of us to get up and say that we want an inquiry into some sort of thing. But, first of all, there is a need to come up with terms of reference which are sensible to reasonable people. Honourable senators opposite have not come up with terms of reference for an inquiry. Rather, they have created an atmosphere which they hope will lead in some way to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade being embarrassed.

PARA.TAB: There is no basis at all for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to feel in any way embarrassed. He has done absolutely nothing wrong.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one accusation has been made against the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that he in any way tried to help anybody whom he should not have helped. No accusations have been made in any way that he is responsible for what happened to Multiplex; no accusations have been made in any way that he is in any way responsible for Mr Bonney allegedly losing $1.25m.

PARA.TAB: It has been said that there was a scam in the United States whereby somebody was going to lobby the United States to change its laws. I would have thought that there was a whole industry of lobbyists in the United States trying to get that country to change its laws. It is not very erudite to say that it is wrong for people to lobby to have the laws of the United States changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Lest people be misled by what Senator Cooney has said, I have pointed out on many occasions that what was wrong with the lobbying was that there was a prospectus put out saying, `If you bought your passport and citizenship, you would get access' when, in fact, that depended upon the United States being convinced to change its laws. It was a dishonest scam.
—Order! That is a comment; it is not a point of order.

—That comment illustrates exactly what I am saying. There is absolutely nothing in that that in any way attaches to Senator Evans. If there is anything wrong with that, it should be taken up by the courts of the United States or the Marshall Islands. But I do not know why this Senate should pursue Senator Evans—and that is what it is doing—in respect of matters which clearly have nothing to do with him and which, as Senator Bishop's objection to what I have already said illustrates, are quite irrelevant to the sorts of tasks and authority he has.

PARA.TAB: I have no doubt that, again and again over the next weeks, questions will be raised by Senator Hill in his erudite way, all of which will be irrelevant; all of which, may I say, are taking up a lot of the time of the Senate. I notice that the Australian Democrats, for example, want to raise a very important matter of public importance. This issue is taking up more and more of the time available on a broadcast day. No doubt the Opposition will continue to pursue Senator Evans. I hope that he has enough patience to withstand it; I doubt whether he will. Nevertheless, the fact of the matter remains that the Opposition will not in any way succeed in detracting from a very honourable man who is doing a very good job.

I was glad to see Senator Teague get up and defend Mr Lamb. I think at least the honourable senator understands that a lot of these attacks, perhaps not intentionally, do hurt a lot of other people. When people ask these questions and pursue these matters, it is proper that they think about how other people might be hurt. I think Senator Evans is big and strong enough. He has had years of experience and he will soon rout such attacks. Nevertheless, it is a problem when other people are affected. In any event, I do not want to hold up the Democrats in pursuing their proper role in the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the additional response given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston on 28 May 1992 relating to visits to Hong Kong by Senator Richardson over the last three and a half years.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be recalled that I asked for the full nature and extent of what I believed to be six official visits to Hong Kong. Today, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) provided an answer which indicates that Senator Richardson has visited Hong Kong on an official basis on no fewer than 12 occasions. All we are told about these official visits, which seem to suggest either that they are the only trips he ever made or that any other trip he made to any other part of the world had flights leading to Hong Kong, is that the assistance afforded to him by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Hong Kong relates to the usual courtesies of booking accommodation—indeed, the Minister said `the normal courtesies'—and that on each occasion officers were notified. There was one event which related to the opening of the Tourist Commission and a visit to the Director, I think, of coaching and technical services.

PARA.TAB: Apart from those almost minimal contacts, the only detail we have been provided with of any substance relates to the visit in January this year when Senator Richardson not only visited—

TALK.START.PARA: —He's leaving the chamber.
—I suspect that the Minister is leaving the chamber for a very good reason: he wants to give himself time to reflect on the inadequacy of this answer and also to distance himself—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—He's a wimp!

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from being a wimp. I think we can take judicial notice of that. He is leaving Senator Richardson to stew in his own juice because the visit in January of this year, which involved a visit to Hutchinsons, Star Television and Cathay Pacific, happens to be the one visit that was made in a private capacity. So here we have quite extensive details being provided of people being visited on an occasion when it was not even in the course of business. If we look at the other 12 occasions when he was there on official business, the only office that seems to have been visited was the Tourist Commission. I find that extraordinary. Indeed, it demands further and better particulars on the part of the Minister.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that those of us who have even a passing knowledge of what goes on in Hong Kong know that Mr David Combe has been there since 1989, or was until recently; that Mr Greg Symons had offices in Hong Kong; and that the firm of Robertson Double, solicitors, who were the recipients of the proceeds of the $250,000 paid by Taiwanese investors, is also located in Hong Kong—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was $1.25m.

—Senator Hill is right; $1.25m—$250,000 provided by one investor. Indeed, we know very little about that firm because it would seem that it is not readily traceable, although the firm named is in Hong Kong. If one takes the word of the Four Corners program, it is registered there as a firm of lawyers.

PARA.TAB: What, therefore, was Senator Richardson doing on all of those occasions to deserve the title of official visit? Presumably the taxpayers are expected to pick up the tab on each and every occasion. It is somehow quite proper for Senator Richardson to go via Hong Kong, wherever he might end up. Whether it is transiting on the way to Japan, Korea, the Netherlands, in relation to a visit to the United Kingdom, or in relation to a visit to the United States of America, all roads, all flights, lead to Hong Kong. Why this peculiar fascination with the Orient? It is hard to believe that Senator Richardson is fascinated by the climate or indeed that he is a cultural aficionado who has discovered some very interesting elements of life in Hong Kong.

We all know that it is a place riddled with fast buck merchants and wheeler-dealers. It is the very sort of place where one would think there might be a hive of commercial activity taking place. It would therefore be very relevant to the Australian taxpayer to know who Senator Richardson was seeing on those many occasions when we are expected to have paid for the trip.

So I have to say that I regard the answer as totally inadequate. It provides only a glimpse of what presumably has really happened on all those occasions. For example, we had an answer provided some months ago which indicated that in the course of one visit Senator Richardson managed to spend in excess of $600 on food and drink in one night. We know, for example, that it is not difficult for Senator Richardson to get special treatment at the Hyatt in Hong Kong.

Again, one would ask: what is the purpose of these visits? It simply cannot be rest and recreation. There has to be a lot more to it than that. Unless and until the Government and Senator Richardson are prepared to make a full explanation to the Senate, we are entitled to presume that not only are taxpayers' dollars being wasted but that also there is a lot more to this than meets the eye. Indeed, given the cast of players who inhabit Hong Kong, it is not at all surprising that Senator Richardson probably does not want to tell us what he has really been up to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Parer (from 187 citizens), Senator Reid (from 79 citizens) and Senator Short (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Campbell (from 30 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 72 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Australian Labor Party should return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy as represented by Messrs Chifley, Evatt and Hayden and reject support for an Australian Republic being promoted by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.
Your petitioners therefore request that:
The Senate call on the Australian Labor Party to return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: Petition rejecting the Labor Party's attack on our Democratic Constitutional Monarchy.
We the undersigned declare our allegiance to the present flag of Australia and object to any change to it.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Australian Government from concerned Australian citizens
(i) Human common sense insists that Australia demands from the Indonesian government an UN sponsored enquiry into the Santa Cruz massacre.
(ii) The basic right to human dignity requires a UN presence in East Timor to monitor continuous, severe, documented violations of which Santa Cruz is a well publicised example.
(iii) Your Australian voters demand that the Australian government promotes UN sponsored talks between the Indonesian government, Portugal and the East Timorese.
(iv) We demand complete cessation of all military traffic between Australia and Indonesia, including arms supply and training.
(v) We advise that your planned trip to Djakarta be cancelled unless serious and successful effort on the part of the Australian government with reference to the above four points is made.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:

1.The massacre of East Timorese citizens by members of the Indonesian military in Dili on 12 November in 1991 is only the latest, albeit most public, assault on the human rights of the East Timorese people since the Indonesian invasion and occupation of 1975.
2.The East Timorese people have not had the opportunity to decide for themselves the future course of their country.

3.Australian military equipment has been sent to Indonesia in clear contradiction of Australian government guidelines which prohibit exports to "governments which seriously violate their citizens's rights".
Your petitioners therefore urge your Honourable House and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:

1.Urge the United Nations Secretary General to send an independent international team to Indonesia and East Timor to investigate the massacre and on-going human rights abuses in East Timor and to establish an UN presence there to monitor the situation.

2.Support the promotion by the Australian government of United Nations sponsored talks on the future of East Timor. Such talks to involve Indonesia, Portugal and representatives of the East Timorese people, including the resistance and the Church, and to be without pre-conditions.
3.Stop all Australian military transfers, whether as aid or commercial sales, to Indonesia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: Political Prisoners
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned wish to:
1.Express our solidarity with the political prisoners of Vietnam, especially Dr Nguyen Dan Que whose only crime is to advocate a peaceful transition to democracy.
2.Express our disgust with the Vietnamese communist regime's flagrant disregard for the basic human rights of Dr Nguyen Dan Que in particular, and of the Vietnamese people in general.

And, while not disapproving of aid to the people of Vietnam per se, we strongly believe that this aid should not be channelled through the communist regime. reject industry codes that will sell out Australia's defenceless children,

PETITION.PARA: because children are defenceless and helpless, because they have no vote, no power, and no advocate other than you.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw the notices of motion standing in my name for 4 and 11 sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Fisheries Management Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No.20 and made under the Fisheries Management Act 1991, and the South East Fishery (Individual Transferable Quota) Management Plan 1991, Plan of Management No. SEF 1, made under the Fisheries Act 1952. Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April and 7 May I reported to the Senate on the Committee's concerns with these instruments, which relate to the notification of safeguards and to a legislative power which was not subject to tabling and possible disallowance. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Hon. Simon Crean, replied promptly to our concerns, undertaking to amend some provisions and providing a satisfactory explanation for others. Mr President, as usual, I seek leave to incorporate the Committee's correspondence in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: SOUTH EAST FISHERY (INDIVIDUAL TRANSFERABLE QUOTA)
MANAGEMENT PLAN 1991, PLAN OF MANAGEMENT NO.SEF 1

PARA.TAB: 30 April 1992

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon Simon Crean MP
Minister for Primary Industries and
Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the South East Fishery (Individual Transferable Quota) Management Plan 1991, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 30 April 1992.
The definition of "SEF licence holder" in clause 3.1, clause 14.2(a) and clause 15.2 all refer to s.31(1) of the Fisheries Management Act 1991. There is no s.31(1); probably s.32(1) is meant.
Clause 15.1(c) refers to paragraph 93(1)(d) of the Fisheries Management Act 1991. There is no paragraph 93(1)(d); probably paragraph 95(1)(d) is meant.

Clause 21 deals with setting up the South East Fishery Quota Register. Clause 21.2 sets out in considerable detail information that the Register is to contain. Then, at the end, the Manager is given a discretion in 21.2(n) to include "any other information the Manager considers relevant". This is a broad power and, although there is AAT review of decisions of the Manager, the Committee would be grateful for the background to this provision. In this context the Committee noted that the new Register provisions inserted in the Southern Shark Fishery Management Plan (Amendment) do not include such a "catch all" provision.

Clause 7 deals with the setting of the total allowable catch, or TAC, for each species covered by the Plan, with the TAC for each species set out in Schedule 3 of the Plan. However, clause 7.2 provides that the Minister may from time to time vary the TAC for a specified species and must notify the variation in the Gazette. This power to vary the TAC has important commercial implications, as clause 9.2 provides that where a TAC is varied quotas are recalculated. Such a variation is legislative in nature. The present TAC are subject to tabling and disallowance. It would seem to be an oversight that variations are merely to be gazetted and are not required to be made by amendments of the Plan, which are subject to tabling and disallowance.
The Committee would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair
Senator Patricia Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles
I refer to your letter of 30 April 1992 concerning the South East Fishery (Individual Transferable Quota) Management Plan 1992. You raise three areas of concern, which I address below.
1.The references to which you refer in clauses 3.1, 14.2(a), 15.1(c) and 15.2 are noted and will be corrected.

2.You note that in clause 21.2(n) the Manager is given a discretion to include any other information considered relevant in the quota register. You asked the background to the inclusion of such a broad provision.

The main reasons for inclusion of this provision in the South East Fishery Plan is to ensure that there is some flexibility. This is a new and complex system and the operational requirements may need to go through some evolution in the light of experience. This provision enables some additional information to be added to the register if needed for effective management. It was not felt to be sensible to require amendment of the Plan to accommodate what would probably be very minor additional details. If major or controversial changes were made to the information required on the register, I would expect that a specific additional provision would be added to the Plan at the time of the next amendments.

3.You suggest that it is an oversight that variations to the TACs need only to be gazetted by the Minister rather than covered by an amendment to the Plan, which would be subject to tabling and disallowance.

I do not agree that this approach was an oversight but it was certainly not intended to disrupt the proper process of scrutiny by Parliament. As you note, the setting of TACs is a vital part of the arrangements and has a direct impact on the viability of an operator. The intention of putting the TACs in a Schedule and giving the power of variation to TACs to the Minister recognised the need to be able to act quickly for stock protection reasons. There is a consultative process which underpins this, however, whereby the Minister takes advice from all those involved with the fishery through the South East Trawl Management Advisory Committee (SETMAC).

The current Plan has been under intensive review since its introduction at the beginning of 1991. As you would be aware, the present Plan will cease to have effect on 31 December 1992 and will be replaced by a Management Plan developed under the Fisheries Management Act 1991. I anticipate that this new Plan will incorporate a number of the changes recommended by the reviews of the present Plan. A draft of the new Plan will be put forward in the next few months and a new Plan will need to come into effect from 1 January 1993.

I will see that your Committee's concerns about the process for amending TACs are fully considered in deciding on the content of the new Plan. This new Plan will, of course, go through the full process of Parliamentary scrutiny. I therefore see no purpose in any further consideration of this matter in relation to the current Plan. In these circumstances I hope that the Committee will agree to the lifting of the protective notice in relation to clause 7 of the Plan.

FISHERIES MANAGEMENT REGULATIONS
STATUTORY RULES 1992 NO.20

PARA.TAB: 2 April 1992

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon Simon Crean MP
Minister for Primary Industries
and Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Fisheries Management Regulations, Statutory Rules 1992 No. 20, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 2 April 1992.

Regulation 21(1) provides that the fee in relation to a matter referred to in Column 2 of an item in Schedule 2 is set out in Column 3 of the item. This reference to Column 3, we suggest, should be to Column 4.
Similarly, the reference to Column 2 in r.21(2) perhaps should be to Column 3, the descriptions in Column 3 being narrower than those in Column 2.

On a more important point, the Committee is concerned about the effect of r.41, which provides fundamental safeguards for persons who pay a penalty in the nature of an administrative fine. Such persons' liability in relation to the offence is taken to be discharged, further proceedings cannot be taken against the person for the offence and the person is not to be regarded as having been convicted of the offence. These are entirely appropriate provisions. However, their beneficial effect may be undone because there seem to be no requirements for affected persons to be informed of these safeguards. The Committee regards this apparent defect as serious. Regulation 40, which prescribes what must be included in notices to those persons affected by the provisions, does not mention these safeguards. The Committee believes that the personal rights of such persons would be improved if an undertaking could be given to amend r.40 to include a requirement that all persons who are given a notice must be informed of the safeguards in r.41. In the meantime, it would be appreciated if you could ask the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to exercise its power under r.40(2) to include this information. This matter is particularly important because of the disparity between the penalties imposed by the administrative action and the possible penalties which may be imposed by a court. The administrative penalty is $200 while for offences in Part 9 of the Regulations a court may impose a fine of $1,000 in seven cases and $500 in one case. Under s.93 of the Act the penalty is six months imprisonment.
The Committee would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely,
Patricia Giles
Chair
Senator Patricia Giles

Regulations and Ordinances Committee

SPEECH.PARA: When the One Nation statement was being prepared, there was an extensive process of community consultation which concerned a number of people, like Senator Short and Dr Hewson, who took it upon themselves to make fools of themselves by ringing businessmen around the country and telling them that they should not consult with the Government. That press statement commenced with the paragraph:

In their meetings with Prime Minister Keating businessmen and their representative organisations should not be backward in their demands in telling the Prime Minister what is really needed to get Australia working again.
The Hawke Government ignored the pleas from business to act to remove barriers to employment and investment and micro-economic reform.

I then went on in the media statement—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Senator Short, your explanation is becoming a little lengthy. Have you described the way in which you believe you were misrepresented? I would remind you that you are not permitted on this occasion to debate the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I am coming to that but I have to describe what I did which is not in accordance with the comments Senator Button made the other day.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order, I wish to agree with you. Senator Short has referred to his press statement and probably the three or four relevant parts to it. But I think he needs to come very quickly to his personal explanation. —Senator Short, I think I have made the point. Perhaps you can complete your explanation.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President, but I do need to say a couple more things to show how I have been misrepresented. I take Senator Bolkus's point; I do not propose to read the full press release. I went on to list in the press release the things that the businessmen should be speaking to the Government about. The press release concluded with the statement that:

SPEECH.PARA: Businessmen in their discussions with Prime Minister Keating and his Ministers must send a clear signal that the Government has to match "Fightback" with their own vision. Nothing less will do.

On the contrary, the whole thrust of the press statement that I faxed to them was on the very clear basis that I wanted them to meet with the Prime Minister and to make the points that were contained in my statement. Senator Button would have known that. He obviously deliberately misrepresented me and thereby misled the Senate. Therefore, I ask, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that Senator Button have the courtesy and the decency to publicly apologise and to withdraw the wilful, deliberate misrepresentation that he made of me. PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The press statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Media Release
Senator Jim Short—Shadow Minister for Finance and Shadow Minister Assisting the Leader on Commonwealth/State Relations

PARA.TAB: SMF5/92

SPEECH.PARA: ACTING SHADOW TREASURER
WHAT BUSINESS SHOULD DEMAND OF PM

In their meetings with Prime Minister Keating businessmen and their representative organisations should not be backward in their demands in telling the Prime Minister what is really needed to get Australia working again.
The Hawke Government ignored the pleas from business to act to remove barriers to employment and investment and micro-economic reform.
If the Keating Government is serious about sustainable mid to long term economic reform then it has to start listening and acting.
The Coalition's "Fightback" package provides a good starting point for businessmen when compiling their own list of much needed reforms.
Examples of specific demands from business should include:
*abolition of employment taxes such as payroll tax and the superannuation and training levies;
*abolition of taxes on exports, in particular the ramshackled wholesale sales tax regime and excise duty;
*deregulation of the labour market to allow employers and employees to freely negotiate contracts of employment, stipulating conditions and levels of pay;
*reductions in personal income taxes to encourage savings and provide an incentive to work;

*streamlining the approval procedures for new development projects, abandonment of the three mines uranium policy, the reversal of the Coronation Hill and Wesley Vale anti-employment, anti-development, anti-export decisions;
*introduction of tax free savings accounts and greater flexibility in superannuation to encourage saving;
*introduction of a goods and services tax (with necessary compensatory means) to tax all Australians when they spend rather than when they earn, export or save;
*acceleration of micro-economic reform in tandem with reductions in tariffs;
*alter the capital gains tax to make roll-over provisions for small business and encourage greater employee share ownership;
*introduce training wages (AUSTRAIN) to encourage the employment of unemployed and disadvantaged labour force participants;
*expenditure cuts to ensure that there is no blowout in fiscal policy and no new unfunded expenditure promises.
These measures would reduce the cost burden to business by $20 billion and make them more efficient and internationally competitive, thereby stimulating investment, economic activity and job growth.

Moreover, the "Fightback" package has been endorsed by most peak business/employer organisations including the Business Council of Australia, MTIA, CAI, MTAA, HIA, VECCI, Australian Institute of Company Directors, ASBA, NFF and others. This is an acknowledgment that the "Fightback" initiatives are both realistic and workable.
"Fightback" clearly signals the dimension of response required to resuscitate the Australian economy and to get business back on its feet.

Experience has shown the Labor Government that half hearted efforts, such as the 1991 March Industry Statement and the October Jobs Statement, are not the solutions to Australia's worst recession in 60 years.

"Fightback" provides a real vision for Australia's economic recovery. Businessmen in their discussions with Prime Minister Keating and his Ministers must send a clear signal that the Government has to match "Fightback" with their own vision. Nothing less will do.
Melbourne
14 January 1992

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 1 June, from Senator Coulter:
Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
`That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

PROCTEXT.PARA: The necessity to revoke immediately all mining leases in the Shoalwater Bay military area of central Queensland and to retain the area in its present form, recognizing its importance as an area of extremely high conservation value and recognizing that the military presence and management in the recent past have been consistent with the protection of these natural environmental values.'

PARA.TAB: Yours sincerely
John Coulter
Senator for South Australia

PROCTEXT.PARA: Is the proposal supported?

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the debate to one hour and that the Australian Democrats, the Government and the Opposition will be limited to 20 minutes each. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the Clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity to revoke immediately all mining leases in the Shoalwater Bay military area of central Queensland and to retain the area in its present form, recognizing its importance as an area of extremely high conservation value and recognizing that the military presence and management in the recent past have been consistent with the protection of these natural environmental values.

There are precious few areas on the Australian continent, large as it is, which have not suffered very severe degradation as a result of various human activities. One such area is Shoalwater Bay on the central Queensland coast which, through a variety of circumstances, almost by accident, has escaped the enormous damage which has occurred right up the east coast of Australia elsewhere from tourism, sandmining, farming and various other activities.

PARA.TAB: Shoalwater Bay was set aside in 1966 as a military area and that, fortunately, fell before the time when the extensive tourist development along the eastern Australian seaboard began. It is a vast area. It is 1,000 square kilometres in area and it includes a very long stretch of coastline but it runs back very extensively into the hinterland, incorporating not only the beaches, but also the very attractive and very important dunal system, perched lakes—inlets which run a long way in from the ocean—mangrove areas, forests, including rainforest, rocky outcrops and mountain terrain. Because of this wide variety of habitats, it is found that this area contains a very high proportion of Australia's indigenous flora and fauna.

Although the area of 1,000 square kilometres constitutes only 0.035 per cent of the total land mass of Australia, it contains 27 per cent of Australian mammals, 33 per cent of birds, 13 per cent of frogs and 12 per cent of reptiles—and, I believe, approximately one-third of all the vegetation which is found on the mainland of Australia. It is a very important reference area. It is one which links the tropical north and the particular vegetation which is characteristic of that tropical region with some of the more temperate species to be found further south. Because it has been under military control, there has been very little access since 1966. My understanding is that, while the military had built a road into the area, that road in recent years has been allowed to grow over and essentially the only access to the area has been by sea, by way of yacht or launch, and it takes approximately 24 hours to get there and 24 hours to get back again. Consequently the human impact on this area is quite restricted.

The area is one of considerable natural beauty. The sandhills along the beach rise very steeply from the shoreline, in some places rising 400 feet and being stabilised by vegetation. One can only observe that, should sandmining occur in this region, there is no way—and I stress no way at all—that any sandminer could put those sand dunes back again, much less put back the important water holding characteristics which those sand dunes represent, or the vegetation which they carry.

The area has, of course, been visited quite extensively by fishermen and, again, largely because of its protection from the land side, it contains a good variety of fish. A number of birds which are listed under the Japan-Australia migratory birds agreement also visit the area and they require protection under that JAMBA agreement. Similarly, birds listed under the CAMBA, or China-Australia agreement on migratory birds, also visit the area.

The sand dunes in themselves act as very important areas for the catchment of water and the area immediately to the south of the Shoalwater Bay, the so-called Byfield area, is one which is absolutely vital for a number of the smaller settlements to the south because of the importance of those sand dunes as water catchment areas. There is a great deal of concern in all of those communities that interference with the sand dunes by sandmining will interfere with the availability of clean water for those areas. I can tell the Senate, having visited and spoken at public meetings in those towns, that there is virtually universal rejection of the proposal to mine these dunes for mineral sands. There is a great deal of apprehension regarding the possible interference with the water supply of those local towns. Also, of course, for the reasons I have already outlined, the conservation groups in that area are adamantly opposed to sandmining.

It may be that if one had such a pristine area as this—one which by all reasonable assessments should be free of mining—but that area contained a unique mineral of very high value without the exportation of which the country may fall into serious economic decline, one may still decide that one would go ahead and mine such an area. The facts of the matter are that the sandmining in Shoalwater Bay is of marginal economic significance at best, and probably is not economic at all. One is surprised as to why the Government at this time should be giving permission for those leases to be upheld and to proceed when the company is projecting forward to 1995 before it reckons that the price of the mineral sands may increase enough for the operation then to become marginally economically viable.

Of course, also there are likely to be significant consequences for the military use of this area. I have discussed this aspect with Senator MacGibbon. I hope that Senator MacGibbon will also uphold the valid argument that there should not be the intrusion of commercial operations involving large numbers of people moving in an area which is for military use. In passing, one must remark that at least in recent years the military has been exemplary in its management of the area as an environmentally important zone. It has taken into account extensive CSIRO studies which, incidentally, have argued very vigorously for the total protection of this area on the grounds of its very wide variety of plants and animals and its pristine nature. CSIRO has argued that way and the military has upheld its concerns. As I have said, in recent years, at least, the military has been extremely good in the way in which it has managed this area. There has indeed been very little damage and I understand that most of the use has involved bombing exercises in one very small and confined part of the total area.

When one is dealing with the economics of this, one is impressed by the fact that almost certainly these mining leases would not be profitable—they certainly are not profitable. One must raise serious questions about the figures used in the environmental impact statement as to viability. One can only reflect that the report by the Bureau of Mineral Resources said that there is a 98 per cent probability that the sandmining project proposed by Pivot Mining would show a zero or less rate of return.

I can only repeat that, if one is dealing with an area of such high environmental value and at the same time one is expecting to get minerals of great national significance out of the area, one perhaps has an equation which honourable senators in this place should consider. When one has an area which is of probably the highest environmental value in Australia, and set against that there is a proposal to mine that area and the return from that mining activity will be nil or less than zero, then there is no equation at all. Then, of course, one does not mine the area; one leaves the area in the state in which it should be left.

Using limited information on the project provided by the company and making assumptions on financing, royalties and taxes, the report from the Bureau to which I referred a moment ago concluded that no profits would be foregone should the Government decide not to grant the mining lease. I have had further analysis done on the figures in the additional information for the final EIS document. The last two pages of section 12.0 entitled `Economic Assessment' contain summaries of financial projections of two schemes for sandmining and further processing.

The document also contains a diagram which tracks through a mine at Port Clinton—Port Clinton being part of the Shoalwater Bay complex—and a dry mill at Yeppoon-Gladstone, which would produce rutile and zircon as end products and ilmenite which would be further processed to murutile at the Murso plant at Gladstone. The capital cost, cash operating costs and production levels, which are called `export sales' in the document, are included. According to my analysis, if costs go over budget and/or production levels are lower than anticipated, then these forecasts will overstate the returns.

For example, revenues are estimated on the basis of projections of the price of rutile at $700 per tonne, zircon at $600 per tonne and murutile at $700 per tonne. On the basis of ABARE's analysis of the mineral sands industry contained in the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly 4(1) March 1992, the price forecasts on which the EIS figures are based seem overly optimistic. ABARE's forecast 1992-93 prices for rutile, zircon and synthetic rutile are $600, $300 and $500 respectively. If these lower prices were used by the EIS—and assuming that the forecast price for synthetic rutile is the same as that for murutile—then the revenue estimate for the mine and the Murso plant would fall to $56m per annum, which is about one-third lower than the EIS estimate. One can only stress again that that EIS estimate had the viability of the mine as zero or very close to zero. At these lower prices, projected revenues would not be high enough above operating costs to justify the required capital expenditure. One would simply seriously and irrevocably damage this important area for no return whatsoever to the Australian economy.

The diagram mentioned earlier provides a financial scenario including a pigment plant at Gladstone to further process the murutile into titanium. This would require an additional $120m capital cost. Assuming that the forecast price of pigment has fallen similarly to the fall in price of the mineral sands which are its major inputs, and that revenues are down 30 per cent because of lower prices, it becomes clear that the project lacks economic feasibility. The long production lead times in big projects means that they are vulnerable to shifts in market prices. This is particularly the case with this project. The sandmining industry is in a depressed state at present, and I note that already 200 workers have been laid off in the last 12 months in Australia in this industry.

In terms of involvement with the local population, one must note that neither the Commonwealth Government nor the Queensland Government has involved the local community in discussions as to what those residents desire for the area. Residents and taxpayers have not been told how much they will have to contribute to infrastructure costs, such as roads, power, water and other services. As I have already mentioned, there are serious concerns about the impact of the proposed mining development on the area's water supply. These are very serious and justified concerns.

Just as importantly, many people do not want to see the development in an area that is very precious to them. I have sat on the beach in Pearl Bay with some of those people and observed the religious feeling that people have in such an important, pristine area. It was an absolutely wonderful experience to sit on the beach one morning and discuss with these people just exactly how they felt and responded, and see their emotional involvement with this beautiful area. The residents want the proposed development stopped immediately, but, as usual in these cases, their voice has been disregarded in favour of an industry bias by both the Commonwealth and State governments.

There are a number of unanswered questions with regard to the proposal to mine the sands of Shoalwater Bay. For instance, the proponent of the EIS and the company which has promised downstream development in the Yeppoon-Gladstone area is Pivot Group Ltd, a holding company for many other companies. However, as I understand it, the lease agreement has been signed by both Pivot Group Ltd and Pivot Mining NL.

I believe that Pivot Mining NL is completely independent from Pivot Group Ltd. Pivot Mining NL will actually be responsible for the mining venture. Why is this other company involved in this matter? Secondly, why is the Government entering into a lease agreement with Pivot Group Ltd when this company, in its 1991—I stress 1991—annual return stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The group has entered into irrevocable contractual obligations to dispose of its interests in sandmining areas on Fraser Island and at Shoalwater Bay in Queensland. This transaction has been reflected in the financial statements.

This means that Pivot Group Ltd must have entered into a contract to dispose of its sandmining interests some time between 1 July 1990 and 30 June 1991, before the group received approval from the Government for these sandmining leases.

PARA.TAB: I have been informed that the Government agreed to the waiving of stamp duty, provided that the companies, Pivot Group Ltd and Pivot Mining NL, complied with certain environmental conditions that have been written into the lease. How much stamp duty will be waived by this agreement? Why was such a deal entered into in the first place? That in itself suggests a marginal economic viability for this proposal. Why has the Government opened the way for sandmining in Shoalwater Bay when it has promised to exclude mining from other past and potential silica and mineral sand resource bases in Queensland, namely, Fraser Island, Moreton Bay and the Shelburne-Margaret Bay area to the north?

There is also a great deal of community concern about other land use proposals for the Shoalwater Bay area. There are eight other proposals for land use. One would like to know whether the Minister could assure the Australian public that these proposals will not also be given the green light by the Government.

There is a need for a wide-ranging inquiry, possibly by the Resource Assessment Commission, into all aspects of sandmining. It is not sufficient to limit the considerations, as is happening at the moment, to what is happening on our beaches. There are extensive deposits of sand in the old dunes south of Broken Hill. It is my understanding that mining there could be carried out with very much less environmental damage than is likely to occur on beaches.

It is also necessary that we look very closely at the downstream uses to which the products of this mineral sandmining are put. We are told by the Government that it is committed to ecologically sustainable development—in other words, development which can be indefinitely sustained. One characteristic of such development has to be that when a non-renewable resource is exploited—and the titanium that comes from beach sand is non-renewable—for use as a pigment, which 90 per cent of the titanium is, and is distributed around the world on walls, it cannot be garnered back from that use and returned into metal. That industry is not sustainable. Again, to mine our beaches in an irrevocably damaging way, to use the products of that mining for a purpose for which there are other pigments—we had paints for thousands of years before we discovered the use of titanium oxide—and to spread them around in ways in which their recycling becomes impossible, when at the same time titanium is a very important resource for many high grade steels, a use from which it could be recycled and for which future generations may well have a need, is to use a resource in a non-renewable way. (Time expired)

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—I should clarify the informal speaking arrangements in this debate. Senator Coulter, as a Democrat speaker, has had 20 minutes. The Opposition speakers will divide the time between them, that is, Senator MacGibbon and Senator O'Chee will have 10 minutes each. Senator Crowley, speaking for the Government, will have the other 20 minutes, to make up the one hour of this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it this afternoon a motion to revoke all mining leases in the Shoalwater Bay military training area. The Opposition is very conscious of the need for the preservation of the peculiar environment of the Shoalwater Bay training area. We are also fully aware of the characteristics of that area. We are conscious of the need to have a military training area for the Australian Defence Force as well as of the need for development of Australian industry and the Australian economy consistent with the maintenance of effective environmental controls.

PARA.TAB: I agree completely with much of what Senator Counter said. The area has survived because of its relative inaccessibility. As well, the peculiar characteristics of much of that country have not made it suitable in the past for grazing or agricultural activities. I differ with Senator Coulter on the point of access to the area. He said that the only way one can get in is by sea. There are a number of roads, but the fine point is that access to them is controlled. The gates are locked and chained, et cetera, and for very good reasons: this is a live firing area where exercises are carried out, and we simply cannot have tourists or the uninformed general public walking through an area where high explosive is moving at very high speed.

Finally, Senator Coulter stressed the point that it probably was not economic to mine the area. That is not a concern of the Parliament. It is for the Parliament not to harass business. It cannot guarantee its survival in an economic sense. The right to go broke is the other side of the coin of the right to earn a profit. Consonant with the responsibilities of government to see that the general public interest is protected, it certainly is not the responsibility of the Government to vet programs on whether they will be profitable.

The Opposition recognises that it is a very complex issue. We are dealing with three considerations which are often mutually contradictory: running a military training area, which is what it is primarily; running a mining operation; and, above all, maintaining the environment, which is a very difficult problem.

My attention has been drawn to an article in the press last week by Fiona Kennedy where she claims that the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter, was one of the very few Federal politicians to have visited the Shoalwater Bay area. I can recall members of this Parliament way back going routinely to the Shoalwater Bay area to witness Army exercises. The first time I went was in 1979; I am sure there was a Kangaroo exercise preceding that. There were both parliamentary and party committees. So there has been a stream of parliamentarians through there.

My own interest in and experience of the area goes back 40 years. Some of my relatives have properties around the border of the training area. I have flown aircraft over the area—C130s and Nomads—on tactical exercises with the Services. I have driven over most of it in Army vehicles. I have slept on the ground in the dust there. The only thing I always do when I am there is be very careful where I put my feet because it is an area that is rife with poisonous snakes. One of the hazards for the Army on exercises there is snake bite. I was in the area for several days last September when 6 Brigade did an exercise, and I think they had eight or nine snake bites, most of them occurring around the watering points, of which there are only two in the area.

The position of the Opposition in relation to this motion is governed by the Government's stated policy, which is on the public record. A media release dated 15 October 1990 by Senator Bolkus, when he was the relevant Minister, said that the issue of leases would be conditional on the front dunes not being touched and on a land rehabilitation program of the highest standards being put in place, and that the company would have to develop a memorandum of understanding with the Department of Defence on how the land will be used. To the Opposition, the Government has gone out of its way to cover our concerns comprehensively.

When Senator Bolkus's press release was issued there were a series of lease conditions—21 of them, according to the papers I have. They dealt with everything from the military use of the area through the environmental management plan to hydrology, which Senator Coulter mentioned. It is a matter of very great concern that Byfield Creek and the catchment area there, which supplies the Livingstone Shire with water for the Yeppoon settlement, is maintained and is not damaged in any way at all. That is covered in the lease conditions. There will be no mining of frontal dunes, which I think is quite critical. The supplies must be brought in and taken out by barge and rehabilitation must be undertaken, not only to rehabilitate the area but until such time, under the aegis of the CSIRO, as the area has become self-sustaining.

In the light of the detail the Government has made available, at this point we have no reason to oppose the mining, given the protection that has been provided by the Government. We certainly will have a major concern in watching the Government to see that it honours the undertakings it has given, but we have no reason to doubt its credentials at the present time.

In the few minutes I have left I want to deal with the use of Shoalwater Bay as a military training area. We cannot compromise the military use of that area and the availability of that to the Australian defence forces as a training area. From my personal experience, the Australian defence forces have had an interest in conservation that goes back to the 1950s. They have an excellent record in looking after their training lands, particularly in the southern part of Australia, around Puckapunyal and Seymour in Victoria. They were interested in preserving the countryside in the 1950s.

If I look at my own State—Canungra, Shoalwater Bay, the high range training area at the back of Townsville, at Tully and the Wide Bay area—the record of the Defence Department is excellent. It is important that the defence forces have access to these areas. They need space to move; they need areas in which to conduct live firing exercises. We cannot train troops without bringing them face to face with reality. While it is difficult to simulate actual warfare, live firing is part of it, and therefore we do have destruction of the environment.

Senator Coulter said that there was a bombing range at Shoalwater Bay. My understanding of the Shoalwater Bay area is that there is one range on Townsend Island and there are other areas where aerial ordnance has been dropped. We cannot escape the fact that damage is done when we detonate high explosives. It is inevitable that that is done. The Services try to restrict the number of times they do that. They repair the damage where possible and they rotate the training areas. It is important that we have a much bigger area than we need at any one time so that we do not wear out the hillsides and the creeks putting vehicles, troops and all the rest of it through them. There are very few places in Australia where we have military training areas. Shoalwater Bay is the only area we have of that size on the east coast. Even using Shoalwater Bay, there is a very considerable transport cost in getting units up to it, mainly from the south, with a few that come down from the north.

The most important concern I have in relation to the use of Shoalwater Bay for mining is the safety distances that are now required with modern weapons. We are moving into a higher technology era where laser designators and laser guided munitions are becoming increasingly common for precision guided munitions. The moment we start using lasers, the safety distances we require go up considerably over the safety distances we require for high explosive. Put quite simply, if we need one mile for a certain type of high explosive, when using lasers we might need 10 miles so that people's eyesight is not damaged.

It would be absolutely intolerable for the use of that training area to be compromised by the presence of miners and their families resident in the area. If human beings are involved in commerce there they must always recognise that they take a secondary place to the activities of the military using it as a training area. As a senator for Queensland, I will have very little patience with anyone who rings up and complains to me about the noise of gunfire or the denial of access to certain areas which comes from the use of that as a military training area.
Subject to the undertaking from the Government that it will support the measures it has listed to preserve the environment, we support the Government.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator MacGibbon leaves the chamber, I ask: what sort of snakes?
—Nasty ones; bities.
—Are they taipans?
—They would be, the odd one.

—I thank Senator MacGibbon for that. That is what I was trying to ask him before, in case he did not understand my interjection. We have been asked today to look at an urgency motion brought into this place by Senator Coulter on behalf of the Democrats that asks the Senate to take account of the necessity to revoke immediately all mining leases in the Shoalwater Bay military area of central Queensland, and it goes on. Essentially, the critical question we are being asked to look at is the revocation of mining leases. On behalf of the Government, I want to say that we will not be supporting this motion. I take comfort from the way in which Senator MacGibbon has taken us through the Opposition's points—or rather the Liberal Party's points.
—The Opposition's.

—I thank Senator O'Chee. I would not like to pre-empt his contribution. Senator MacGibbon actually illustrated in large part the reasons why the Government will not be moving to revoke these licences.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter made a number of points in his contribution. In particular, he mentioned that we have a pristine area here. I think it is, by whatever definition, relatively pristine. I understand that the military took over that land in about 1965, and it is possible that not too much had been happening there before the military took it over. However, to talk of any land in Australia as pristine in 1965 is a bit exciting. Somebody must have walked over it. Probably it was not as it ever was before, but compared to other areas where there had been felling for grazing or different land use, quite clearly it was relatively uninterfered with.

Senator Coulter went on to say that the military has been very good at looking after this land, which is a change of heart from what the Democrats have had to say about military protection of places in times past. Even more interestingly, he said that only a small area has been used for bombing. I cannot imagine any area used for bombing that would still rate the description `pristine', unless it was referred to as pristinely interrupted. No place that has been used for bombing can be a pristine area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe they were darts.

—We know that they were not. As I understand from what Senator MacGibbon has said, the defence forces have not bombed all over the place at all; they have tried to confine their bombing to an area. But it is quite clear that that area cannot be in the state it was in before the military arrived and before it started dropping bombs.

PARA.TAB: I suppose we could get down to how much land has been destroyed in this area by bombing versus how much land is proposed to be included under the mining leases. For the record, the mining leases will occupy about 5 per cent of the land of the Shoalwater Bay National Estate area. I do not know the size of the bombing area, but I am advised that the five mining leases will constitute 5 per cent of the Shoalwater Bay National Estate area. It depends on where that area is; I would not want to say that 5 per cent is very small so therefore we do not have to worry about it. But it should be noted that it is 5 per cent. It is not 50 per cent, it is not 25 per cent, it is not more than half. It is a small area in terms of percentage. I would also presume that it is probably not where the bombs have dropped, although I am not clear where the bombing area is with respect to the mining leases.

Today we are making clear what our positions are. Much work has been done over the years in coming to this decision. Most of what has been said today has not told the full story and long history of this area. It is true and important to note that prior to that land being acquired by the Commonwealth as a defence training area prospecting licences were issued by the State of Queensland and held by Murphyores Incorporated Pty Ltd and Mineral Deposits Pty Ltd. These approvals have not been given out of the blue; they have arisen as a result of a very long deliberative process dealing with rights which were in place before the Commonwealth acquired the land for a defence training area.

As I understand it, prior to 1965, under State mining legislation, a mining company holding a licence to prospect could expect to be granted a mining lease on request. Mineral Deposits Pty Ltd waived its compensation rights in exchange for the restoration by the Commonwealth of its pre-acquisition dredging leases. That action was agreed to and approved by the Governor-General in Council in 1969. Those dredging leases expired in 1988 unused. To avoid a compensation claim by Murphyores, the Commonwealth agreed that its existing prospecting licences would be continued and that any subsequent applications for mining leases would be granted on substantially the same terms as previously held from the State.

It is important to note that all of this has been a matter of considerable consideration. It went through the High Court. We are not rushing to produce exploration licences or mining leases without massive deliberation in this area. I take Senator MacGibbon's point that probably nowhere has such thought been given to the balance between the need for development and the protection of the environment. In this case, it has been complicated further by the requirements of the military which is present in this area.

In 1980 the whole of the Shoalwater Bay defence training area was put on the register of the National Estate. As I mentioned earlier, there was a settlement out of the High Court when it was tackling this case. The Commonwealth agreed to the issues of mining leases to Murphyores unless environmental reasons following the preparation of an environmental impact statement prevented the exploration of minerals. The EIS was completed in February 1990, the outcome being that mining leases could be issued subject to a number of conditions being met.

It is also important to note that the terms of the 1970 agreement between the Commonwealth and Murphyores, and the terms of the High Court settlement of the action between the Commonwealth and Murphyores, meant that the Commonwealth was legally obliged to issue leases subject to conditions. In 1990, the Cabinet decided that the leases could be issued subject to a number of stringent conditions designed to protect the environment and heritage values of the area, as well as the area's use as a military training area.

Other honourable senators have mentioned the lease conditions. It is very useful to acknowledge the presence of the lease conditions. There are 21 points. As Senator MacGibbon has already stated, it is probably the most comprehensive and thorough arrangement or detail of a lease to ensure, as much as possible, that almost every variation of environmental concern is covered. Some of the conditions have been referred to previously, but I think they need to be stated again. In particular, the frontal dunes are not be used, not to be included. Those listening to Senator Coulter might not have understood that. The frontal dunes are not to be touched. There also has to be a barging of the products, heavy equipment and fuel from the area. Senator MacGibbon also mentioned the difficulty of access—although quite clearly there is some access because it is a military training area. To minimise any further environmental damage from infrastructure, most of the comings and goings for the mining areas will be by barge.

Condition 11 points out that if any areas of special significance, which are as yet unrecognised or undocumented, are found—be they of flora and fauna or Aboriginal significance—the mining plan has to ensure that those areas will be protected and avoided by the dredge path. I will not go through all of the points of the lease agreement. Condition 16 provides that two Commonwealth Government nominees are to be afforded access to witness, inspect or examine any part of the operation, including the processing plant and any monitoring of equipment. They shall be provided with any necessary assistance in carrying out such duties.

It is important to note that if any of the conditions of this lease is breached, or if there is evidence of significant impact on the environment, the work shall halt. Point 21 is very important. It provides for liaison with ATSIC to ensure maximum protection of significant Aboriginal sites and close working with Aboriginal communities to ensure that their knowledge and expert evidence, if you like, of those areas is taken into account.

In some ways, we have here a brilliant example of what is meant by `sustainable development'. Quite clearly, there are benefits from the mining. While Senator Coulter argues that this mining can be carried out in all sorts of other places, quite clearly the exploration shows that there are significant amounts of the rare earth from sandmining in this area. The mining companies have made the economic decision to proceed. On the one hand, the Government has to balance that sort of development which, according to some reports, will provide a significant number of jobs—perhaps 400, others say 500, and I have heard others mention less than 400—in the long term. That cannot be overlooked. There will also be a return to the Government and to the people of Australia, through the balance of trade, of up to $270m per annum. This is not an insignificant mining project. On the other hand, we have an area which, by some definitions, is pristine. It has been relatively untouched over the years. It is an area which any number of people say is very beautiful and deserves our protection and keenest environmental regard.

How do we find the solution between these conflicting areas? In this sort of process, particularly the lease conditions which go with the allowance of these leases, the Government has required the mining companies to seriously understand its intentions in this matter. Protection of the environment is a very high and significant part of this Government's agenda. Mining cannot proceed, as it has in the past, with no regard at all to the impact on the local community or local environment. There cannot be disregard for the consequences of these activities. Mining companies now recognise that. In coming to an agreement on these lease conditions, these mining companies understand how serious is the Government's intent to protect the environment as much as possible while at the same time properly allowing development. If and when the operation proceeds, it will need the closest examination and supervision. I believe that it is an excellent example of what could be meant by `sustainable development'.

It is important to note that until those conditions of the lease are met mining will not proceed. The proposals by the mining companies must have the approval of the Queensland Government before the implementation of the lease permissions can proceed. There are brakes and checks at every turn in the granting of these leases, from which we should take heart. We do not necessarily want to wholesomely approve that this should be the process in every case, but it certainly shows that government, committed to environment protection, can put those stringent requirements on mining and that the mining industry can appreciate the seriousness of its obligations and come to the party.

It is perfectly reasonable for the mining companies to say, `We are not going to be constrained by all of those considerations about the environment. We are not going to do that at all. We will take our mining equipment or our mining proposals elsewhere'. They have not done that. They have found it more reasonable to actually sit down with the parties involved, State and Federal government, and take into account the conditions of the lease, which certainly indicates a serious desire by the mining companies to cooperate in this area and that they also see the importance of sustainable development.

The debates we might have had 25 or 50 years ago when mining companies would have laughed people supporting the environment to scorn no longer take place. The mining industries know that they cannot ignore the environment; they do so at their own peril. They also have to know that if they ignore the conditions of the environment they take on not only the Government but also the people of this country, both through the Government and outside of government, who say that wilful and wanton damage of the environment will not be allowed, as has been the case in the past.

Strangely, this Shoalwater Bay development, in providing this kind of example, deserves our most serious supervision and following of progress. Not only is this development a matter of concern between environment and mining—if you like, government and its concern for the environment being the same as the rights of mining—but also, as has been mentioned earlier, it takes into account the needs of the Defence Force. Some of us—and I would be included—would like a situation where we never have defence forces and we never have to test weapons. I would be appalled if we were to go the way of a weapon that somehow has a laser attached to it which makes it bigger and brighter and has a `10 times factor', as I think Senator MacGibbon put it. But I am not unrealistic about the needs of defence forces for proper and adequate training. This agreement that has been reached between government, mining and the Department of the Defence—which is, although an arm of government separate from its concerns about the environment, clearly a part of government—is a stunning example of what could be meant by `sustainable development'—something from which we could take cautious heart.

If there is any damage—more than is permissible or allowable under the mining lease—to the environment, quite clearly the Government will move to see that a stop is put to either the whole mining operation or to those processes and practices that are environmentally damaging. At the same time, the terms of the lease conditions also provide for rehabilitation. The conditions of the lease provide not only for final rehabilitation—meaning, I presume, at the end of the mining operation—but also for rehabilitation on the go, as the process proceeds, so that the land is not left degraded, to be blown away or forgotten for the duration of the mining which may in fact be a number of years. Rehabilitation is required as the process proceeds, thus minimising the damage from the lack or presence of plants, to enable plants not only to emerge and regrow but also to bind the soil.

The Government will be voting against this urgency motion. The Government is concerned about all of the issues raised by Senator Coulter, but in its process to protect the environment, having regard to the needs of the military in this area and by placing very stringent conditions on the mining, I believe we have here an example of sustainable development.
