We should not blush but support such a process and, indeed, extend these sorts of very stringent environmental conditions to other areas where the mining industry in the past has not been required to be as concerned as government is—the mining industry now seems to appreciate that it must be concerned—to protect Australia's environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter asked the Senate to support an urgency motion to revoke sandmining leases in the Shoalwater Bay area. Senator MacGibbon and I looked at the case very carefully. There was some superficial appeal in the motion, but I agree with the comments of my colleague and friend from Queensland Senator MacGibbon that we cannot support the motion which Senator Coulter has brought before the Senate. One of the reasons we cannot support it is that clearly Senator Coulter, on the arguments advanced today, labours under some misapprehensions not only about the area but also about the nature of the sandmining that would take place.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter gave a very eloquent and very moving speech about the sand dunes, about the migratory birds and about the beauty of sitting on the beach, but many of these concerns are not real concerns at all. For example, Senator Coulter's concern that the sand dunes might be affected has in fact already been dealt with. It has been dealt with in the lease conditions, No. 9 of which states:

SPEECH.PARA: There shall be no mining of frontal dunes.

Quite clearly, the frontal dunes that Senator Coulter mentioned will not be affected. It is a spurious and perhaps misleading argument to say that this is one of the reasons the sandmining leases should be revoked. The matter has been dealt with and need not be dealt with by the Senate. Senator Coulter said that he had a concern about migratory birds. As somebody who enjoys looking at various forms of wildlife, I agree that this could be a problem. Again, the lease conditions that govern this sandmining lease deal with this matter. Lease condition No. 11 states:

If areas of special significance, eg major areas of rainforest, rare and/or endangered flora and fauna and aboriginal areas of cultural and heritage significance, are found during the exploration phase, the mine plan shall ensure that they are protected by having the dredge path avoid these areas.
Condition 14 states:

Special attention shall be paid to the education of all employees on the desirability and methods of environmental protection including the protection of areas excluded from operations on environmental grounds and of Aboriginal sites.

That matter also has clearly been dealt with. There is no reason why we should support this motion. The area is the subject of significant studies. The whole area has been looked at, the environmental impact has been looked at, will be monitored during the course of the life of this mine, and poses no real threat to the matters Senator Coulter has raised.

PARA.TAB: Why then should we support this motion? Senator Coulter raised a number of points that were perhaps more philosophical. He did say, for example, that these areas would be devastated. Devastated would not be the case. Senator Coulter perhaps has not sat on the beaches at the Gold Coast. Nearly all of those beaches were the subject of sandmining in the 1960s and 1970s. The area around Currumbin was heavily sandmined in the 1970s. There was in fact a processing plant at Currumbin. One would not even know it now when one goes to visit the area because, of course, it has all been restored. So it is wrong to say that sandmining would destroy the area, that sandmining would destroy the environmental significance or the beauty of the area, because sandmining clearly in the past has not done this.

In fact, Senator Coulter seems to miss the point that in Queensland these days there is increasing movement towards multiple use of land. For example, the Byfield Creek sandmining area is in the middle of a national park. The effect has already been looked at. It is considered that the sandmining will not significantly affect the national park and it is planned to go ahead. So the argument that mining industries destroy the environment, the argument that the mining industry will devastate these sites to such an extent that they cannot be restored, is clearly wrong. It has been shown to be wrong in the past and clearly will be shown to be wrong again.

Senator Coulter then raised a more philosophical argument. The argument he raised was that we should not allow this sandmining to take place because it was non-sustainable. On what basis did he say that it would be non-sustainable? He said that it would be non-sustainable because the titanium oxide which would be extracted and used could not be recycled; therefore, it was clearly a non-sustainable industry—a non-sustainable extractive process.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have that right!

—On Senator Coulter's logic, we should not mine for oil, coal, gas or any mineral which cannot be substantially recycled. One cannot put the argument that something is non-sustainable because it cannot be recycled in this industry or that industry but it is still a sustainable industry; you either have it or you do not. Senator Coulter clearly misses the point that nearly every mining industry—under Senator Coulter's definition of non-sustainability—is non-sustainable, if that be the definition of non-sustainability.

PARA.TAB: When we look at these issues we have a responsibility to recognise that we are involved in an extractive process—we are taking something out—but that we are taking it out for a purpose: to sustain the economy, to provide resources and, most importantly, to provide jobs. If Senator Coulter had his way and the motion were to be passed and the Government accepted it, then we would be losing not only a sandmine but also the jobs that would go with it. The National Party cannot accept that, when the project has already been the subject of significant environmental study and there are 21 special clauses to the lease which are designed to protect the environment and ensure proper management and care throughout the life of the mine.

It would be devastating to towns such as Gladstone—which would receive the benefit of the mine—were this motion to be passed and the Government to accept it. It is planned that two downstream Gladstone mills would result from the project, with an initial capital expenditure of $180m—$180m in an area which is already suffering very high levels of unemployment and where existing industries are not assured of being there in 20 years time, or even in five years time, because of the effects of the recession and the drop in global demand for many of the products that are made there. What we are talking about here is turning our backs on $180m worth of potential investment in Gladstone alone with just two mills. An enormous boost to the economy of Gladstone and central Queensland would flow from this mine if it were given the chance, but Senator Coulter does not wish to give it that chance.

Finally, Senator Coulter told the Senate that the profitability of this mine is marginal. The profitability of this mine may be marginal—maybe it is not marginal—but is it for the Senate to be the arbiter of business transactions and business investment in this country? Is it for us, as members of the Senate, to sit here and say, `This project is viable; that project is not viable, therefore we are not going to allow that project to take place.'? Of course that is not our role in the Senate. If we agree to these leases on principle, albeit with conditions, then it is for the company concerned to make the judgment as to whether the mine is viable and whether it will go ahead. If the mine is not viable, as Senator Coulter would have us believe, then the company is clearly not going to invest in it.

With respect to Senator Coulter, it is a furphy to suggest that the mine is possibly marginally viable and, therefore, we should block it. It does not follow that we should take that course of action and, as a senator from Queensland, I would be loath to vote for a motion which overrides the initial and ongoing environmental studies that have been done; to vote for a motion that would not create jobs but would, in fact, cause the loss of jobs; to vote for a motion which would deprive one of our regional cities of $180m worth of investment; and to vote for a motion on the basis that Senator Coulter or some other honourable senator in this chamber believed that a particular investment project was not viable. We, on this side of the chamber, will not be supporting the motion for the reasons that have been set out—reasons which we believe are eminent commonsense.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement on the basis that I have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Opposition defence spokesman, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), made a claim in a press release issued today to which I want to respond. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Opposition today said that documents leaked by the Coalition showed the office of the Minister for Defence had been party to a scheme to allow a major defence contractor to circumnavigate—
I think it should have been `circumvent'—
contractual obligations.
That is a very serious charge. Mr Downer has totally got his facts wrong and if he had rung my office he would have found out why.

PARA.TAB: The circumstances are that a firm called Techway has contracts with the Defence Department. There was concern as to whether it was meeting the Australian content. When this was brought to the attention of my office we launched an investigation. We requested the Department of Administrative Services to look at the Australian content of Techway and to report back. Mr Downer claims in his press release that we have turned `a blind eye' and that in some way we are not concerned about it. The facts are the direct opposite. We immediately investigated this situation to make sure that the contractual obligations were being fully met. We informed Techway of this. For Mr Downer to cast a cloud over my office in such a defamatory way when the facts are directly the opposite is a very shameful thing for him to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the personal explanation of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray).

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware of the issue that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has raised, but I am not aware of what has been going on in his office or the Department of Defence. I draw to the Senate's attention that some two or maybe three years ago I was assured by officials of the Department of Defence that regular assessments would be made under the terms of the contract with IBM and that all participants in this DESINE contract would be scrutinised on a regular basis in respect of their Australian and New Zealand or ANZ content.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister whether that has been occurring regularly. In other words, has there been compliance throughout the period since about 1989 on this contract? In addition, I was given assurances at the same time by officials of his Department that the Department of Defence would also be scrutinising the total ANZ content, not from a compliance point of view but to ensure that this requirement was met. Has that regular scrutiny been carried out by his Department as well? What exactly is the position with both DAS and Defence in terms of the assurances that I was given by Defence officials during considerations of the estimates in May and October of 1989?

The snippet which the Minister has just given us simply raises more questions in respect of which I ask him to give us some response. I would be very happy if he were prepared to respond now. If he does not wish to do so, I would be happy for him to take them on notice and give me a considered response.

TALK.START.PARA: —With enormous prescience, I feel almost impelled to say that I am sure one of my colleagues will ask me about this at Question Time tomorrow. That is only prescience; it has not been organised yet. I do not want to delay the Senate now and I can probably put it more fully then.

PARA.TAB: But, yes, it has been under constant review and that did cause some friction between the contractor and the Department. It is one of the reasons that we got them together to discuss these issues. The difficulty with Australian content is determining whether it is in terms of the hardware, quality assurance or through life support. There is also a difficulty in assessing how one assesses the content—whether one does it in terms of hard material or in dollar terms. This is where some of the friction or differences between the departments monitoring this and their belief as to whether or not Techway has met its obligations has occurred. This is the reason that, when Techway approached my office to raise the issue, we brought it and the Department together and we decided to have the Department of Administrative Services, which I understand is already doing a similar inquiry with the Tax Office with Techway—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are going to do this all the time?

—Yes, that is right—do it all the time. But we had someone independent come in—and I think we all concede one way or another that DAS has had a lot of experience in this regard—to make its evaluation. Techway was happy with that and the Department of Defence was happy with that.
—But have they been doing it all the time?

—Of course they have been doing it all the time; they monitor it all the time. As I say, trying to establish in through life contracts whether one is actually meeting the requirement, because at different times the amount of Australian content—
—That is why it has to be regular; that is why I am asking you whether they have met the requirements.

—I did promise Senator Newman an explanation, but without her interrupting all the time. Through the life of the contract the amount of Australian content will change. It is arguable that one can say, `Whilst you have not met the ANZ content to this stage, because the through-life will involve more, you will meet it finally'. As Senator Newman says, the monitoring is very important.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer and the journalist in the Australian used a leaked document from a branch head to a division head suggesting a course of action. The division head rejected that. My office was sent a copy of it by the branch head and we rejected it too. Now we are being labelled as trying to obstruct or interfere in the contractual arrangements and not to meet the ANZ content on the basis of a leaked memo that was rejected. That is a nonsense position, and those accusations are a reflection on my office that borders on the defamatory, unfortunately. The moment Techway approached our office we got DAS to investigate it and arbitrate on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have not answered whether they have been being monitored all the time by both departments and whether they have been consistently within the requirements.
—Why don't you put all these questions on notice?
—I was planning to put them on notice but I got an opportunity to ask the Minister.

—If Senator Newman will stop interjecting I will try to give her an answer to her two interjections. One asked whether they have constantly been monitored. The answer is yes, but it is not possible in a through-life contract to establish absolutely, until the contract is completed, the final ANZ content. There has been a disagreement on whether there is sufficient ANZ content in the hard discs, screens, et cetera, or whether there has been an attempt to assess it in dollar terms in the through-life contract. We brought in DAS, with its vast experience, to try to make a fair assessment of that.

PARA.TAB: I must say that the report of DAS, which I understand is on the way, will probably come up with solutions to satisfy everyone. But that does not justify this trite and defamatory stuff coming from Senator Newman's colleague. I know Senator Newman has never put out anything like this. She tries to research her material and, if it does have problems, she usually does not hesitate to contact my office to check whether it is true or not. To say that my office has deliberately involved itself in contractual matters to have those contractual matters ignored is defamatory in the extreme.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled Who is to Guard the Guards? I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
TO
THE PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY'S REPORT "WHO IS TO GUARD THE GUARDS?"

The Report on the Parliamentary Joint Committee's evaluation of the National Crime Authority, tabled on 28 November 1991, follows on from the Committee's earlier evaluation in 1988. That earlier Report recommended that a comprehensive evaluation of the Authority's work, and the need for a body such as the Authority, be undertaken seven years after the date of commencement of the National Crime Authority Act 1984. The Committee has a statutory duty under section 55 of the National Crime Authority Act "to monitor and to review the performance by the Authority of its functions" and to report its findings to Parliament.
It is now nearly eight years since this House enacted the National Crime Authority Bill. In delivering the Second Reading Speech, the then Minister for Communications said:
—the Authority was "designed to effectively coordinate and lead on a national basis the attack against organised crime";

—"the basic role of the proposed Crime Authority—although there are others as well—will be to operate as an arm of the criminal investigation process, gathering and assembling evidence for transmission to other law enforcement agencies for use ultimately in conducting prosecutions".

So far as the Government is concerned, the Authority has generally lived up to the hopes placed in it. Indeed that is also the view of the other Governments represented on the Inter-Governmental Committee, the Ministerial Committee to which the Authority is primarily accountable, and which now comprises all nine Governments in Australia. The Inter-Governmental Committee's submission to the Parliamentary Committee said, in part, ". . . . the NCA remains the most effective national vehicle for countering organised crime that can be devised, given the division of responsibilities amongst the Australian jurisdictions and the need to balance effectiveness with accountability . . . ".

In its current evaluation, the Parliamentary Joint Committee has come to a similar conclusion and supports the continued existence and activities of the Authority, and acknowledges that it is now a vital part of Australia's law enforcement regime. The Committee accepts the continued validity of the reasons that led to the establishment of the Authority, and does so notwithstanding a number of submissions to it critical of the Authority and opposed to its continuation.

As the only law enforcement agency in the area of organised crime able to operate in and across all Australian jurisdictions, the Authority has been able to ensure that the targets it pursues have not been able, as in the past, to evade proper investigations because of jurisdictional problems. The Mr Asia group is perhaps the classic example of such evasion, as Mr Justice Stewart showed in his 1983 Royal Commission report.

There are some aspects of this national role which should be emphasised. The Authority has working with it officers from every police service in Australia, numbering in total 91 at 31 December last. The scope of the Authority's activities is reflected in the multiple sources of its references: of the 13 references it has received so far, the Commonwealth is involved in 12, New South Wales 8, Victoria 5, South Australia 4, Western Australia 2, Queensland 2 and the Northern Territory 1.

As a result of Authority investigations, persons have been convicted in all the mainland States. Each State and Territory has its own legislation underpinning the Commonwealth Act. Those jurisdictions which have granted references have contributed substantially to the Authority's operating costs—directly under the cost-sharing arrangements to the tune of more than $22m to 30 June last, and indirectly through the provision of the police officers mentioned earlier, the salaries of most of whom continue to be met by their parent forces.

The Authority coordinates its activities with those of other agencies. These coordination arrangements were formalised in 1991 by the establishment of a Consultative Committee and a Secretariat, which are the primary selection vehicles for recommendations on Authority references and inquiries to the Inter-Governmental Committee. Represented on these two bodies are the Australian Securities Commission, the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and all the Commissioners of Police. No other law enforcement agency is subjected to such a discipline.

In the area of investigative techniques, the Authority has adapted and extended the model of the Costigan and Stewart Royal Commissions and uses all the relevant investigative talents—lawyers, accountants, police officers, intelligence officers supplemented where required by tax officers, customs officers and other specialists. Where appropriate, the Authority has concentrated on the financial assets of those whom it has investigated, using the pecuniary penalty provisions of the Customs Act and the Proceeds of Crime Act and referring understated or undeclared income to the Australian Taxation Office. It has also introduced new investigative techniques in some particular areas of organised crime.

The proceeds of crime frozen or secured up to 30 June 1991 as a result of Authority investigations amounted to more than $38m. The Authority also makes use of the money laundering provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act. Most of the people facing proceedings in this complex area have been charged following Authority investigations. In one investigation, the value of assets frozen or secured is $9m.

The Taxation Office has issued assessments amounting to more than $47m as a result of Authority investigations. In addition, the Authority has notified the Tax Office of a further $22m in understated or undeclared income, and has assisted in the issue of other assessments amounting to more than $14m. These figures demonstrate that the Authority is targeting people at the top of the tree and that it is doing so with some success.

An example of its leadership in the area of investigative technique is the Authority's use of Chinese officers, beginning some years ago, in its investigations into drug importations, an initiative recently taken up by the NSW Crime Commission and the NSW Police Service.

The Queensland Criminal Justice Commission, the NSW Crime Commission and the NSW Independent Commission Against Corruption are well aware that innovative and successful investigative techniques arise from mixing investigative talents. The first two in particular have followed in the Authority's footsteps. The Government commends this path to police forces. The use of accountants and investigative lawyers is critical to the effective investigation of organised crime.

The Authority has also displayed leadership in other areas. It has organised operational conferences on particular aspects of organised crime. It is making a substantial contribution to lifting the standard of strategic intelligence in law enforcement agencies generally. Its innovations with information technology and electronic surveillance have attracted attention elsewhere.

The Government and the Inter-Governmental Committee believe the Authority is an essential element of the Australian law enforcement strategy, and has justified its existence hitherto. It should not be assumed, however, that the Authority can rest on its laurels. As was indicated in the Parliamentary Committee's Report, the Authority's role and function must remain under critical evaluation. While the reasons for the establishment of the Authority are still valid, there has been significant development over the past 8 years in the capacity of Australian police forces to undertake sophisticated investigations. The Authority itself has contributed to those changes, and their implications for the role and operations of the Authority require continuous assessment. Members of the Inter-Governmental Committee look to the new Chairman, Mr Tom Sherman, to move firmly to consolidate and build upon the foundation now established and to lead the Authority in a productive partnership with other law enforcement agencies.

Most of the genuinely held concerns about what the Authority might suffer and do or not do have turned out to have been misplaced. No credible evidence has been forthcoming that the Authority has been a danger to civil liberties. Nor has it been shackled in what it wishes to do: it has never been refused a reference. The prospect of political interference was a concern in 1983 and 1984, but there has been no suggestion that this has occurred. Legal challenges to the Authority's powers and the like have been few—perhaps surprisingly so. Those proceedings which have reached the Federal Court involving the use by the Authority of its powers have all been resolved in the Authority's favour. One such matter did not reach the Court, the Authority having altered its view. That these and similar fears have been allayed is largely due to the good sense of successive Chairmen and Members of the Authority, and its staff, who have established both its independence and its credibility.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee received 56 submissions and took evidence from 64 individuals at 12 public hearings in six cities. The public hearing with the Authority in the course of the evaluation was the first time that the Committee had heard evidence from the Authority in public. The approach adopted by the Committee in holding public hearings was in contrast to that adopted by a previous Committee in 1988 when conducting an evaluation of the Authority: all its hearings were in private. The public hearings seem to have been successful.

The Authority being constituted as it is, the Government has consulted the Inter-Governmental Committee on the Report's recommendations. What follows is accordingly a response not simply from the Commonwealth but from all nine jurisdictions.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee's first recommendation was that the re-allocation of resources required by police forces to compensate for the Authority's changed emphasis be given urgent attention. These are matters for Police Ministers and Commissioners. No doubt the NCA's new Chairman, Mr Tom Sherman, and the other Members of the Authority, together with the Inter-Governmental Committee, will keep the directions and resource implications of the Authority's investigations under constant review.

The number of police officers attached to the Authority fell significantly between 30 June 1990, when the number was 145, and 30 June 1991, when the number was 95—a fall of more than one-third. The change in the Authority's emphasis has already returned some resources to police services. The Minister for Justice will be examine recommendation as it affects the Australian Federal Police (AFP), and his State and Territory counterparts will no doubt be doing the same for their police services. The reduction in police numbers is not necessarily permanent or long-term. The Authority's emphasis may well change again and create new demands for police officers. These are properly matters for negotiation as and when the need arises.

The second recommendation is that there be a continuing review of the potential for duplication of intelligence functions between the Authority, the AFP and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI). The Inter-Governmental Committee accepts this recommendation. It will ask the three agencies themselves to keep the matter under review, and it will obtain a report from them annually on the situation.

The need to remove the prospect for duplication has been, and continues to be, a concern of all of the participating jurisdictions. The National Crime Authority Act specifically refers to the need for the Authority to consult with the ABCI. The co-operation between the Authority and the ABCI has improved significantly to the extent that they are jointly involved in the development of several strategic overviews of specific intelligence targets. The current Director of the ABCI has acknowledged in his evidence to the Parliamentary Committee that the two bodies have a good working relationship and healthy communication links. The Australian Police Ministers' Council, which has responsibility for the ABCI, has before it matters relating to the operational efficiency of the intelligence gathering resources of law enforcement agencies generally, including the Authority, the ABCI, the AFP and State and Territory Police.

The third recommendation is that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security be given jurisdiction to investigate complaints against the Authority, its staff and those seconded to work for it. A complaints procedure was recommended by the Inter-Governmental Committee to the Joint Committee, so the Inter-Governmental Committee has no difficulty in accepting the recommendation.

The Government will bring forward legislation to create the position of Inspector-General of the National Crime Authority. It is intended that complaints could be made by members of the public direct to the Inspector-General, or be referred by the Parliamentary Joint Committee or a member of the Inter-Governmental Committee. For the purposes of investigating a complaint, the Inspector-General would be given full and unfettered access to all Authority information, materials and staff. He would also have discretion to refuse to investigate complaints which are frivolous, vexatious, trivial or otherwise without merit, or where he is of the view that no useful purpose would be served. It is not proposed that the Inspector-General would investigate complaints against individuals working for the NCA where such a matter fell within the ambit of existing legislation, such as Commonwealth or State police complaints arrangements. The Inspector-General would report his findings to the Minister responsible for the Authority, and would report annually to the Parliament.

The fourth recommendation is that the Attorney-General's Department, in consultation with the Privacy Commissioner, develop specific privacy guidelines to cover the Authority's activities. The reasons for the recommendations are set out fully in the Committee's report. The Authority has no difficulty with it. The Inter-Governmental Committee accepts the recommendation. It is proposed that compliance with the guidelines, once developed, be monitored by the Inspector General of the Authority. The Attorney-General's Department will be consulting the Authority and the Privacy Commissioner shortly. It is noted, however, that the matter is complex and not without difficulty—as has been the case in developing similar guidelines for the Australian Security Intelligence Organization.
Recommendations five to seven go to the heart of the relationship between the Joint Committee and the Authority.
Broadly, what is proposed in the Report is that the legislative constraints which limit the Joint Committee's access to certain information about the Authority's activities should be swept away.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee has itself, in the body of its Report, acknowledged that the question of the extent to which it should be permitted access to Authority information is a matter of grave concern to each of the Governments represented on the Inter-Governmental Committee. It is not as simple a matter as is represented by some current and past members of the Parliamentary Committee.

It was not the intention of the Government, nor the Parliament, when the National Crime Authority Act was passed in 1984, that the Parliamentary Joint Committee would become involved in the operational activities of the Authority.

History has shown, however, that the relevant sections of the Act suffer from some ambiguity. This is perhaps due to the fact that these provisions were inserted by the Senate in 1984 and were not as well developed as might have been desirable. Thus, although the original Bill provided for the Inter-Governmental Committee "to monitor generally the work of the Authority", the addition of the Joint Committee provided for it "to monitor and review the performance by the Authority of its functions".

The Inter-Governmental Committee regards itself as the body to which the Authority is primarily accountable. It is the Ministers on that Committee, as representatives of all Australian Governments, who have created the Authority and keep it in being. It is they who give references to the Authority. Without their support, the national character and capacity of the Authority would immediately dissolve. It is they who provide financial and human resources to the Authority, and monitor priorities and direction. It is they to whom accountability is primarily owed. The Joint Committee does not and cannot do any of these things, and the accountability owed to it is accordingly of a different character.

It was recognised in 1984 that, because of the nature of the special powers given to the Authority, there was a need for special attention to the balance maintained between the civil liberties of individuals and the operational needs of law enforcement, and to the balance between those civil liberties and the concept of accountability. The Parliamentary Joint Committee was the watchdog established with principal responsibility to ensure that these balances are appropriately maintained.

It is the opinion of both the Government and the Inter-Governmental Committee that certain principles need to be established to ensure that the Parliamentary Joint Committee can fulfil its responsibilities without impinging on the necessary operational security of the NCA's investigations. The Government and the Inter-Governmental Committee are of the unanimous view that the Parliamentary Committee should have access in principle to all non-operational information, but should not have access to operational information the disclosure of which might prejudice—the safety or reputation of a person or the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence; the effectiveness of an investigation; or the operations of law enforcement agencies.

The solution first proposed by the Parliamentary Committee to the disputed question of access to information from the Authority is, in effect, that it become the superior body, with powers greater than the Inter-Governmental Committee. By the operation of section 59(5) of the Act, the Authority is unable to furnish to the Inter-Governmental Committee "any matter the disclosure of which to members of the public could prejudice the safety or reputation of persons or the operations of law enforcement agencies". Such matters may be furnished to individual Ministers who have issued the relevant reference, but not to the Committee. The Parliamentary Committee proposes no such constraint on itself in acquiring such material, only on disclosing it.
The Inter-Governmental Committee does not accept this solution.

In paragraph 7.57 of its Report, however, the Parliamentary Joint Committee itself recognises the problems involved in its having unrestricted access to information, and has indicated its willingness to accept a second option which would provide it with the power to access all save "sensitive" information held by the Authority. This appears to the Inter-Governmental Committee to be a preferable approach.

The Government will, after discussions with the new Chairman of the Authority and the Inter-Governmental Committee, present to the Parliament a proposal for an amendment to the National Crime Authority Act which would provide the Parliamentary Joint Committee with access to all non-operational information, together with a clear definition of operational information. The Government accepts that even with a clear definition of the type of information not to be disclosed to the Parliamentary Joint Committee, there may be occasions where the Parliamentary Joint Committee would wish to dispute a decision by the Authority that material was "operational" and therefore not available to the Committee. In the past such situations have not been resolved easily, if at all.

It is proposed to include in the draft legislation a procedure for review of the Authority's decision. It is envisaged that, following a request from the Parliamentary Joint Committee, the Inspector-General of the Authority (referred to in relation to recommendations three and four above) be empowered to review the Authority's determination and report to the Minister responsible to the Parliament for the Authority, who should retain the final decision on disclosure. These arrangements would ensure the accountability of that final decision, through the Minister, to the Parliamentary Committee and the Parliament as a whole.

It is intended that the proposed amendments to the National Crime Authority Act be formulated in a manner acceptable to the Government, the States and Territories, the Parliamentary Joint Committee, and the Parliament as a whole.
Recommendation eight is that the National Crime Authority Act should be amended to confer on a member of the Authority a discretion to hold investigative hearings in public.

This recommendation raises important issues of principle, which are well presented and canvassed in Chapter Seven of the Joint Committee's report. The Inter-Governmental Committee has, in examining this recommendation, also taken into account the view of the Authority itself, which is that the recommendation should be adopted. After very careful consideration, however, the Inter-Governmental Committee has decided that the recommendation should not be taken up, the essential reason being that the risks in the Authority conducting public hearings outweigh the benefits. The risks include danger to the reputations, rights and civil liberties of persons called before public hearings, as well as prejudice to future court proceedings. There are also operational considerations. As is noted above, the Authority's basic role is investigative: its aim is to gather admissible evidence of offences with a view to people being prosecuted. Evidence given at hearings can be and is used as evidence in court, although witnesses at hearings cannot be obliged to incriminate themselves.

In the view of the Inter-Governmental Committee, this sets the Authority apart from the other agencies which are quoted in the Report. The role of the NSW Independent Commission against Corruption, for example, is primarily the exposure of corruption, so that while the Commission can insist on answers to its questions, such evidence given before it is not admissible in proceedings. In this aspect it resembles a Royal Commission, the object of which is the truth rather than admissible evidence. In the present context, the relevant part of the charter of the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland is the investigation of organised crime which is beyond ordinary police methods, dearly with a view to the gathering of admissible evidence. As the Inter-Governmental Committee is advised, the Commission has never used its public hearings powers in such investigations. Indeed, the Commission has adopted a properly narrow view of the circumstances in which it will use its public hearings powers. In its 1990-91 Annual Report, it says that the public hearing process "cannot be taken lightly" and "should be reserved for serious matters of substantial public interest which go beyond the conduct of the individual and point out some issue of public principle".

It is relevant to note that the National Crime Authority Act provides for the Authority to hold public sittings (as distinct from hearings) "for the purpose of informing the public of, or receiving submissions in relation to, the general conduct of its operations." The Authority is prevented from divulging at such sittings "any matter the disclosure of which to members of the public could prejudice the safety or reputation of a person or prejudice the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence". It is a matter of regret that the Authority in the nearly seven years of its existence has held only five such sittings, the last in March 1990. It may be that the greater use of public sittings could achieve the objectives of those who urge public hearings—notably the fostering of public confidence and a reduction in secrecy—without running the risks attendant on public hearings mentioned earlier. Accordingly, the Inter-Governmental Committee will be asking the Authority to examine that possibility, and in doing so to consult with the Joint Committee. The possibility of some legislative change to section 60 of the Act is left open, but not so as to change the character of the sittings as distinct from hearings, nor to reduce the existing safeguards. Any proposals the Authority might wish to make will be carefully considered by the Commonwealth and of course by the Inter-Governmental Committee.

Recommendation nine is that at an appropriate time in the future the appointment of Authority Chairmen be formally reviewed. This recommendation arose from the criticisms of a number of witnesses who appeared before the Joint Committee and urged that judges not be appointed to the position of Authority Chairman. The recommendation has been overtaken by events with the appointment of Mr Sherman as Chairman of the Authority. Mr Sherman is not a judge, but he is a distinguished legal practitioner. It is the sole concern of the Government and members of the Inter-Governmental Committee in such matters that the appointee be the best person available.

Recommendation ten is that consideration be given to appointing a senior police officer, either serving or retired, as a member of the Authority. The Inter-Governmental Committee is of the view that the sole concern in assessing prospective members of the Authority should be the suitability of available candidates to fulfil that role, regardless of background. On this basis, no special consideration will be given to a police officer, serving or retired. Neither is such a person in any way disqualified from appointment. The question of future membership will be discussed with members of the Inter-Governmental Committee prior to the expiry of the current members' terms of office on 30 June 1992.

The eleventh and last recommendation is that the Attorney-General's Department consider the effect of section 12 of the National Crime Authority Act and address any ambiguities that may exist in subsection 12(4). This recommendation is entirely acceptable. An examination of the matter is in hand, and the considered views of the Authority will be taken into account, as will those of the Inter-Governmental Committee.
The Government and the Inter-Governmental Committee will continue to monitor and review the activities of the National Crime Authority, as will the Parliamentary Joint Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, Who is to Guard the Guards?, was provided after the Committee received 56 submissions and took evidence from 64 individuals at 12 public hearings in six cities. It was therefore quite an extensive review of the NCA's activities. The Government is now responding to the recommendations made in the Committee's report. I wish to comment briefly on the Government's response, which on the whole is somewhat disappointing.

PARA.TAB: The first recommendation of the Committee suggested that, in view of the different emphasis the National Crime Authority was now following, a careful and clearly detailed reallocation of resources should take place. The Government's response is that this should happen on a continuing basis by negotiation. In a certain sense that is true, of course, but in another it is far too casual. Priorities do change, but with an authority such as the NCA this needs to be done, and is being done, after careful consideration is given to the tasks that the Authority should undertake following consultation with other law enforcement agencies in the field and, indeed, after consultation with the IGC and the Joint Committee .

Priorities have changed in the last year while Mr Justice Phillips has been Chairman of the Authority, and they are likely to be adjusted again slightly with the appointment of a new chairman. Essentially, we can expect that the priorities to come to grips with white collar organised crime will remain, and we even have now a corporate plan in place. So it is possible not only to determine ahead what the priorities of the NCA are but also what the resources should be that will best serve the achievement of those objectives.

To the extent that I agree that it will happen by negotiation, it will be necessary to monitor performance and whether it is adhering to the priorities that have been established or whether success has indeed followed the attempts by the Authority to follow these priorities. It is the type of monitoring that the Joint Committee has undertaken.

It might be worth noting, even at this early stage of my comments, that somewhat later in the report the Government seems to lay stress on the activities of the intergovernmental committee and to hold out that the intergovernmental committee is the body that has the prime objective and the prime task of carrying out the monitoring process. The argument is put that it is so because the intergovernmental committee is involved through the State police Ministers and the State police forces in the day to day work of the National Crime Authority. This is indeed so and, by and large, the cooperation between the State police forces and the NCA has been constructive and useful. But monitoring is a different process, and monitoring is best carried out by an agency or committee that is somewhat removed from the day to day activities of the body it is intended to monitor. Looking at the reports presented to us by both the IGC and the NCA, we find that there has been precious little monitoring activity by the IGC.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't monitor their own police forces.

—That may well be the case. Certainly, we have had evidence that there has been little overt consultation and very little monitoring of the NCA by the IGC. Perhaps I will return to that point a little later.

PARA.TAB: The Joint Committee's second recommendation was that there should be a continuing review to avoid duplication between agencies which have the task of collecting crime intelligence: the NCA, the AFP and the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. It was acknowledged in the report that all three agencies have distinctly different tasks. In particular, the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence was, after exhaustive examination, found to provide useful information. Therefore, I find it a little odd to see it listed as one of the agencies that the coalition parties would abolish if they ever came to government. Once again, we have a requirement to monitor the activities of the NCA and the other agencies.

The Committee's third recommendation called for an inspector-general to be appointed to deal with individual complaints of people who have appeared before the NCA or who have been involved in one way or another in its investigations. That obviously arises out of the recognition that, while the Joint Committee is capable of discharging, and in fact has discharged, its duty to monitor the activities of the NCA, it goes beyond its resources and, indeed, its expertise to follow through individual complaints which require detailed investigation and could, on occasion, also require hearings. I therefore welcome the Government's acceptance of that recommendation.

Recommendation No. 4 called for privacy guidelines to be put in place. Once again, I am pleased that the Government has seen fit to accept that recommendation. Even though the Government protests that the task is somewhat complex, we are told that it will be pursued in consultation with the Privacy Commissioner.

I turn to the nub of the report, and the matter that has provided the greatest difficulty for the Committee and the NCA and now, apparently, also the Government; that is, the matter of secrecy provisions. At the moment, although the parliamentary Joint Committee is charged with a duty `to monitor and review the performance by the Authority of its functions', it is not in a position to obtain adequate information from the NCA. That was certainly well and truly documented during the inquiry and by many witnesses. The difficulty is, of course, that some of the information that the Committee would require to discharge its duties properly could affect people's reputations and, indeed, their involvement in legal proceedings; and it could disclose information that would help criminal elements. There is, therefore, a case for dealing very carefully with such information.

The Committee's first option to deal with that was to have access to such information but to impose upon itself a strict prohibition on disclosure. It is not so much the Government that rejects this, but, rather, the Minister says that `the inter-governmental committee does not accept this solution'. I find that a little strange, particularly, as I have said before, as it is this IGC which so far has done very little monitoring that we have seen evidence of.

However, the second option that the Committee put forward was to have access to all information except sensitive material. The Government has fastened on to this suggestion and has changed it somewhat, but is now suggesting that we should define `operational information'; that such operational information should be excluded from the provision of information to the Joint Committee; but that the NCA should be obliged to provide all non-operational information to the Committee. The National Crime Authority will determine in the first instance which definition the particular item of information falls under, and the definitions will be put into legislation on the basis of amendments that the Government will be preparing. I certainly welcome that.

I find that the inspector-general will review, if the Committee is in disagreement with a decision of the NCA, and that, finally, the Minister has the final say, leaving the decision in the political arena which I am not particularly pleased about. I would have thought that the work of the National Crime Authority and the monitoring being done by the parliamentary Committee should not be placed in any way in the political arena when we are talking about access to information.

The nub of the issue really is what the definition actually will be that distinguishes operational from non-operational information. It may well be that it is a definition we can work with and still discharge our duties to monitor the very important work of the NCA, but it may well be that it will be used to exclude useful information from the consideration of the Committee. In that case, it would be an extremely disappointing result to an inquiry that has been carried out thoroughly, an inquiry that has also found that the NCA is carrying out useful work in the area of law enforcement and that it should certainly continue its work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to the Government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled `Who is to Guard the Guards?'. I particularly want to raise the role of the National Crime Authority and the role of the inter-governmental committee. The inter-governmental committee is made up essentially of State police Ministers with, I think, one aberration; that is, the South Australian Attorney-General representing that State.

PARA.TAB: That group sees itself as playing an intrinsic role in the functions, supervision, monitoring and direction of the National Crime Authority. In fact, on the only occasion I had the dubious distinction of meeting with that body, together with my colleagues from the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority, I found its members, quite frankly, pompous, over-bearing and vain but, more than anything else, steeped in a deep lack of knowledge of the functioning of the National Crime Authority. It is not without significance that we say in our report that, as we have examined the functioning of the inter-governmental committee, its own performance has been absolutely appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's very rough.
—I inform Senator Michael Tate that, for instance, it has met but 16 times over seven years as a function of the National Crime Authority.
—A concentrated effort.

—Let me tell honourable senators how concentrated it was. In the first three annual reports on the National Crime Authority, in which the IGC is entitled to make a public comment, its comments were restricted to but one page. That is what I call tight writing. That was for the first three reports. Thenceforth, there has been a deafening silence. It has not even written a response—private or public—to the annual report of the National Crime Authority. The Victorian Council for Civil Liberties, for instance, notes:

SPEECH.PARA: I think the National Crime Authority needs to be seen to be accountable, and not just accountable to the IGC.
That is a very penetrating observation. It continues:

In my view, the IGC is a body that has a greater vested interest in the National Crime Authority. I do not mean that disrespectfully. You are talking about relevant Ministers and so forth, some of whose staff are employed with the Authority from time to time. To me, this Committee stands much further away from any taint of vested interest in the Authority.
And so we do. But that contrasts rather quaintly with the IGC's view of itself and its role with respect to the NCA. It says:

The IGC is firmly of the view that the IGC itself provides a better line of responsibility to ensure both the protection of civil liberties and the effective oversight of the operational and functional activities of the NCA.

Yet, as I say, the IGC wrote three pages on reports spanning a period of eight years and held 16 meetings over a period of seven years. Let us remember that the IGC is a creature of political expediency. I think it was Senator Gareth Evans when he was the Attorney-General—in one of his more distinguished careers—who noted that the only way the NCA was likely to get off the ground, so to speak, was to have the curious cooperation of the various States. I have to say that there is no stronger believer in State responsibilities than me. The difficulty I have with these collective responsibilities is finding Ministers who have themselves actually taken collective responsibilities for the functions which they demand as their absolute right.

PARA.TAB: I have always been moved by the fact that after 90 years of Federation we still cannot find a common starting date for school children. Yet we have all these State education Ministers demanding exclusive rights to spend money and exclusive rights to responsibility, but just no exclusive rights in terms of raising the money. I regret that we find a similar circumstance here in a different sphere. I was interested to note, both privately and publicly, the views of Mr Edwards, the Western Australian Labor State Minister for Police, who has been a vigorous, vocal and trenchant critic of the Western Australian Royal Commission, which happens to be exposing the corruption of his mates and the corruption of an activity over which he had judicial responsibility, or a jurisdictional responsibility at least, for a number of years.

As we look around the States we ask ourselves how effective the State police have been and how effective the police Ministers who make up this body have been in supervising, monitoring and publicly reporting on the effectiveness of their own police forces. We can go through almost every single State and see that over the last decade there has been a crisis of some sort or another with major consequences.

Without being parochial for more than but a moment, in a recent case in Western Australia the police knew of a bribe in respect of a local government. They had all the facts; they had the tapes; they had the evidence. But after two years they had not completed their inquiries, let alone launched a prosecution. That, of course, has been subject to some public criticism by counsel representing the Royal Commission in WA. That bribe and the circumstances surrounding visited some of Mr Edwards's mates. I do not for a moment suggest that he was, in any way, deliberately or accidentally inhibiting or interfering in that investigation. I simply say that that sort of activity was going on at a time when there should have been proper supervision and accountability on the part of that State police force.

As we look at the IGC and at the examples given in respect of its activities with regard to the NCA, we see that it has been equally delinquent. For instance, no management review has been initiated by the IGC since the NCA started. Nobody would know better than Senator Tate about the political and managerial imbroglio into which the NCA has been plunged on more than one occasion in the last few years. In fact, I know of no public comment by the IGC which in any way would maintain public confidence in the National Crime Authority.

When, on occasion, the problems of the NCA have been made public, such as the problems with the chairmanship and the problems in South Australia, to my knowledge, there has been no activity or endeavour at all on the part of the IGC to sort those problems out. It has been silent in its response, and its silence has reflected its activities. This is a body that had the absolute impertinence to suggest, in its submission to the inquiry of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, that the Joint Committee was most inappropriate and ought to be abolished; and I suspect it thought the Committee was totally irrelevant. Given its own performance, it had the audacity to suggest that this Parliament ought to abolish its watchdog on the National Crime Authority.

To my knowledge the National Crime Authority has not received—and I am sure Senator Tate will disagree with me if I am wrong—one single reference from the IGC. There have been no management assessments. In fact, there has been no contribution by the IGC towards the functioning, the management, the references, the conduct, the efficiency or the appointments of the National Crime Authority. As I say, there has been a deafening silence. I must say that, as I looked around at some of those Ministers making their contributions on the day I met them, I thought it is better that they stay silent because that way nobody will ever know the contribution they have to make.

I will touch very briefly on the second matter which is this question of accountability to the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. The IGC believes, for some peculiar reason, that it is made up of all very trustworthy Ministers who are entitled to be and capable of being the repositories of secret and sensitive information, including information on operational matters, but that this Parliament's Committee is not. If one looks at the way the police departments around Australia are running at the present time—how they are functioning and how they leak like sieves—it hardly gives one any confidence that they can have access to information with great safety. I seem to recall two people being murdered as a result of information being leaked out of a police department in respect of a national investigation. However, the parliamentary Committee proposes that its members be provided with more substantial information, not of an operational nature, so as to allow them to more effectively monitor the conduct and performance of the NCA.

Some little time ago now, members of the NCA appeared before the Committee. I had the impertinence or the audacity to ask them why the last chairman had resigned and whether the circumstances that caused him to resign were the subject of any internal inquiries or inquiries by other police forces. I knew that in some way the Victorian Police Department had been involved. I was told by the witnesses from the National Crime Authority that they could not tell me whether they had inquired into that or whether there had been any investigation or discussion or consideration by the National Crime Authority of the circumstances of the resignation of the chairman because, if they told me that, that may be telling me whether there was an operational matter afoot, and to tell me that would be a breach of the provisions of the Act. What a nonsense. If one cannot get that trivial, incidental information, what prospect does the Joint Committee have of being able to, with any intelligence, supervise the conduct of the National Crime Authority?

With that sort of activity and conduct in mind, I have introduced into this chamber a private member's Bill of, more than anything, a declaratory nature. Senator Spindler has gone further in his private member's Bill, but neither of those Bills, to my knowledge—in the case of my Bill it has come through the shadow Cabinet and the party room—has received any form of blessing from the Government. As Senator Spindler indirectly observed, the nature of this report is not what the Government thinks but on almost every occasion what the intergovernmental committee's view is of our report. We know what its view is: it sought for us to be abolished.

We are left with this rather limp proposal that the Government will look at the matter and see whether it can find a set of words that will provide a definition of `non-operational information'. After all this endeavour, the Government is still not competent to make judgments about the level of access that ought to be obtained by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.

In my view, this is a disappointing report—a report that does little more than reflect the cynical attitude of the intergovernmental committee. In no way does a paper of eight and a half foolscap pages begin to address this very fine document of 275-odd pages. More than anything else, perhaps it reflects the general malaise and incompetence of this Government, but certainly it reflects the predictable direction of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled Who is to Guard the Guards? The report on the Committee's evaluation of the National Crime Authority, tabled on 28 November 1991, followed an earlier evaluation tabled in 1988. This earlier report recommended that the evaluation of the Authority be undertaken seven years after the date of the commencement of the National Crime Authority Act 1984. As a result of that evaluation, the Government believes the Authority has lived up to the hope placed in it by the nine governments in Australia represented on the intergovernmental committee at ministerial level.

PARA.TAB: The intergovernmental committee's submission to the Joint Committee said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the NCA remains the most effective national vehicle for countering organised crime that can be devised, given the division of responsibilities amongst the Australian jurisdictions and the need to balance effectiveness with accountability.

The Joint Committee has come to a similar conclusion and supports the continuing existence and activities of the Authority. The Authority operates in the area of organised crime across all Australian jurisdictions.

PARA.TAB: A number of recommendations were brought down by the Committee and those recommendations have been responded to by the Government. It is not my intention to cover all the recommendations, but there are a number I wish to comment on. Before doing so, let me say something about the National Crime Authority and its effectiveness. I suppose it is hard to measure the activities of the National Crime Authority other than by way of arrests and convictions. However, if one looks at the financial side of the action taken by the National Crime Authority and the matters it has brought to light, it is very clear that the Authority has been acting in a way that will target the people at the top of the tree.

First, let us look at the cost-sharing contributions to the National Crime Authority. Those jurisdictions that have granted references have contributed substantially to the Authority's operating costs, directly under the cost-sharing arrangements to the tune of more than $22m to 30 June last, and indirectly through the provision of police officers, most of whose salaries continue to be met by their parent forces. The success of the National Crime Authority continues from that point, with the proceeds of crime frozen or secured up to 30 June 1991 as a result of the Authority's investigation amounting to $38m. The Taxation Office has issued assessments amounting to more than $47m as a result of the Authority's investigation. In addition, the Authority has notified the Taxation Office of a further $22m in understated or undeclared income and has assisted in the issue of other assessments amounting to more than $14m.

These figures demonstrate that the Authority is targeting people at the top of the tree and is doing so with a great deal of success. Those amounts—the proceeds frozen, the tax not paid, the undeclared and other taxes—total $121m. These figures show fairly clearly that the National Crime Authority is performing a massive task in its fight against organised crime in this country.

I shall deal very quickly with some of the recommendations. The second recommendation from the Committee is that there be continuing review of the potential for duplication of intelligence functions between the Authority, the AFP and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. The intergovernmental committee accepts this recommendation. It will ask the three agencies to keep the matter under review and will obtain a report from them annually on the situation. This is a step in the right direction. It did appear from the findings of the Joint Committee that there had been some duplication of intelligence. A report and continuing discussion between those three bodies might go some small way towards interrupting the duplication of intelligence being gathered by the various authorities.

The third recommendation is that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security be given jurisdiction to investigate complaints against the Authority, its staff and those seconded to work for it. A complaints procedure was recommended by the intergovernmental committee to the Joint Committee, so the intergovernmental committee has no difficulty in accepting this recommendation. I point out to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that it seems that the intergovernmental committee is having a great deal of say in the matter. Perhaps the Government should be a little more forceful.

It is pleasing to know that the Government will bring forward legislation to create the position of Inspector-General of the National Crime Authority. It is intended that complaints by members of the public could be made directly to the Inspector-General or be referred by the Parliamentary Joint Committee or a member of the Inter-Governmental Committee. This will allow people who feel as though their liberties or freedoms are in some way being infringed upon by the National Crime Authority to have some real way of making a complaint and having it redressed.

The only disappointment I have is with recommendation 8, which is that the National Crime Authority Act should be amended to confer on members of the Authority a discretion to hold investigative hearings in public. I accept the evaluation by the Government that there is some danger in holding investigative hearings in public. I know that, by conducting public hearings, some opportunity exists for the reputations of people and their rights and civil liberties to be affected. However, some of the criticism over time of the National Crime Authority has been that it is too secretive. If we are to have any investigating authority, it is my feeling that that authority should be able to hold public hearings so that it can give the public some chance of making a decision as to whether an investigation is being carried out properly.

I accept the reason that it does affect people's civil liberties and may affect some people's reputations. Of course, it could go on to affect some evidence that might come down in a court case at a later date. Weighing against that is the fact that the National Crime Authority does have a responsibility to the public. Having regard to that responsibility, I believe that in future some of the investigative hearings should be held in public so that we overcome the accusation that the National Crime Authority is too secretive in the way that it carries out its work. Some other members of the Committee may wish to speak later. Therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with some sadness that I see this report before us and that we need to have a body that inquires into the various programs and policies that have been, or are about to be, carried out throughout the States and Territories which look at the issues of crime and, in particular, violence in our society. I guess that this report has come about because of the increasing violence that is occurring in our community.

PARA.TAB: Only a couple of weeks ago, a little girl of five who had been left with her young brother was snatched from a shop in a shopping centre in Victoria, taken into a stairwell and raped. Her young brother has most probably been injured for life in the sense of his guilt and responsibility. Heaven knows what will happen to her and her family as a result of that incident. That is violence at one end of the scale.

At the other end of the scale, in March this year, in an area just near my office, a 63-year-old invalid pensioner was stripped, tied to his bed and slashed with a knife to his forehead, nose and fingers. He was stabbed in the buttocks with a syringe and repeatedly kicked and punched. While he slipped in and out of consciousness, he was repeatedly burned with an iron to his forehead, legs, back, elbow and the length of his arms—all for a $130 welfare cheque. That is the sort of violence that is being perpetrated in our community, much of it on older people in their own homes.

In Northcote in March, a 67-year-old man was beaten to death in his store, while in February an 80-year-old grandmother was repeatedly punched and kicked in her West Brunswick home. A 71-year-old man was bashed on New Years Eve and died later in hospital as a result of his injuries. A 68-year-old woman was bashed and raped in her Murrumbeena home in December. An 80-year old man had terrible injuries inflicted on him. On 22 October last year, a 60-year-old engineer was bashed in his Sunbury home. On 14 October 1991, an elderly couple were confronted by robbers in their Rowville home for the third time and bashed for the second time in less than 18 months.

We saw the brouhaha that went on last week about our brochure, which sets out the fact that serious crime has increased since 1983. Assault is up by 140 per cent; stealing is up by 69 per cent; fraud is up by 110 per cent; motor vehicle theft is up by 53 per cent; robbery is up by 66 per cent; arson is up by 109 per cent; and breaking and entering and stealing offences are up by 30 per cent. We have record unemployment and youth unemployment at an appalling level, the worst recession in 60 years, increasing family breakdown and decreasing living standards. All those ingredients, leavened with a watering down of standards—we have seen the media, business people and politicians grasping for the hot issues and the hot, sexy stories—have produced a recipe for violence.

Very rarely do I agree with Mrs Kirner, but Mrs Kirner has told the Victorian Parliament that she recognises what might happen—we only have to cross the Pacific and see what happened in Los Angeles to know what might happen—if we finish up with an underclass of children in terms of their employment and education. Professor Blainey says:

SPEECH.PARA: The nation probably has less social cohesion and less sense of common purpose than at any time since 1901.

However, Mr Keating, in his One Nation slogan, is clearly dividing a nation that is already divided by economic misfortune. This tome is a symbol of what has happened in our society, as is the need to produce a document of 208 pages about programs that are directed at looking at the issue of violence. I call on this Government to address the real issues—the economic and social issues—in this country that require us to have a document of this length rather than its petty leadership fights and its petty factional fights for preselection in New South Wales. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) today in Question Time whether he was aware of Trends and Issues Paper No. 23. He indicated that he was but then went on to talk about police notification. Trends and Issues Paper No. 23, put out by the Australian Institute of Criminology, has nothing to do with police surveys. Indeed, it is just the opposite; it is an international survey comparing Australia with other countries. Fourteen countries were surveyed in total. The paper created a victims survey rather than a police notification survey. It is too difficult to survey Australia in comparison with other countries because of the legalities associated with what constitutes assault, for instance, in the various countries. So this was done as a victims survey. There were a number of findings about which the Institute is particularly concerned. I believe that this Trends and Issues paper was the main reason for this national violence monitoring unit to be set up and the recommendations that came from that.

PARA.TAB: The 14 countries with which we are compared are England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland, the Netherlands, West Germany, Switzerland, Belgium, France, Spain, Norway, Finland, the USA and Canada. We rated the highest of any of those countries per head of population in the areas of theft of cars, burglary, attempted burglary, sexual incidents and the very common offence of assault with force. We have the highest number of incidents per head of population of any of the named abuses. The category of `sexual incidents' does not include sexual assault—it is a lesser offence. Per head of population, we are the third highest of any of those countries, following the USA and Canada, in serious sexual assault; the highest in assault using force; the third highest in sexual assault, including rape, following the USA and Canada; and the third highest in all crimes, following the USA and Canada.

I do not believe that the Australian people realise just how bad things are in Australia. These figures show that we are the third highest of the 14 countries in terms of all crimes. We do not want this fact portrayed to the rest of the world. The recommendations that the Institute is talking about here obviously result from that survey. I will be interested to see whether the Government bothers to do anything about it. When I asked Senator Tate at Question Time today what he intended to do about it, there was no response at all. He said nothing. When I asked a supplementary question and indicated that he had not answered my question, he again said nothing. If the Government is really serious, if it believes that Dr Hewson, in bringing up the serious concerns of the community, is wrong, then it must rethink its views. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the report of the National Violence Monitoring Unit. Because I have only five minutes to speak about a 217 page document, I have to limit myself to one recommendation, recommendation 95 on page 175. The recommendation states:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal should consider requiring more detailed classification program description to enable television viewers to exercise informed choice of programs, and to enable those responsible for children to exercise responsibility for children's viewing practices.

SPEECH.PARA: Parents want more than that. There has been a significant increase in complaints to television stations and to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal about the level of violence and offensive sexual material being broadcast by TV stations. Australian parents do not want to be lectured by this unit that the ABT should have more detailed descriptions. They want tighter guidelines. They do not want the situation that we have now where television broadcasting is virtually self-regulatory. There is definitely an increase in the level of violence and offending sexual material on TV and that is likely to continue.

PARA.TAB: Professor Brent Waters, who is consulted by the Film Censorship Board, appeared on 2 April before the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies. I refer in particular to the evidence that appears on pages 1197 and 1198 of the Hansard report. I asked him:

SPEECH.PARA: So, you would suggest that the interim standards of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal should conform to those of the OFLC?
That is the Film Censorship Board. Professor Waters said:
Yes.
I asked:
Do you realise that that would mean there would be a broader range of very violent material going on to television?
Professor Waters said:
Yes.
He went on to say that we should be concerned about time, that this material should be shown late at night, et cetera. The need to educate parents came through again.

PARA.TAB: Today the Film Censorship Board told us that although Professor Waters is consulted by the Board from time to time, he does not speak for the board.
