We were also told that the exercise currently being engaged in by the ABT and the OFLC, the Film Censorship Board, would not result in more levels of violence. But when the Board was asked whether it could describe to the Committee definitively whether or not the level of violent material actually going over broadcast television was appropriate at this time, it could not. Then it said, `Oh, but it is our intention not to see more violence going on TV'. Let us look at its intention in 1988 when it changed the guidelines on violence. It said to the Committee that it was its intention to see that there was less violence.

If we look at the guidelines from 1987 and 1988, as presented to us by Mrs Beryl Van Luyn from the National Viewers and Listeners Association, we will see the difference between the `M' category in violence in 1987 and the `M' category in 1988. In 1987 violence which was gratuitous, exploitative, relished, cruel or unduly explicit was not permitted in the `M' classification. In 1988, in the `M' category, `realistic violence of medium intensity may be depicted but violent depictions with a high degree of realism or impact are acceptable only if contextually justified'. The `contextually justified' loophole enabled the review board to override the `R' classification and make the rape film, The Accused, an `M' classification, legally available to children. That is a disgrace. That is precisely what has happened. The Film Censorship Board has not reclassified into a higher classification any material that was available before 1987. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: On a number of occasions I have raised the question of treaties being dumped into this Parliament. Twenty-nine treaties have been dumped onto the table. The list is made up of treaties signed for Australia but requiring further action before entering into force for Australia, treaties signed for Australia which have entered into force, and treaties acceded to or accepted by Australia.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the parliamentary process does not enable a proper input into consideration of international treaties. Clearly, some of these treaties are fairly routine but there are a lot of treaties which are signed and which have great implications for national and State laws. The very fact that the Federal Government can utilise treaties—that is, utilise the external affairs power—in order to bring into this Parliament legislation which will override the powers of the States is an example. It is a very real example as to why this Parliament—particularly the Senate, which is supposed to be the guardian of the rights of the States—should have more say in treaties and provide more direction, as it were, to the Government with respect to those major treaties which very often have broad-ranging ramifications for the people of Australia and State governments and State parliaments.

I do not suggest that the Parliament should waste too much time on a treaty such as the Air Services Agreement with Brunei Darussalam, which was done at Canberra on 30 April 1992 and entered into force on 30 April 1992. I believe that this Parliament, this Senate, should establish a Senate standing committee, as I have proposed, to examine proposed treaties so that the Parliament can have more input and more say. Possibly we would have had fewer problems with the Bill of Rights, fewer problems relating to the CEDAW convention and a whole range of other conventions, had the Parliament been consulted, had there been a procedure, a structure, which would have enabled the Parliament to at least have a good look at these treaties instead of what occurs now. What occurs now is that all of these treaties come in, they are dumped onto the table and we have only five minutes to deal with the lot. It is impossible. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! On behalf of the President, I table the original certificate received through his Excellency the Governor-General, from the Governor of South Australia, of the choice by the South Australian Parliament of Alan Baird Ferguson as a senator to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator John Wayne Olsen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I presume from its title—National Health Act, Report to Parliament under section 135AA, 28 May 1992—that this document contains the privacy guidelines for the conduct of the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits program. The legislation which was brought in states:
The Privacy Commissioner must, by notice in writing, issue guidelines for the conduct of the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits program.

This has been an area of concern to me for a considerable amount of time. When the pharmaceutical benefits scheme went into the health insurance scheme with Medicare, it occurred to me, like Archimedes when he was sitting in the bath tub, that suddenly all the data on Australians who had a Medicare claim or who had received a pharmaceutical benefit would be stored in one department. It was of concern to me.

PARA.TAB: I have raised this in Estimates committees over a period of about two and a half years. When I first raised it, it seemed that the Health Insurance Commission was not very concerned about the issue—not for any malevolent reason but perhaps because it had not occurred to the Commission that there were real live people at the end of the records, and that there is much sensitive data which can be identified by the treatment number and the type of pharmaceutical which somebody may be receiving.

Gradually, the Commission has admitted that there are privacy concerns to be addressed. The Privacy Commissioner is now issuing privacy guidelines for the conduct of Medicare and the pharmaceutical program. I welcome this. I will need to look at those guidelines very carefully to see what I think of them. I ask all honourable senators to look at them carefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think he has issued them. That's the point, isn't it?

—I am in a very difficult situation. I can go only on the title of the document because it was not available to me before it was tabled. I have been waiting for this come on because I knew it was about to occur. I would have liked 10 minutes to have gone through the document beforehand. If these are the guidelines which I am waiting for—Senator Tate may or may not know whether they are—I draw them to the attention of all honourable senators. It is an important issue; it is an issue about the privacy of all Australians.

PARA.TAB: This is entitled, Medicare and Pharmaceutical Benefits Program, Privacy Guidelines, Report, so I presume that is what we are talking about. I was part of the consultation which was undertaken with respect to these guidelines. I have taken a specific and careful interest in them. I draw these guidelines to the attention of all honourable senators. They are of significance for all Australians. The only way Australians can avoid being on these records is by paying for their medical treatment without receiving a Medicare rebate, and paying for their pharmaceuticals without receiving pharmaceutical benefits. There are few of us in that situation—99.99 per cent of Australia's population is caught up with its records being there.

It is of vital importance that we address this issue. There are a number of levels which need to be addressed on the issue of privacy with regard to these pharmaceutical records. Should they be depersonalised? How long should they be kept? These issues have to be addressed. The issue should be debated. It has not been taken up by the press. It ought to be debated and looked at carefully because it has implications in the short term and it has implications in the long term. I draw the attention of honourable senators to those guidelines and ask that they be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will have noted Senator Kay Patterson's deep interest in this matter. I am not too sure where we are at and what the motion is. Have we moved to take note of the document?
—Yes, the motion is that the Senate take note of the document.
—Has it been tabled?
—Yes, it has been tabled.

—Before the dinner break I was speaking on a report issued by the Privacy Commissioner under section 135AA of the National Health Act. I presumed that the document that was tabled would be the guidelines because that was what we were waiting for. I am informed that the Privacy Commissioner is not actually issuing privacy guidelines for the conduct of the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits programs in this report. As he is required to do under section 135AA(3) of the Act, the Privacy Commissioner is in this report informing the Parliament that he has been unable to issue these guidelines prior to the due date of 1 April 1992.

PARA.TAB: The reason for this failure is in no way the responsibility or the fault of the Privacy Commissioner. The fact is that the Attorney-General's Department believes there is a need to amend the overriding legislation to ensure that the Privacy Commissioner's guidelines do not have any unintended consequences in terms of the de-identification of health-related data. The Government has foreshadowed that these amendments will be included in legislation to be debated during the Budget session, and the Privacy Commissioner has indicated that if this legislation is passed the guidelines will then be issued as a disallowable instrument, which is required by the Act.

As I said before the dinner break, there is a need for fully fledged public debate on what should be done with the personalised medical-related information which the vast majority of Australians provide to the Health Insurance Commission. Many important issues must be considered. For example, for how long should the Health Insurance Commission, or the bureaucrats, be able to hold this information in an identifiable form? Should it be de-identified permanently? Should people have access to health information about themselves? Under what circumstances should the Health Insurance Commission or the Department be able to re-identify historical medical data?

The Health Insurance Commission might argue that some of the amendments I put when this legislation was going through have caused some of these problems. I make no apology whatsoever for that. The Government had the chance to look at those amendments. Yes, there are some unintended consequences of those amendments. For example, can an individual have his or her information retrieved?

The debate we have to have is on two levels, as I said before dinner. Do we depersonalise all the information and have it, for example, identifiable by postcode, so that we could identify 12-year-old boys living in a particular area near high tension wires and decide whether they were more likely in adulthood or in late adolescence to develop testicular cancer? Would those boys then be able to be identified by their school records or some other means?

What about information relating to a drug taken by women in the early 1950s to maintain pregnancy which has now been found to cause cancer in the young adult offspring of those women? The public has to have a decision. Do we need this data so that we can identify the people who have taken these drugs and perhaps approach them and say, `We believe that you took this drug. Your children need to be checked because they are at risk.'? That is one side of the coin, and that is the argument for keeping this data in some way that can be repersonalised.

The other argument is whether it is appropriate for a government of any persuasion at any time to have a record of every single individual. In Estimates committees I have been told that we could identify all families with fibrocystic disease, families with phenyl ketonuria, families with thalassaemia—any family that has a genetic disorder—and that that disorder could be identified by the type of treatment. For example, a family with two or three children with fibrocystic disease could be identified by the fact that a child may have had a bowel blockage at birth, that a child may have needed treatment from a thoracic surgeon or required certain drugs. That story could be put together from the pharmaceutical data and from the Medicare data and a picture could be made of a family. That is not brave new world stuff. The Health Insurance Commission has admitted that we could identify some genetic disorders on the basis of the data the Commission now holds.

The community has to decide whether we keep that data in a form that is depersonalised but retrievable and can be identified—and these are the discussions we were having with the Privacy Commissioner. That data could be retrieved with senior approval—maybe the approval of the Minister or a committee—for the public interest and in the public good. The problem we struck was the concern about whether it is in the individual's good. What happens if we find that a particular individual has had a drug and, 20 years later, is now sensitised to some other substance? Can that person get that data back? The way the legislation is written at the moment, there is some doubt as to whether any of us as individuals or any member of the public could get that data back. Should we be able to get that information back in the public interest? Should we be able to identify people who have had a particular treatment, or is the public interest better served by it only being able to be retrieved in terms of non-personal information, that is, postcode or whatever?

My predilection as a Liberal is that people ought to be responsible for their own records. They should carry not a smartcard—far from it—but a simple piece of paper, something we used to rely on once upon a time, before technology became so highfalutin, a card that indicated the drugs they had had. In my ideal world, that is what I would want. People would then be able to say, `I have this card; I have carried it around'. It would not be a case of having a nanny state where we would be saying, `It is important because we might find in 20 years time that there is a drug that is going to affect someone'.

That is the debate the public ought to be having; it has not been having it. I notice that the person from AAP is listening to what I am saying. I hope this is reported because this is the debate we should be having. We should decide as a community whether we are prepared to keep that data in a form that is depersonalised and, with a certain authority, can be restructured or repersonalised, or whether we should expunge that data and keep it in a form in which it cannot be identified after, say, a period of five years. That is the debate we should have and have not had yet.

As I said, the Privacy Commissioner has not issued these guidelines because there are some problems, but he has called for and received submissions from interested parties, after issuing draft guidelines earlier this year. The debate has been confined mainly to epidemiologists, other medical researchers, the privacy lobby and interested parties. It is a debate that has been kept largely from the public arena. This unexpected extension of time before these Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits privacy guidelines are issued provides us as legislators with an excellent opportunity to generate public debate about an important issue that affects virtually all, if not all, Australians.

This is a debate I think we ought to have. When we have had it I will be happy, but until we have had it I will not be happy. I believe it is something the public ought to know about. They ought to debate this matter and make a decision once and for all on how they want their Medicare and pharmaceutical data stored and whether they want it to be able to be retrieved in terms of being able to identify their names in 20, 30, 40 or 50 years time. We ought to address the sort of government we may have. Despite the fact that I do not like my colleagues on the other side, I believe they would deal with that data in a proper form. I am not so sure about governments in 30, 40 or 50 years time with data which would extend much more than technology can offer us now. It is a debate we ought to have. I hope somebody is listening and that we will have a proper debate on the issue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (PUBLIC MOBILE LICENCE CHARGE) BILL 1992

This Bill imposes a charge on the grant of certain public mobile licences under the Telecommunications Act 1991. This Bill should be read with the proposed amendments to the Telecommunications Act included in the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 which, together with this Bill, will enable a fee to be charged for the grant of the third public mobile licence.

The amendments to the Telecommunications Act will insert a new section 57A which will enable the Minister to determine an allocation system for the purpose of granting public mobile licences to eligible corporations.

This Bill will impose a charge on the grant of a public mobile licence in accordance with the allocation system. A charge will not be imposed where an eligible corporation is seeking to renew its licence or in circumstances where a licence is being transferred from one eligible corporation to another.

The Government has announced that the allocation system for the granting of the third public mobile licence will be based on criteria including the bid price, industry experience and financial strength, industry development commitments and Australian equity participation.
The amendments to the Telecommunications Act referred to previously will also insert new provisions in that Act which will enable the charge imposed by this Bill to be collected and recovered.
Financial Impact

The charge imposed on the grant of the third public mobile licence by this Bill is expected to result in a significant contribution to Commonwealth revenue. It is not possible, however, to estimate the extent of the likely contribution given that the amount obtained will depend on the result of the process for granting the licence.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1992

This Bill is an Omnibus Bill amending 10 Acts administered within the Transport and Communications portfolio. While the proposed amendments do not, in general, involve significant policy changes, they are important for the general administration of the Transport and Communications portfolio. Details of the amendments are as follows.
Air Navigation Act 1920

The Bill amends the Air Navigation Act 1920 to enable ratification of two new Protocols to the Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation. These Protocols increase the membership size of both the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organisation and its Navigation Commission.
Australian Maritime Safety Authority 1990

The Bill amends the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990 to extend the Authority's functions to allow it to provide services to the Commonwealth, a State, the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory. Those services are to be services of a maritime nature and are to be provided on a commercial basis. This means that the Authority will be able to recover the costs of providing any such services. The new provision will complement the existing function of the Authority which allows it to provide services to the maritime industry.
Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989

The Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 is amended to extend the Act to the Indian Ocean Territories—Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands—as a consequence of the Government's decision to eliminate all differences between the law of the Indian Ocean Territories and that of mainland Australia. The Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 has also been amended to provide that Australia Post is to supply its standard letter service, a community service obligation under section 27 of the Act, to the Islands at the single uniform rate of postage for carriage which applies within Australia.
Civil Aviation Act 1988

Amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988 will provide that the Authority is not entitled to reimbursement by the Commonwealth where it suffers financial detriment as a result of complying with a ministerial direction concerning the performance of its environmental functions. Rather, as foreshadowed by the Government in response to the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aircraft Noise, it is intended that these costs be borne by the aviation industry.

Under section 69 of the Civil Aviation Act the Authority is empowered to recover unpaid charges by imposing liens over aircraft. The Bill amends section 75 to make it clear that the Authority's statutory liens are to have priority over any other financial security interests, including pre existing mortgagees.

The amendments insert new transitional tax provisions into the Principal Act which deal with the valuation of trading stock, accelerated depreciation of assets and capital gains tax. These provisions are consequential upon the Authority becoming liable to pay income tax from 1 July 1991 and are similar to transitional tax provisions applied to Telecom and Australia Post. These amendments have been drafted in accordance with policy advice from the Treasury and will ensure that the Civil Aviation Authority is accorded the same treatment as other Government Business Enterprises that are now required to pay income tax.

Other amendments will be made to correct typographical errors and to clarify that it is an offence for an aircraft to commence a flight unless it has a maintenance release that is valid for the duration of the flight.
Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986

The Bill amends the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 to specify that the Corporation is not entitled to Commonwealth reimbursement for financial detriment that it suffers as a result of complying with a ministerial direction concerning the performance of its environmental functions. It is intended that the aviation industry bear these costs.

The amendments also clarify the FAC's financial transactions powers. As a result of a decision by the House of Lords in 1990 there is a risk that an Australian court could find that the FAC does not have the power to enter into financial management risk transactions, such as interest rate swaps, fixed rate agreements and options and futures contracts. The amendments expressly provide that the FAC can enter into such transactions and are similar to provisions that were inserted into the Civil Aviation Act 1988 and the Australian National Railways Commission Act
1983 by the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Act 1991.

New transitional tax provisions dealing with accelerated depreciation of assets, capital gains tax and superannuation will also be inserted into the Principal Act. These provisions are consequential upon the FAC becoming liable to pay income tax from 1 July 1991 and are similar to transitional tax provisions applied to Telecom and Australia Post. These amendments have been drafted in accordance with policy advice from the Treasury and will ensure that the FAC is accorded the same treatment as other Government Business Enterprises that are now required to pay income tax.
Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Act 1981 and Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983

The Bill contains a number of amendments to Australia's Protection of the Sea package of legislation. This legislation implements several International Conventions which deal specifically with the prevention of pollution from ships. The amendments in the Bill are a consequence of amendments to these Conventions adopted recently by the relevant international organisation.

The Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Act empowers Australia to intervene on the high seas in respect of any shipping incident resulting in or likely to result in major pollution damage. The amendments to this Act will enable intervention in respect of a wider range of environmentally hazardous chemicals.

The Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act implements the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, known as MARPOL. This is the principal convention in controlling pollution from ships, currently applying to over 90 per cent of world shipping tonnage. The Bill proposes two major amendments to this Act.

The first will give effect to Australia's obligations under Annex IV of the Protocol on Environment Protection to the Antarctic Treaty relating to the disposal of untreated sewage, oil, chemicals and garbage in the Antarctic Area. This Annex was drafted with a view to imposing MARPOL-like obligations on those countries not a party to the MARPOL Convention. Consequently, for Australia there are few additional measures to be implemented. It is therefore efficient and sensible to include the proposed amendments in the MARPOL legislation, rather than legislation administered by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories which will implement the remainder of the Antarctic Protocol.

The other significant amendment is the introduction of a requirement for ships to have on board an oil pollution emergency plan, which is the result of a recent amendment to the MARPOL Convention. This is one of several changes to international pollution regulations as a result of the lessons learned from the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989. The emergency plan will consist of four basic elements: an outline of procedures for reporting incidents; a list of authorities or persons to be contacted in the event of an incident; a detailed description of the steps to be taken immediately by persons on board to reduce or control discharge of oil following an incident; and a procedure for co-ordinating response efforts with national and local authorities.

Ships visiting Australian ports will be required to have an emergency plan available for inspection by Australian Maritime Safety Authority surveyors as part of the normal port control process, and sanctions are provided for failure to comply with these requirements.
Navigation Act 1912 and Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Act l990
Amendments to the Navigation Act 1912 and to the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Act 1990 will correct minor drafting errors.
Telecommunications Act 1991

A number of amendments are made to the Telecommunications Act 1991, the most important of which are to enable a fee to be charged for the grant of the third public mobile licence, allow a dominant carrier to discriminate between customers in certain circumstances, allow particular basic carriage services and particular circumstances in which such services are provided to be excluded from the requirement under section 194 for basic carriage services to be set out in a tariff and to protect the name and symbol of the Australian Telecommunications Authority (AUSTEL).

The amendments will enable a fee to be charged for the grant of the third public mobile licence and an allocation process for the selection of the licensee to be determined by the Minister. These amendments are of a technical nature and do not affect the objects, underlying principles or general thrust of the Act. They provide a greater degree of commercial certainty about payment arrangements and the allocation process for mobile licences, at a time when parties are considering whether to make substantial investments in developing proposals for the selection of Australia's third public mobile licensee.
A charge will be imposed on the grant of a new public mobile licence by clause 4 of the Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill 1992.
A new Division 5A will be inserted in Part 5 of the Telecommunications Act to enable the collection and recovery of the public mobile licence charge.

Section 183 of the Telecommunications Act 1991 is amended to allow certain exceptions to the rule that prevents a dominant carrier from discriminating between customers. The purpose of the amendment is to allow the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (AOTC) to proceed with its proposal to offer concessions to low income and other disadvantaged customers. AOTC has already publicly announced a package of proposals which it proposes to implement on 1 July 1992. The amendment will ensure that AOTC's proposal can proceed.

Section 194 of the Telecommunications Act 1991 is amended to enable regulations to be made allowing for the supply of certain basic carriage services or the supply of such services in certain circumstances without the services being included in a tariff, as presently required under section 194. The amendment will enable international transit arrangements to be excluded from the tariffing requirement. The details of such arrangements are considered to be confidential between the carriers involved.

A new section, section 402A, is inserted into the Telecommunications Act 1991 to protect the name and symbol of AUSTEL. New section 402A provides for a penalty of $3,000 for anyone contravening the protection provision.
Financial Impact
There will be no significant effects on the Commonwealth expenditure or revenue resulting from most of the amendments.
The amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988 and the Federal Airports Corporation 1986 dealing with transitional tax provisions will clarify the taxation liability of those organisations.

The amendments to enable a fee to be charged for the grant of the third public mobile licence, together with the proposed Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill 1992, are expected to result in a significant contribution to Commonwealth revenue. It is not possible to estimate the extent of the likely contribution given that the amount obtained will depend on the result of the process for granting the licence.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: ACT SUPREME COURT (TRANSFER) BILL 1992

This Bill will enhance the protection of the independence of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court, which is to be transferred to the Australian Capital Territory on 1 July 1992. At present, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 merely provides that from 1 July 1992 the ACT Legislative Assembly has legislative power in relation to the establishment and administration of courts. Without something more, none of the traditional safeguards of an independent judiciary are entrenched in Territory law.

In the Australian Capital Territory, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act takes the place of a constitution. It is therefore appropriate that the Self-Government Act should contain provisions entrenching the position of an independent judiciary, in a similar manner as does Chapter III of the Constitution in relation to the federal judiciary.

On 8 April 1992 the ACT Legislative Assembly formally requested that the Commonwealth Parliament amend the Australian Capital Territory (SelfGovernment) Act, so as to provide a new Part of the Act dealing with the Judiciary. Specifically, the following provisions were requested by the ACT Legislative Assembly—

a provision for the existence of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory, which is to have all the original and appellate jurisdiction that is necessary to administer justice in the Territory;

provisions for the removal from office of a Judge, a Magistrate or another judicial officer, only after a request to the ACT Executive by the ACT Legislative Assembly made in accordance with a report of a judicial commission, which has found that the behaviour or capacity of a person could amount to misbehaviour warranting that person's removal from office;
provisions for the determination of judicial remuneration, which guarantee the non-diminution of that remuneration; and
provisions to protect the position of the Judges who will continue as Judges of the Court after 1 July 1992.

Under the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, the ACT Legislative Assembly is excluded from making laws in relation to the establishment of courts, subject to provisions of the Act providing for the transfer of legislative power. The ACT Magistrates Court was transferred to the ACT Government on 1 July 1990, when the ACT was given legislative power in relation to the establishment of magistrates' courts and coroners' courts. The Supreme Court will, under the existing provisions of the Act, be transferred on 1 July 1992 when the ACT obtains legislative power in relation to all courts; completing the process of transfer of ACT Courts to the Australian Capital Territory.

The Bill largely implements the recommendations of a working party comprising representatives of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Tourism, the ACT Government Law Office and the ACT Supreme Court. The ACT Law Society and the ACT Bar Association were also consulted.

The Bill provides for the amendment of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988, both Commonwealth Acts, and the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933, a Commonwealth Act which will become a Territory enactment on 1 July 1992. There are also some minor, consequential amendments of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, the Judges (Long Leave Payments) Act 1979 and the Judges' Pensions Act 1968.
The amendments of the Self-Government Act include provisions for the:
jurisdiction and powers of the Supreme Court;
establishment of a judicial commission to investigate allegations or complaints about the conduct or physical or mental capacity of a judicial officer;
removal of a judicial officer from office; and,
remuneration and allowances of judicial officers.
The amendments of the ACT Supreme Court Act include provisions:
concerning the seniority of the Judges of the Court;
for the exercise by the Supreme Court of jurisdiction under subsections 46(4) and 48(2) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1989 of the Territory;
for approval for the holding of other judicial offices by Judges of the Supreme Court;
in respect of the jurisdiction and powers of the Court;
for an oath or affirmation of office to be taken by the Registrar of the Court; and
in respect of the appointment of officers to assist the Sheriff.

The principal provisions of this Bill are those that entrench in Commonwealth legislation the traditional protections of judicial independence. Because the provisions are to be in Commonwealth legislation, the ACT judiciary will not be subject to the possibility of an attack on the independence of the ACT judicial system from the ACT Executive or Legislature.

Appointment of judges in Australia is traditionally a matter for the Executive. While the ACT Supreme Court has been a Court created by the Commonwealth, Judges have been appointed by the Governor-General in Council. The Bill provides for all future Judges and other officers of the Supreme Court to be appointed by the ACT Executive.

The amendments of the Self-Government Act provide for the removal of a Judge or other judicial officer or a member of a tribunal by the ACT Executive following a resolution of the ACT Legislative Assembly acting in accordance with a report of a Judicial Commission, in which the Commission has concluded that the behaviour or physical or mental capacity of the judicial officer or member of the tribunal concerned could amount to proved misbehaviour or incapacity such as to warrant removal from office. This standard for the operation of a judicial commission is the standard recommended by the Advisory Committee of the Constitutional Commission in its 1988 Report (paragraph 5.55).
A judicial officer may only be removed from office by the Executive in writing.

The Judicial Commission will be constituted by judges who have been, but are no longer, Justices of the High Court, or who are or have been Judges of a superior court of record of a State or Territory (other than sitting resident Judges of the ACT Supreme Court) and will be appointed by the ACT Government. The Commission may be a Standing Commission or established ad hoc.

The retiring ages of the present Judges and the Master are protected by the provisions of this Bill. After 1 July 1992, the ACT Legislative Assembly will have power to make a law that establishes a retiring age for Judges or the Master that is different from that which now applies. New section 48B provides that such a law is to have no effect in relation to a Judge or the Master who was appointed before the commencement of the Act, unless the Judge or the Master consents, in writing, to the different law applying to him or her. It will therefore be possible for the ACT Legislative Assembly to increase or decrease the retiring age of members of the ACT Judiciary, but the retiring age of the current members of the Supreme Court can only be changed with their consent.

As a further safeguard to judicial independence, the amended Self-Government Act and the amended ACT Supreme Court Act will provide that the remuneration and allowances of a judicial officer cannot be diminished while the officer holds office, and the amended Self-Government Act provides that the remuneration and allowances of the Chief Justice, the Judges, the Master, the Chief Magistrate and a Magistrate of the Australian Capital Territory are to be determined by the Commonwealth Remuneration Tribunal.

The current Chief Justice and Judges of the Court, except the additional Judges, will continue to hold office on terms no less favourable than those of Judges of the Federal Court of Australia. The additional Judges are, of course, all Judges of the Federal Court of Australia.

Some provisions of the Bill have been included to ensure that there is no doubt as to the fact that the ACT Supreme Court will continue to operate as the same entity after 1 July 1992. The translation of the Supreme Court Act 1933 from an Act of the Commonwealth Parliament to an ACT enactment in no way creates a break in the existence of the ACT Supreme Court.

Amendments of the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988 will ensure the continuity of office of the Judges and the Master of the Court. New section 29A, of the Consequential Provisions Act provides that the Chief Justice, the other Judges (including the additional Judges) and the Master as at 1 July 1992, continue to hold their office after 1 July 1992 notwithstanding the fact that from 1 July 1992 the ACT Supreme Court Act is an ACT enactment.

New section 29B provides that all proceedings pending in the Supreme Court on or before 1 July 1992, and any judgment or order entered or made before 1 July 1992, are to be continued on and after that date as if they were proceedings instituted in the Court referred to in the ACT enactment.

The Bill is expected to have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. The running costs of the Supreme Court were agreed with the ACT Government in 1988 and that amount will be included in the General Revenue Grant of the ACT from 1 July 1992.
I table the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

This Bill contains a number of important policy initiatives aimed at increasing the control which the Government may exercise over Australia's migration program. In particular the Bill contains significant measures to strengthen Australia's ability to cope with the increasing number of people claiming refugee status. Provisions have also been included to deter persons, primarily Indonesian nationals, from fishing illegally in Australian waters. The Bill also contains new powers to facilitate the successful operation of the Government's initiative to attract successful business migrants to Australia. Finally, the Bill will make a number of minor technical amendments to the Act.
Refugee Initiatives

Over the past three years the number of applications for refugee status from persons wishing to remain in Australia has grown dramatically from below 500 applications per year to a current caseload of 22,500.

Many of these applicants have been able to continue to delay their departure from Australia by deferring the lodgement of an actual application for refugee status. This is a cynical abuse of the refugee determination process which will not be tolerated by the Government.

Under the present policy based arrangements there are uncertainties about our ability to require applicants to cooperate in pursuing their claims in an expeditious manner. The Government has therefore decided to introduce a regulatory framework to underpin Australia's asylum determination procedures.

The Government announced on 12 February 1992 that new arrangements would be introduced to improve the efficiency of Australia's system for processing claims for refugee status. The amendments set out in this Bill will facilitate refugee processing within a regulatory framework that provides certainty and accountability. The Bill will provide the Minister of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs with a clear basis of power in the Act to make regulations for the orderly processing of refugee applications.

The new measures developed to improve the refugee determination process will result in a more efficient and equitable system. Incorporating processing arrangements in regulations will produce a more predictable processing environment. All applicants have an equal opportunity to pursue their claims.

The amendments in the Bill also relieve the Minister of the obligation to consider refugee applications by persons who hold the special four-year temporary entry permit granted to nationals of the People's Republic of China who were in Australia on 20 June 1989.

The rationale for this provision is that these people have already been given protection which satisfies Australia's international obligations. Removing the duty to consider their applications will ensure processing resources are more productively employed for persons who do not have effective protection.

The amendments will also allow the Minister to determine processing priorities so that processing of new applications for refugee status is not impeded by the existence of a backlog of unprocessed applications. Applications will no longer be processed in chronological order of receipt. Rather, applications in the backlog will be processed in tandem with new applications. The Government wishes to eliminate any incentive for persons with no claim to refugee status to lodge ill-founded applications simply to achieve continued residence in Australia while awaiting processing of their application. The amendment will also provide that applications in the backlog shall not be found to be subject to an unreasonable delay merely because other applications received more recently are being processed or have already been determined.
Illegal Fishermen

For some time now, the Government has been concerned about the problem of the incursion of foreign fishing vessels into Australian waters. The vessels are largely Indonesian in origin. The problem is serious, with consequences for the fishing industry, our marine environment and quarantine arrangements.

Existing laws have not had the desired deterrent effect. There have been claims that the fishermen apprehended, in serving their gaol sentences, have a `paid holiday' at the Australian taxpayers' expense. The small gratuities granted by State Corrective Services to all prisoners for their work may represent a significant amount to an Indonesian fisherman.

The scheme outlined in this Bill is the result of discussion between the relevant State and Federal agencies. It is the first step in a much wider strategy and indicates our determination to deal with this problem effectively. The scheme will render any crew member of a fishing vessel apprehended liable for the cost of his custody and removal from Australia. The master, owner, agent or charterer of the relevant vessel will also be liable for that cost. The Secretary of the Department will be able to serve a Notice on State and Territory gaols, banks or other financial institutions that may hold funds in trust for these prisoners. The notice will require them to pay the funds to the Department up to the amount of a person's liability.
The scheme, together with the present capacity to confiscate fishing boats and to impose gaol sentences, increases the disincentives for these fishermen to fish illegally in Australian waters.
Business Migration
I turn now to the amendments which relate to business migrants who arrive in Australia.

The Bill provides a legal framework to implement two aspects of the Government's new Business Skills migration category which was announced on 17 December 1991. The first is a system of mandatory participation by Business Skills migrants in the monitoring of their business activities after their arrival in Australia. The second is the creation of a power for the Minister to cancel permanent entry permits and entry visas of Business Skills migrants after their arrival in Australia if they do not enter into business activities which meet the objectives of the category or make a genuine effort to do so. These provisions will apply to such migrants within their first three years after arrival in Australia. The Minister cannot cancel entry permits or visas unless action is initiated within the three year period.

The provisions of the Bill relating to mandatory participation in monitoring, introduce a requirement for Business Skills migrants to provide business related information and notification of changes of address, after their arrival in Australia. There are financial penalties for non-compliance with these requirements which are considered and fair. Payment of fines will not release migrants from the requirement to furnish information.

I am confident that the information gathered will serve to confirm the value of this form of migration. It should minimise much of the criticism of business migration which has been prevalent, but largely unfounded, in recent years.

Also, aggregated data from the monitoring will be available to help those involved in planning services to assist migrants in business. The individual information on migrants will of course be protected by the provisions of the Privacy Act 1988.

The second part of these changes deal with the power to cancel entry permits and visas. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommended that the new arrangements for business migration should not use a system of conditional visas. The Government accepted that recommendation. Nevertheless, it is appropriate for the Minister to have the power to deal with cases of serious abuse. This concept is incorporated in these provisions.

Each business migrant acknowledges at the time of application that he or she understands the business objectives of the category and the expectation that they will make genuine efforts to comply with them. Additionally, each business migrant acknowledges that they and their family members' entry permits may be cancelled if they do not meet the objectives of the program or make genuine efforts to do so.

The Bill gives the Minister clear legislative indicators on which a decision is to be based if cancellation is being considered. The overwhelming majority of business migrants are not likely to be affected by the use of this power. Only those whose intentions are inconsistent with the objectives of the category need have any concern about its use. It is not anticipated that the power will be exercised on more than a few occasions.

The Bill includes provisions which mean that the power cannot be used against a business migrant unless the Minister has notified him or her of the intention to do so within three years of the migrant's arrival in Australia. This provision allows business migrants time to make sensible business decisions. It also allows sufficient time for an assessment to be made that the business is likely to be of ongoing benefit. It also recognises that, as permanent residents, business migrants should not be under the threat of cancellation indefinitely. There is a requirement for the Minister to consider any submission by or on behalf of the business migrant. The Bill provides for determinative review by the AAT.

These amendments relating to business migrants will help to ensure the successful operation of the Business Skills category of the migration program. The Bill will also maximise economic outcomes arising from it and provide the Government with a stronger information base from which to make decisions in future. This is achieved without placing unnecessarily onerous conditions on business skills migrants. Business migrants have proven skills of value to Australia. Their entry has the continuing support of government at all levels as well as of the business community.
Finally, I will deal with some of the other, more minor, amendments to the Act.
Section 20(1)(d)(iii)

The purpose of the Migration Act is to enable the Commonwealth to exercise its power to control certain persons or categories of persons who may lawfully enter and stay in this country. It has always been the intention of this government, and previous governments before it, that this power should be exercised with the public interest in mind.

One means of ensuring that the public interest is observed is to define those categories of persons whom it is undesirable to have stay in Australia. Such categories include persons who make false or misleading statements or produce bogus documents, or those with highly dangerous and communicable diseases, and those persons with criminal records. Section 20 in the Migration Act defines these categories. That section requires persons falling within these categories to be recognised as illegal entrants unless the Secretary or his delegate excuses them.

The amendment proposed to this section is in response to a Federal Court decision which has limited the power of the Commonwealth to decide who may enter and stay in Australia with regard to persons with criminal records. The intention of the Government has always been that a person who has committed a series of unrelated crimes which have resulted in that person being sentenced, in total, to a period of twelve months or more imprisonment, should be categorised as a person to whom section 20 applies.

The Court decision, however, requires that this provision be interpreted very narrowly. It would apply only to a person in circumstances where there is a court order that several sentences of imprisonment are to be served consecutively so as to make up one continuous period of detention of at least one year.
The amendment proposed to Section 20 will make this long-standing policy of the Government clear in the legislation and overcome the narrow interpretation of the Court.

The amendment will not operate retrospectively to apply to persons who have, pursuant to the decision of the Federal Court, been lawfully resident in Australia and whose circumstances meet those described in the amendment to section 20(1)(d)(iii). In respect of these persons who may be outside Australia at the time of commencement of the amendment, they will not be caught by the amendment. In effect, the amendment will not apply to such persons in respect of any convictions which may have occurred before the commencement of the amendment.
Amendments to Provisions Affecting Illegal Entrant Status

The Bill will make a minor technical amendment to section 14 of the Act to remove unnecessary retrospectivity from the provision. If a person produces bogus documentation or makes misleading statements in respect of the grant of a further entry permit after entry to Australia they will become illegal entrants. That status is effective from the date of grant of that entry permit rather than from the date of entry to Australia as presently provided for in the Act. At present, a person to whom section 20 of the Act applies (eg a person with a criminal record) becomes an illegal entrant upon entering Australia unless a properly endorsed valid entry permit is granted. That requirement is inappropriate in some cases.

For example, when official guests of the Government visit Australia. Section 15 of the Act has been amended to allow the regulations to exempt persons or classes of persons from the consequences of section 20.
Review

The Bill makes some minor amendments to the provisions relating to statutory merits review. The most important of these will permit a review authority to remit a case to the primary decision-maker to be reconsidered in accordance with the review authority's directions. This amendment, which is supported by the Immigration Review Tribunal, should lead to speedier review decisions in many cases by eliminating unnecessary steps in the process where the review application is successful.

The Migration Act has provisions under section 115 and section 137 which permit the Minister to set aside a decision of an internal review officer and the Immigration Review Tribunal respectively, and substitute a more favourable decision. The Minister is required to table a statement in Parliament in each such case. Different tabling requirements were imposed under the two provisions because they were enacted at different times. The Bill seeks to amend section 137 to make the tabling requirements in that section identical with those in section 115.

The other amendments remove a possible ambiguity relating to the time limits for making review applications. These amendments will ensure that visa applicants have adequate opportunity to seek review of unfavourable decisions.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill and I commend the Bill to the Senate.
