SPEECH.PARA: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This is the main Bill in a package of six Bills that will, as part of the simplification of the sales tax law, replace the existing sales tax legislation. It represents a major overhaul by the Government of the existing sales tax law.

SPEECH.PARA: Overall, the package of Bills will replace the 27 Acts which currently deal exclusively with sales tax. The Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 will replace the 11 Assessment Acts, and the Sales Tax Procedure Act, that are necessary to administer the law under its current structure.
The main features of the measures are:
.a significant reduction in the number of persons required to pay sales tax;
.a complete restructuring and redrafting of the WST legislation, in plain English, to make it simpler to use and more certain in its application;
.a streamlining of the system for acquiring business inputs and other conditionally exempt goods free of tax; and
.a significant strengthening of the anti-avoidance provisions of the law.
These changes will complement legislation introduced late last year to expand the range of business inputs which are exempted from tax.
The simplification of the sales tax law will bring substantial benefits both for taxpayers and the Australian Taxation Office which is responsible for administering the tax.
I now turn to the more important changes.
SMALL BUSINESS CONCESSION

The exemption for small business has been considerably widened so that it will offer to the majority of taxpayers the option of not paying tax. Exemption will now be available to all persons liable to pay sales tax if their liability does not exceed $10,000 per annum. This is a considerable advance on the present concession, which is mainly limited to manufacturers and has a generally lower threshold. While the concession will be optional—some small businesses may wish not to take up the concession so that they may continue to acquire their business inputs free from tax—it is expected that a significant number of small businesses will avail themselves of the concession. This will result in savings to those businesses who will no longer be required to lodge returns and make small tax payments to the Australian Taxation Office. It will also reduce the costs of collecting the tax.
REGISTRATION AND QUOTATION

Under the existing law it is compulsory for persons liable to pay tax to be registered and quote their certificates of registration. This compulsion will be removed by this Bill. Registration of taxpayers will be optional, as will quotation by those who elect to be registered. This will remove the need for penalties for non-registration or for failure to quote a certificate. It will also relieve taxpayers from the threat of penalty in situations where they are not certain whether they should register or quote a certificate. However, because of the general advantages of registration it is expected that most taxpayers who are currently registered for sales tax will remain registered. Moreover, certain exemptions from tax in the area of business inputs will be restricted on purchase to registered persons.
CONDITIONAL EXEMPTION SYSTEM

The Bill will provide a much simpler set of rules for persons who are currently entitled to exemption from sales tax and will continue to be under the new law. Such persons will, in some cases, be able to be registered and simply quote a sales tax registration number to obtain goods tax-free. In other cases they will quote in a similar fashion to the existing conditional exemption system except that there will be authority for it in the law. This will make quotation for persons entitled to exemption more certain.

The new system will, however, impose a liability on any person who provides an incorrect certificate. This is considered appropriate bearing in mind that the person providing the certificate should be aware of the purpose of use of the goods and whether or not exemption applies. The new system will also benefit vendor taxpayers who will no longer have a liability if they accept an incorrect certificate in good faith.
AVOIDANCE OF TAX

Consistent with the Government's policy to stamp out tax avoidance, the Bill will contain a general anti-avoidance provision to catch schemes designed to avoid the payment of sales tax. The general provision will replace a number of provisions that are directed to particular schemes but which do not cover the field of tax avoidance.
GENERAL LIABILITY TO TAX

The basic aim of the sales tax law is to impose a tax on all goods going into use in Australia for the first time unless they are specifically exempted. There are some gaps in the present law in reaching this aim and the law is to be tightened in certain areas to ensure that all goods that should bear tax do so. This will be achieved by strengthening the provisions relating to royalties and catching certain manufacturing costs that presently fall outside the tax base.
Additionally, a liability will be imposed on the sale or use of goods that ordinarily would be subject to tax but somehow have managed to by-pass a taxing point without payment of tax.
COMMISSIONER'S DISCRETIONS

In revising the existing law, a significant number of Commissioner's discretions have been removed with the object of making the law more self-assessing. Commissioner's discretions have been retained only where it is essential for sound administration or to avoid the need for unduly complex law.
GENERAL

There are a number of other changes to the law which will make it easier to follow. The rules relating to leases have been considerably simplified to bring them into line with sales of goods. A number of complex deeming provisions relating to the making-up of goods from materials supplied by a customer have been removed and replaced with a simpler system. There will be new rules for selling goods tax-free to Australian residents intending to travel overseas which will clarify this situation.
SUMMARY

While the new law is a considerable simplification of the existing law there are still some areas which will remain reasonably complex. This is unavoidable with a wholesale tax that is imposed only on goods. However, it is the Government's position that in the field of indirect taxation it favours the present wholesale tax because it enables essential goods such as food and clothing to be exempted from the tax and it leaves important service industries which are vital to the growth of the economy, such as the tourist industry, largely free from tax. It is also much easier to collect, having far fewer collection points than a retail or general consumption tax.
This Bill not only simplifies a relatively complex taxation law but it represents a considerable advance in writing law in a plain English style that can be easily understood by the general public.
Mr President, the new law will not commence to impose tax until 3 months after it has received the Royal Assent. During this time the existing law will continue to apply.

The delayed introduction will allow the Commissioner of Taxation sufficient time to publicise the changes to the existing law and to set in place the new arrangements that will be necessary for its administration.

Additionally, members of the Simplification Review will be making themselves available during this period to meet with key bodies and taxpayers' representatives to discuss the new law and to identify any concerns with it. The Government is aware that, in a project that has seen the complete restructuring and re-writing of the sales tax law, it is likely that some errors and unintended omissions or changes are unavoidable. These will only emerge after detailed analysis of the new law over an extended period.

Finally, Mr. President, I would particularly draw Honourable Senators attention to the Explanatory Memorandum accompanying these Bills. While all of the changes made by the Bill are explained in detail in that document, the aim of the Simplification Review has not merely been to improve the sales tax law but also to improve the traditional explanatory materials brought forward to explain it. One example of this is the Explanatory Memorandums for these Bills. They have been specially designed, after discussions with representatives of their users, to meet concerns expressed about the structure and short-comings of earlier explanatory memorandums. In particular, the memorandums seek to provide, in a form easily accessed by all users, a detailed explanation of all the changes proposed to the existing law as well as the reasons for those changes. Recent advances in computer technology now enable far more professionally presented and better structured material to be brought forward. Maximum use has been made of this technology by the Review team. I also note that there is a separate Explanatory Memorandum which sets out quite comprehensive tables which identify where provisions of the existing law are dealt with in the new law, and vice versa.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX IMPOSITION BILLS 1992

PARA.TAB: These Bills are part of the package of six Bills that make up the new simplified sales tax law.

SPEECH.PARA: These three Imposition Bills will have the effect of imposing tax on the assessable dealings that are liable to tax under the Sales Tax Assessment Bill. Three Imposition Bills are necessary because of the requirement of the Constitution that a law imposing taxation shall deal only with one subject of taxation and that laws imposing customs duty and laws imposing excise duties deal only with those duties.

The first Imposition Bill will impose tax on relevant dealings to the extent it is a duty of customs; the second Imposition Bill will impose tax on relevant dealings to the extent that it is a duty of excise and the third Imposition Bill will impose tax on relevant dealings to the extent that the tax is neither a duty of customs nor a duty of excise.
I commend these Bills to the Senate.
SALES TAX AMENDMENT (TRANSITIONAL) BILL 1992

This Bill is part of a package of six Bills that make up the new simplified sales tax law. Its purpose is to provide for the necessary transitional arrangements that are essential to ensure a smooth change over from the existing law to the new law.

More specifically, the Bill will terminate the old law from the day before the first taxing day under the new law. It will provide that in certain situations goods taxed under the existing law will not be taxed under the new law. Where goods can be taxed under both the existing and new law a credit will be available for tax paid under the existing law.

The Bill will also deal with the position of goods acquired tax-free under quote under the existing law but which are not dealt with in a taxable manner until after the first taxing day of the new law.

To reduce the burden on taxpayers who are presently registered for sales tax from applying for fresh registration under the new law, there will be provision for existing registrations to continue. Registered persons will not have to re-apply for registration.

A further transitional provision will preserve the operation of the current small business exemptions to ensure that no small business is disadvantaged by the change over to the new law. The Bill also covers other minor transitional arrangements.

Finally, in the event that there are some matters not adequately covered by the transitional provisions, there is power for regulations to be made to deal with them. The Government is taking every step to ensure that in the general operation of the sales tax law, no taxpayer will be disadvantaged as a result of the change over.
The operation of the Bill is explained in more detail in the Explanatory Memorandum circulated with the package of Bills.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) BILL 1992
This is the second major Bill in a package of six Bills which make up the new simplified sales tax law. This Bill needs to be read together with the other Bills to which it is linked.

The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill will identify those goods which will be exempt from sales tax, either absolutely or in certain circumstances. It will also classify the remaining goods for the purpose of determining the rate of sales tax to be paid on them.

The Bill will contain guidelines clarifying the circumstances in which exemption may be claimed to make it easier for persons to decide if they are entitled to claim exemption. The Bill will require persons claiming exemption to intend to use the goods in circumstances for a minimum period.

The Bill will also require goods generally to be used for more than 50 per cent in exempt circumstances in order for exemption to apply. Other goods will be exempt if they are for use exclusively in a stipulated way. Some goods will be exempt if they are for use to a sufficient extent in a specified way.
There will be a further requirement that, apart from leases, the person who claims the benefit of an exemption will be the person who will have to actually use the goods in the exempt way.

Another change which will make the application of the sales tax laws more certain is the use of standard terminology. In the existing law, different terms with similar or overlapping meanings are used to describe similar concepts. In the new law, in keeping with the policy of plain English drafting, key concepts which recur in descriptions of goods will be expressed in uniform or standard terminology each time those particular concepts are referred to.

Although the scope of existing exemptions and classifications will be preserved as nearly as possible, the adoption of standard terminology will result in some small change to some items. These changes are explained in detail in the Explanatory Memorandum circulated with this Bill.
In the course of reviewing the existing law some obsolete items have been identified and these have been omitted.
The new law will make a number of changes to the classification of goods as a result of the simplification review. Some goods which are taxable will now become exempt. These are:
.natural mineral water
.pallets for transporting or storing goods
.gases
.works of art
Some goods which are presently exempt will become taxable. These include:
.plastic and rubber sheeting
.switch lampholders
.some sensors and thermostats
.pet food for dog and cat breeders
In addition, exemptions have been drafted in simpler language. The structure of the exemption Schedules has been altered so that similar kinds of goods will be grouped together and easier to find.

Finally, there will be some adjustments to the scope of the exemptions for goods for use in business or industry. One of the main changes will be in the presentation of the exemptions. There will now be separate references to each industry or activity covered by the business inputs provisions although the structure of the exemption for each industry will be similar. This will overcome many of the inconsistencies in the existing treatment of different industries. Much of the complexity and duplication within the existing exemptions for `eligible business goods' and `aids to manufacture' will be removed.

The last point which should be noted is that some exemptions for business inputs will only be available for registered persons. This will be done to encourage regular users of these exemptions to register and quote a number which is a simpler system than quoting an exemption declaration.

An Explanatory Memorandum containing detailed information on this Bill is being made available to Honourable Senators and further details on the changes made by the Bill will be found in that document.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

If we look at the latest year, we see that funding for one program has gone down from $5.4m to $5.1m. Funding for another program has gone down from $32.9m to $28.1m, and so on. So there has been a series of significant falls in allocations to various art forms while over the last four years there has been this significant increase in funding of the Australia Council's own programs.

What concerned me was that a lot of these programs seemed to have a fairly peripheral involvement with the arts. There may be some merit in having some talkathons and all sorts of other gatherings which no doubt excite people. Perhaps I am being unreasonable in saying that gatherings of intellectuals may be very useful and perhaps I am cross because I am obviously not classified as an intellectual and so I did not go. Remarkably, I got an invitation which, I regret to say, I did not see. These gatherings, these talkfests, may be useful, but I am certain that if the arts organisations were asked whether they would prefer the Australia Council to actually give them the money so that they could run their arts programs or have talkathons run by the Australia Council, the universal view would be, `For heaven's sake, let the Australia Council cut down its own programs and let more arts money actually go to the arts'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Baume for providing entertainment to the good citizens of the nation glued to their radios at the moment, as I know they are. I cannot allow his comments about Fightback and the arts to go uncommented upon, although I certainly do not intend to provoke a debate about it; I know that you, Mr Chairman, would not let me anyway. The arts groups are understandably concerned about the impact of the GST upon their performance, their operations, in a variety of ways; but that is a matter for debate on another day. I feel it is appropriate to put that on the record. I cannot provide Senator Baume with the detail about the 1986-87 and 1987-88 changes. No-one here has access to records of that vintage, but I will certainly get someone to do an analysis and provide some information to Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: Although any individual program by the Council—whether for the Council's own purposes or for a grant—is open to review and scrutiny, because it is an expenditure of taxpayers' funds, it is a bit unkind to the Council programs to generalise about them in the way Senator Baume has done. Many of them are widely regarded as providing very worthwhile assistance to artists and the arts. Nevertheless, so as not to waste the time of the Committee, I accept that there is legitimate interest in the variation to which Senator Baume refers. I will get the information for him as soon as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that and say in passing that I too will not enter into a debate on the matter. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) was the first person to mention the GST and its impact on the arts, I should tell him, if he wants some concerns in the arts about tax and its impact on the arts, that maybe he should discuss with arts people the consequence of the proposed changes in the sales tax situation. I am surprised that the Parliamentary Secretary would not have noted that sales tax has an enormous and severe impact on the arts, particularly if the recent judgment in relation to the making of stage props is set aside. I remind the Parliamentary Secretary that overall the GST and the Fightback package bring significant benefits to the arts. I will leave it at that. It is fairly self-evident why it brings those benefits, but if the Minister is keen for a debate at some time I hope he will facilitate one.
—If there is nothing further on program 1.3, we will move to subprogram 1.7, National Film and Sound Archive.

—I will be very speedy about this. The response I received to the questions I put on notice concerning the time that the Mitchell repository has been empty is a matter of some concern. As I understand it, the National Film and Sound Archive did not occupy the building until late last year, even though it became available back in 1985. It was occupied by the Department of Aviation until February 1988. Apparently the total amount of rent paid over that period for a building which was not used was something like half a million dollars.

PARA.TAB: I asked what had gone wrong. As I understand it, the reply says that there were union concerns about occupational health and safety issues which took until December 1991 to resolve and the building was then occupied. I must say it is extraordinary that there can be delays of years in this sort of thing. The response by the Archive was that after the end of the occupation of the building in February 1988 the complex fit-out and shelving work took until May 1989 to complete. The problems included dispute and litigation between the fit-out contractor and the shelving contractor, damage to shelving on installation, difficulties in achieving the strict humidity controls and temperature requirements, and the need for rectification of insulation panels. In addition, there was repairing damage, disputes about occupational health and safety, and so on. There has been an extraordinary waste of half a million dollars in rent for a place that was not occupied.

I asked how much it would have cost to build a special purpose repository with the same sort of capacity, recognising that something like $3.16m had to be spent in fitting out this building. I was told that the cost of construction of the shell for an equivalent repository in 1985 would have been between $1.1m and $1.3m. It would have cost only $1.1m to buy a repository on which we have spent $3.2m and which the Archive has been unable to occupy for all that time. We have wasted half a million dollars on dead rent. I simply want to put on the record that this is not really a very effective way to manage one's properties, and I hope this kind of problem will be better dealt with in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last thing I would try to do is to mount a defence of the indefensible. All I can say is that the honourable senator's last comment is apt. The management of such things in the future will need to be—and I am assured will be—improved. Senator Baume is quite correct.
—If there is nothing further on subprogram 1.7, we will move to subprogram 1.8, Cultural Heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories several questions on notice relating to the $20m provided for in the One Nation statement for restoration of heritage buildings. I did that against the background of the unfair and inequitable distribution of this money as between the States. The situation is quite disconcerting. I pointed out the discriminatory nature of the formula proposed. The formula for the disbursement of those funds was on a per capita basis for the States and Territories, which is quite inequitable. For example, Queensland has only 510 heritage buildings—less than half of Tasmania's 1,101—yet under the proposed formula for the disbursement of the $20m, Queensland will receive approximately $3.4m compared with Tasmania, which will receive $520,000, or almost six times the funding for less than half the number of buildings.

PARA.TAB: As a representative from Tasmania, I am concerned about this. I appeal to the Committee and to the Minister to agree with me that that is inequitable. Quite clearly, the Department thinks it is inequitable, because I asked the Department a number of questions and its answers can be seen at page 145 of Additional Information received by Estimates Committee D. In answer to my question `What will be the method of disbursement of the funds?', the Department's reply states:

SPEECH.PARA: The funds will be disbursed on a per capita basis to the States and Territories.
I asked:

Is the Department aware that Tasmania has 1101 buildings on the Register of the National Estate—which represents 14% of the Australia-wide total; yet has only 2 and 1/2 per cent of the Australian population?
The Department replied:

The Department is aware that Tasmania has 1101 historic places on the Register of the National Estate; the term `places' includes buildings and sites such as parks and gardens, mines and mineral processing works, cemeteries and graves.
I asked the further question:
Does the Department acknowledge that a funds distribution formula based on population and not buildings will severely disadvantage Tasmania but not the larger States of NSW and Victoria?
The Department answered:
No comment.
There was no justification at all for what clearly was a ministerial decision. I asked the Department:
Was this method of allocation recommended by the Heritage Commission or the Department?

The answer to that was `No'. Clearly, the Heritage Commission did not recommend to the Minister the disbursement of the additional funds on a per capita basis, which is the cause of the most unfair situation that has emerged.

PARA.TAB: I want the Parliamentary Secretary to give the Committee a bit of explanation, if he can, to justify the Minister's allocation of this money on a per capita basis. Does the Minister not think it ludicrous that a situation can arise where Tasmania, with twice the number of heritage places compared with, for example, Queensland, is receiving $531,000 as compared with Queensland's $3.4m? To put it another way, Queensland is receiving six times the funding for less than half the number of places. Can the Parliamentary Secretary justify this? If so, how?

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, the first point to make is that I would not have thought this level of policy detail by the Government is a matter normally pursued in Estimates. This is a matter of Government policy decision which has been made. If somebody wants to pursue why the Government made a policy decision, that is the purpose of things such as Question Time.

PARA.TAB: One Nation seeks to develop a series of socially worthwhile expenditures that will provide significant economic stimulus and jobs, and conduct particular socially worthwhile programs. One of those socially worthwhile programs is the $20m for heritage properties. This allocation was influenced by a number of factors, including, of course, the concern about the employment implications of how the money would be spent. The Government made a policy decision that it would do this on a per capita basis. Every State is advantaged by the decision of the Government to provide this extra $20m. Tasmania has not lost anything; it has gained half a million dollars that it would not otherwise have had.

I want to make it clear that, of course, every State would have liked more money for every program. For example, in relation to this program, they all have many more heritage buildings than this money will enable to be restored. It is not as if the money in Queensland will lay idle waiting for some useful purpose to which it might be applied. All the States could undoubtedly have spent more money than they received on heritage properties.

A number of factors were considered in the equation, not the least of which was the economic impact of the expenditure. For that reason, the per capita formula was considered on balance by the Cabinet, which made the decision, to be the appropriate formula. There is really nothing for me to add. The criteria were determined by Cabinet, and they have been applied. It is a matter of judgment as to whether it was the appropriate criteria. Senator Harradine has made his judgment clear, as has the Government. The appropriations are merely an accurate reflection of the decision made by the Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I have acknowledged publicly that I welcome the additional amount of $20m. Our heritage is certainly precious, but it is crumbling. I can think of a number of places in Tasmania—Entally House for one—which need vast sums of money to be restored.

PARA.TAB: I agree, and I have indicated publicly, that one area of employment that would be very useful for young people to be engaged in is assisting in the restoration of their heritage, including graveyard sites and so on. We can see around the countryside old grave sites that do need upkeep and repair. That is something that I know young people can get very interested in. It is a very worthwhile task for them.

If the Committee of the Whole cannot examine a question of additional estimates, what can it examine? This is $20m of additional estimates; obviously that is what we are about. Secondly, I heard what the Parliamentary Secretary said. He valiantly maintained that it was the Government's policy. I did not hear any justification for it. The major reason I am raising this matter now is that there is nothing much we can do about it. I believe that I cannot do anything about it as far as legislation is concerned. I cannot move amendments.

I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to take that situation on board. Can he tell me whether it is the normal situation that disbursements for heritage properties are made on a per capita basis? I want to make it perfectly clear that it is my view, and I believe the view of the commission, that the disbursements should be made on the basis of need—in other words, where there are a larger number of heritage properties in a given State, that should be the basis of disbursement. I will leave it at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was simply taking on board Senator Harradine's comments; I was not planning on adding anything further. However, let me make sure that there is no misunderstanding. For Commonwealth programs in this area, normally grants to the States are made on the basis of lists submitted by the States. Although that would not precisely in every sense constitute a needs basis, it is closer to that which Senator Harradine is seeking. This was a special appropriation to achieve a heritage purpose, but with significant employment concerns as well. That, therefore, meant that the basis of allocation on this occasion was different. But there is no intention of which I am aware to change the normal annual budgetary appropriation for such heritage property expenditure.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Giles)—If there are no further questions, we will go to subprogram 1.9, the Australian National Maritime Museum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised in Estimates the shortfall in revenues that appeared to be developing in the National Maritime Museum, despite the fact that it is an outstanding museum. I am glad to be a member of the museum which, I must say, did an excellent job on Sunday night with the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the sinking of the Japanese submarines.

PARA.TAB: I want to ask whether there has been any further development in attempts to make good the shortfall. I noted in the replies to me that Mr Blunn said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . but we are confident that at the moment they do not require money in the Additional Estimates process, that they will be able to manage.
That was in April. It is now the beginning of June. I wonder whether that situation still obtains or whether there are any financial crises facing the Australian National Maritime Museum.

PARA.TAB: Last night I asked whether the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the sinking of the Japanese midget submarines in Sydney Harbour was a cost burden. I was assured that the whole procedure had cost something like $2,000 only. I believe that was $2,000 very well spent as a major promotional activity for the Australian National Maritime Museum. I certainly hope that there will be no diminution in the quality of the service or the exhibits that the Maritime Museum has been conducting, because it is certainly one of the outstanding elements of that Darling Harbour area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse Senator Baume's remarks about the museum overall. I advise him that, as I think was indicated in the earlier Estimates hearings—he would understand that I was not there, so I am not absolutely sure—it was too early in the life of the museum for judgment to be made about what was required to supplement the funds of the National Maritime Museum. It has since become apparent that assistance is required. During the course of this financial year, funding will be sought from the Advance to the Minister for Finance to assist the National Maritime Museum. The major consideration will be in the Budget and it will come up for consideration then.
—If the Parliamentary Secretary could give me an indication of the extent to which that shortfall is expected, I would be grateful.
—We move on to subprogram 1.10—Australian National Gallery.

—With regard to the Australian National Gallery, in Senate Estimates hearings I raised the extraordinary situation where the Australian National Gallery was facing problems transporting its proposed Cambodian exhibition to Australia. This is a matter of major significance. The political implications of Australia trying to establish closer links with Cambodia at a time like this are clearly of great moment. I understand that there were extraordinary difficulties in encouraging the RAAF, because of requirements about user pays and so on, to transport these objects at a reasonable cost, particularly as the RAAF was in the process of taking men, materials and equipment to the Cambodian area because of Australia's contribution to peacekeeping in that region.

PARA.TAB: I understand that there is a real risk that this politically and artistically very important exhibition that the Australian National Gallery wanted to put on may well not be able to proceed if suitable arrangements were not made with the RAAF to transport it. I wonder whether some sort of reasonable accommodation has taken place, as I understand that at that stage the matter was fairly urgent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that agreement has been reached between the responsible people at this end and the RAAF. The RAAF will transport the disassembled crates to Phnom Penh and the packed objects on the return as far as Bangkok. I understand that agreement has been reached on the matter.
—Thank you.
—There being no questions on program 2, Antarctic, we will move to subprogram 4.1, Policy and Program Support, and Paralympics funding.

—I wish to make a brief point. Has the Government considered the strong case put by disabled sports people for a reallocation of funding for international sport, particularly in terms of their participation in events such as the Paralympics? There is no doubt that the outstanding achievements of disabled Australian sports people overseas seem to be significantly disproportionate, to the advantage of disabled sports people, to those of able bodied Australian sports people overseas. This was evident, for example, in the winter Olympics where Australian skiers, unfortunately, did not do very well, whereas the disabled skiers did outstandingly well. I think the first gold medal won by any Australian skier in any major international races of this kind was won at the recent disabled skiing Olympics which followed the normal Olympics.

PARA.TAB: Disabled sports people get very little money. They still require a large amount of funding for travel and sustenance. These people may well be in a situation which is less conducive to their being able to raise adequate money themselves to fund such programs. I understand that the Government obviously has limits on all of its funding. I am not stressing the need for increased funding for sport at a time of financial restraint. After all, there have been enormous increases in funding of sport in recent years. It seems to me that there is an unfair concentration away from disabled sports people and I wonder whether the Government has addressed that problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are being treated absolutely shamefully.

—The Government has already provided $200,000 towards the cost of assembly, outfitting and transportation of teams for the summer Paralympics in Barcelona and Madrid and the winter Paralympics in Albertville. We have provided $386,000 directly to national sporting organisations for people with disabilities so that other athletes can get international competitive experience in preparation for the games. The summer Paralympic training camp will be held at the AIS soon, before the athletes leave, at an additional cost of $100,000, to be borne by the Government. So far, that is $686,000 to which I have just referred. It is the Government's intention to provide a further $100,000 direct to athletes to attend the Barcelona games.
—Early enough to become acclimatised?

—The Commission's board has also agreed to re-examine the situation at its July meeting. I do not have the detail to answer Senator Reid's question. This is clearly a significant contribution. We can always argue about questions of allocation, but it is significant, and I am advised that it is a matter that will continue to be under review.

—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary. I understand that it is under review. Is there not a time constraint with respect to the upcoming requirements? If it is under review, I do not think there is all that much time to review it. Widespread concern has been expressed about the unfair treatment of disabled athletes. I think Senator Reid's interjection along those lines reinforces the community's concern about the lack of support for those people. I am concerned that the media seems extraordinarily uninterested in the successes of Australian disabled competitors. For example, the outstanding skiing results of disabled athletes at the Winter Olympics for the disabled got very little media coverage.

PARA.TAB: I raise this because a day or so ago—I think it was last Friday—the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced a $5m grant to the Sydney Olympic bid for the Olympics 2000. It will be interesting to see where that money comes from. I hope that it will not be taken from existing programs to sporting organisations. I would not mind if it came out of the disgraceful political stunt which emerged out of the office of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly). Grants to sporting and other organisations were based not on advice from the Department or the Australian Sports Commission but on political advice.

As the Committee is no doubt aware, I was accidentally faxed something which was meant to go to one of the Labor members of parliament whose area was supposed to be the recipient of some of those grants. I was astounded to see that at the top of the fax the electorate was mentioned, whether it was marginal or safe, whether it was marginal Labor or safe Labor, and the name of the occupant of the electorate. Using sport as this kind of pork barrel is unacceptable. If the $5m which is to go to the Sydney Olympic bid is to come from that disgraceful pork barrel, I would be overjoyed; it would be a much better way to use sporting money, but I do not think it should come from other allocations to sporting people. I certainly hope that it does not come from the meagre allocations presently made available to disabled athletes.

I also noticed that when that grant to the Sydney Olympic bid was announced on Friday—I am certain it will be well used; I hope that the Sydney bid succeeds—the Prime Minister said that he hoped there would be a different flag by the year 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be a different government; we know that!

—At least we know that by then there will be a different government but the same flag. It disappoints me that again we have a sporting event being used for a political purpose by a Prime Minister who is desperately searching for some sort of diversionary tactic to take people's minds off the disastrous economic situation that he, as Treasurer, got Australia into. I do not wish to go off at a tangent on that matter except to say that the comparison between the funding of the Olympics and the Paralympics and other disabled sports people seems unreasonable.

PARA.TAB: I am also concerned about what is happening with ministerial attendances at the Olympic Games. We have been assured that a former Minister, Senator Richardson, has not officially been invited to go to those games at the expense of the Australian Olympic Committee. I hope that that is so. That is what I understand to be the assurance. If that is not so, I would be grateful if Senator McMullan could tell us of the situation. Has Senator Richardson or any other Minister, apart from the present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, been invited at either Government or Australian Olympic Committee expense to attend the Olympic Games? If any such Minister has been invited, does the cost of such an invitation come out of money that otherwise would be going to Australian athletes?

TALK.START.PARA: —There were quite a number of rabbits hopping in and out of burrows during Senator Michael Baume's contribution. I do not wish to pursue most of them. They bear little relationship to the Estimates, although it was evident that Senator Baume enjoyed himself.

PARA.TAB: I refer to a matter which Senator Reid raised about the timing of the availability of the $100,000 to assist athletes with disabilities to go to Barcelona. I am advised that that money is available now; the timing of the visit is at the discretion of the athletes. The money will not be made available merely at the death knock. I do not have any information for Senator Baume with respect to ministerial visits. All I know is that only one Minister is going—the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly).

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to subprogram 4.4—Australian Sports Commission.

—I wish to raise the question of advertising and sponsorship. I understand that along with the breakfast advertising revenue there is also revenue from sponsorship from Australian Airlines at the Australian Institute of Sport. Is it commercial in confidence to establish the size of that sponsorship? Is it a significant amount? I imagine that Australian Airlines would be proud to say by how much it is supporting Australian sport.
—It is not commercial in confidence. It is not immediately available, but we will provide the information to Senator Michael Baume.

—I raise a question which was also asked at the Estimates with respect to the advertising of breakfast cereals. Could Senator McMullan explain to me how it is that an employee of the AIS, as an individual and exclusively, is able to obtain payment from Kelloggs for advertising a product—the product is made by Kelloggs—at the same time as he is being paid by the AIS for his skills and intellectual input to that organisation? The AIS employs Mr de Castella, who appears in those advertisements and receives an independent benefit. Is Mr de Castella the only employee who is able to receive a benefit in that way?

—I am advised that Mr de Castella is the only employee who is able to receive that form of payment. I understand that Mr de Castella's contract has already been forwarded to the Estimates Committee. That contract provides for Mr de Castella to continue with or enter into outside commercial arrangements.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that Mr de Castella is required to give written notice to the chairman of all direct or indirect pecuniary interests. The official conduct guidelines which apply to all office-holders also apply to him. I am advised that the Commission is seeking legal advice as to whether a question of conflict of interest is involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who approved the contract? Is it in complete conformity with all the provisions of the Public Service Act?

—I am advised that it is not a Public Service contract. I am also advised that the contract is consistent with the relevant Act, the Sports Commission Act, and that the contract was approved by the board of the Commission.
—Without asking an all-encompassing question, it was proper in every respect?
—`Proper' is a value judgment. As far as I can tell, it was lawful in every respect.

—Perhaps I had better ask the obvious question. Why is it that Mr de Castella, as much as I admire his sporting prowess and have been happy and proud to cheer for him on the occasions he represents Australia—
—And hope to do so again.

—And I hope to do so again. Why is this stand-alone athlete, who happens to be employed, however one quaintly puts it, by the Australian taxpayers, able to receive payment for appearing in an advertisement promoting a product whose development is, in part, paid for by the AIS, and which attracts a royalty? By any measure, it rather seems an odd circumstance. It would be like the Managing Director of Ford getting paid for saying that Fords are great cars.

—My understanding is that the Act gives the board a lot of discretion in these matters. The board made an independent decision that it believed it was in the interests of the Commission to make the appointment with a contract including those terms. Of course, I could not possibly be aware of what was in the board's mind that persuaded it that that was the case.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—We move on to subprogram 4.5.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have quite a few concerns about this area, some of which will be addressed in legislation which will be coming before us, I think, tomorrow. But I have to say—
—If we ever get to deal with legislation.

—I certainly hope we do because the legislation addresses problems in respect of which I said that the coalition would introduce legislation if the Government did not do so. The Government promptly and properly said that it would try to fix it up. I want to mention that legislation is needed to close the Vinnicombe loophole. In fact, this is the third time that the ASDA legislation, which I think was given royal assent only 15 or so months ago, has had to be fixed up for one reason or another. This is not really too cheering. But I will save that debate for when that legislation comes up.

PARA.TAB: What concerns me is the enormous amount of expense that the sporting bodies involved innocently in the Vinnicombe affair were put to by simply carrying out Government policy. Here we have a situation where it has cost cycling bodies `big bickies'—I think that is the expression—to get legal advice and to appear in court. I think the Australian Sports Drug Agency is still in court on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank goodness. They're about the only ones that are.

—I acknowledge Senator Crichton-Browne's interjection. The other sporting bodies were terrorised into reaching an accommodation. Quite frankly, I was opposed to this; and I think most Australians would have been as well because it meant that Vinnicombe got out of having to serve the penalty that he should have served for being a self-confessed taker of performance enhancing drugs.

PARA.TAB: I have spoken to the sporting bodies involved. They say that they had no option. They did what the Government told them to do, which was a condition on their getting a sporting grant. As a result of doing what they had to do to get the sporting grant, they were subject to significant legal expenses when Vinnicombe, in this case, claimed that he had been improperly tested.

It seems to me that these sporting organisations were totally `innocent'. They had not undertaken the test. They had not done anything wrong. They simply ended up with the legal bills, with no guarantee that the Government would pay them. I understand that they can make application to the Minister, to legal aid and all sorts of things. I wonder whether all those bills have been paid by this Government. I wonder whether there will be any indication to sporting bodies that, unless they accept the quite proper instruction from the Government to abide by these rules and take action on positive drug tests, they will not receive government funding. We have also got to see that they are properly protected from the consequences of doing what the Government tells them to do. I think some kind of assurance is absolutely essential.

I am talking only about amateur bodies. Professional bodies can perhaps cope with this, although I think the New South Wales League of Wheelmen would probably dispute that. The League probably wonders—and once again it may have a sound case—why professional bodies should also be penalised by having to pay legal costs for doing the right thing, for following the Government's policy. Has the Government met these legal expenses? Are these legal expenses all over? Will the Government give some kind of assurance to sporting bodies that very sympathetic attitudes will be adopted in protecting them in this way?

I also ask the Parliamentary Secretary what the state of play is with the action against the Australian Sports Drug Agency? Is the Government going to hold out to try to ensure that `right' is maintained, that purity, goodness and the Australian way triumphs over drug taking and cheating, which Mr Vinnicombe appears to have got away with?

One of the things that has annoyed me immensely about this situation is the way that Vinnicombe has been trying to pretend that people like me have got it in for him, that we have some sort of fixation about him and are giving him an unfair go.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just don't like cheats.

—I just do not like cheats—that is fair enough. The fact is that we had a young athlete rubbed out for drinking too much coffee by accident. We then have Vinnicombe who, on a technicality, gets away with half of his proposed sentence even though he admitted that he took the drug and the tests showed that he had taken the drug. Had that test been taken in Australia and had exactly the same results as those taken overseas been registered, he would not have wriggled out of the penalty that was properly imposed on him and which I must say I regret to see he managed to escape on legal grounds.

PARA.TAB: It is an appalling thing that young people would look to that man and say, `Isn't it great? Here is someone whose example I should follow if I want to be a champion Australian sportsman'. I hope simply that young people will recognise that his short cut to fame is also a short cut to disaster—a short cut in many cases to death, as we have seen with some Dutch cyclists who went down that track. I wish that the few people who have written to me expressing concern that I have been unfair to poor Martin Vinnicombe could see the consequences of drug taking in sport and the disastrous lead he is giving to young Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not my area of responsibility in the normal course of events, nor do I claim great expertise in it, but I would have to say that I am not amongst those who think Senator Baume has been unfair to Mr Vinnicombe. That might be a modest enough way of making clear my views on the matter without going too far.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume asked two particular questions. Let me respond to them as precisely as possible. The Amateur Cycling Federation, I am advised, has not applied for any government assistance for its legal costs, so that problem with regard to it has not arisen yet. As to the case being taken by Mr Vinnicombe against the Sports Drug Agency, I am advised that the Agency certainly is not seeking in any way to settle this matter out of court. In fact, it is optimistic that it can win in this case. It is not a matter I know about in detail, but my advice is that, far from any intention to settle out of court, it is quite determined to continue and persist.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one other matter that concerns me. It is excluded from the proposed amendments—the third bite at the ASDA legislation cherry. There appears to be no capacity for a confession by an athlete of having taken drugs to carry the same weight as a finding by the Australian Sports Drug Agency. We had Vinnicombe in this situation confessing that he had taken performance enhancing drugs—after he had been found out, of course. He did not volunteer it until he was found out. As I understand the situation, such a confession, according to the legal decision, did not mean that the organisations that had banned him for two years had acted properly.

PARA.TAB: Here we have a confession. Why on earth, when we have a confession, does that not have the same weight as someone being found in a proper test to have taken drugs? Why is it that the only apparent evidence of drug taking that is acceptable is one that is in a file which is subjected to two tests and goes through all the other rigmarole—leaving, by the way, escape hatches, which we hope are being closed by the coming legislation, through which Vinnicombe escaped? What is the Government doing about making such confessions equally as forceful as ASDA drug test findings?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is necessary to distinguish between the role of the Sports Drug Agency and the role of the relevant national sporting organisations or the Australian Sports Commission. It is not for the Sports Drug Agency to decide that somebody is guilty. Its job is to conduct tests; and I understand that it also has a parallel educational function. In so far as its testing function is concerned, the Agency relies on the empirical evidence of tests conducted by laboratories which have IOC accreditation.

PARA.TAB: The Agency does not take a position on the guilt or otherwise of the individual athlete. This is a matter for the national sporting association or the ASC, if Commonwealth funding is involved. I am sure that the relevant national sporting organisation would unquestionably be interested in such admissions by athletes. I understand that the AOC has amended its doping policy to recognise such admissions as a prima facie case for investigating a banned doping practice, and the Australian Sports Commission intends to make a similar amendment to its policy.

As the policies of national sporting organisations must accord with those of the Commission, national sporting organisations will be required also to include similar provisions in their doping policies. It is proper for admissions by athletes to be dealt with by those organisations which are concerned with the issue of guilt and application of appropriate sanctions. This is not the ASDA's role. So the Government is not taking any action about it through ASDA or through that Act, but the appropriate action has been taken through the appropriate body, which is the Sports Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I just want to get this clear. The Sports Commission will in future regard a confession as evidence of having taken drugs? I was not quite certain, because of the particular choice of language there. It said that it would be a practice worthy of investigation. That is not what I am after. I am after a confession of drug taking carrying the same force as a positive drug test. In the Vinnicombe case, he admitted to having taken drugs, once having been caught out. It would seem to me vital that there be an unequivocal and clear statement from the Australian Sports Commission that organisations that receive government support and funding must act on people who are `guilty' of taking performance enhancing drugs as a result of either test or admission.

—I was getting advice and did not hear every word Senator Baume said, but I think the advice I have will meet the concerns he has raised. My advice beyond that carefully worded initial response is that it is the Sports Commission's policy that national sporting organisations should regard an admission as sufficient evidence upon which they would be entitled to act. It is the Commission's intention that bodies receiving its funding should include that in their policies.

—This then leads to another problem. Take the case where someone admits taking a drug and the ASC says to the sporting organisation—say once again it is cycling—that this person should be suspended, the person is suspended and then attacks the decision in the courts. There has been nothing `illegal' done by the person unless a particular law gets changed. Is the Government going to change the law so that people do not have the capacity to challenge their suspensions simply because there has been an admission rather than a positive drug test which meets some specific legal requirements?

—Putting aside the peculiar legal circumstances that led to the fact that the Vinnicombe admission could in some way be regarded as nullified by subsequent evidence—and I must say that anybody who was not paid $2,000 a day for the opinion could not possibly come to that conclusion; nevertheless, somebody did and it is not for me to say who or why—it seems inconceivable that an individual could pursue a legal action against a sporting body on the basis that it acted on his or her admission. It may be that the individual concerned would subsequently want to retract that admission.

PARA.TAB: The Vinnicombe case has peculiar one-off aspects to it which we hope that the change in legislation will prevent recurring. However, in the normal course, putting all the government bodies to one side, if an individual comes before the relevant disciplinary tribunal, however constituted—if I may use that as a generic term for the cycling federation, the soccer federation, the baseball league or whatever—and says, `Yes, I took performance enhancing drugs on these occasions' et cetera, and the sports body takes action on the basis of that admission, it is hard to see that the individual could sue. It may be that one could subsequently come back and say—and I am not trying to make light of this; I am trying to envisage the only circumstance in which this might arise; and one must realise that admissions, in some legal circumstances, can be challengeable depending on the circumstances in which they were obtained—`I provided this admission under X, Y and Z circumstance which indicates that it should be disregarded and I withdraw the admission'. In that case, unless the association had acted in bad faith and twisted the individual's arm or in some other way acted improperly, if action were taken against it, I would have to say: so be it.

But, if it were an innocent party in the matter, I cannot see that it could be sued in any way. It might be required, in the normal course of natural justice, to review its decision through its normal channels because new evidence becomes available, but at this stage it is hard to envisage how a more substantial problem than that might arise for the sporting body concerned.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—If there are no further questions, we will move on from the ASDA to the next program, program 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we move on, I would like to clarify a couple of matters about funding. I think Senator McMullan said that the Australian Amateur Cycling Federation has not requested funding. For the record, it should be remembered that on 27 May 1987 a prescription by a Dr Daisy Balm for a substance called primabolan was written out for Mr Vinnicombe. At one point Mr Vinnicombe said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why should I be punished for one stupid f . . . g mistake. . . But hell, had I not been caught and gone on to become world or Olympic champion, people would have been none the wiser.
He also said:
I'm banned from amateur cycling, not professional cycling, so they can get——

That is what you call rigid remorse. It does not matter, of course, that there was very clear evidence that he was trying to flog drugs to another very prominent Australian athlete who had the courage to dob him in, to use the Australian vernacular; nothing further was done about it.

PARA.TAB: My understanding is that there was a funding request by the Australian professional cycling association. Could Senator McMullan explain what happened to that request for funding and why it was that the litigation seemed to evaporate into an appearance before Bob Ellicott with the matter not pursued further? As to the other two gentlemen who were involved, what happened to that litigation and, more particularly, why did the Australian Sports Commission agree not to pursue the matter through the courts? Why did it go to arbitration?

TALK.START.PARA: —The only reason I did not refer to the professional cyclists association application was that, in effect, Senator Baume said—I do not want to put words in his mouth—that this was not a matter of concern to him; he was concerned about the amateur bodies. I do not know the name of the body, but I am advised that the professional cycling association has made an application and, although it has not yet been officially approved, I understand that decisions have been made which mean that it will be approved. The Attorney-General's Department, or whichever body it is that makes the decision, has indicated that that will be the decision. I am not absolutely sure of the stage it has reached in the process but it will be approved. I was not trying to be clever when I responded only to the specifics of Senator Baume's question; that information I am happy to make available.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the question concerning the reason for that case being allowed to be converted into an arbitration, I am advised that the Federal Court advised mediation in the matter and that the mediator offered—if I am getting the words correctly—to arbitrate. If I have not got the words right, blame it on my trade union background; they are the words I understand. Anyway, the mediator offered to do something with that impact. And the legal advice was that the wisest course of action was to accept that offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not dismiss the merits of the professional body. I was not as concerned about it as I was about the amateurs but there is no doubt that one of the professional bodies—I think it was the League of Wheelmen—did feel under great pressure to enter that mediation because there was no assurance that, if it stood up for what it knew was right, it would receive any support or have any access to legal backing. This is one of the real problems that we face: unless there is some kind of undertaking about legal support, there is a real risk of people being prepared to enter into this sort of mediation because the consequences of not settling are financially disastrous, even to professional sporting bodies. This seems to me to be quite untenable. I hope that the Government will remove from sporting bodies this risk of being forced to come to an accommodation with cheats, as happened in this case, when there should really be no basis for them doing so.
—In light of Vinnicombe's confessions, does the ASC see merit in reopening the matter of Vinnicombe previously seeking to sell drugs to Gary Niewand?

—I understand that there has been an initial investigation which concluded that there was not sufficient evidence to establish that matter and that unless further evidence came forward the matter did not warrant reopening.
—Did it find on the balance of probabilities that Gary Niewand was telling the truth?

—I do not think that the investigation went so far as to enable a conclusion like that to be drawn. I just make it clear that I am leaving that hanging a bit, because the nature of the investigation was not such that it reflected in any way upon the integrity or veracity of Mr Niewand. He is not a gentleman that I know but I am advised that he is a respected individual. It is just that the investigation was not of a nature that would enable that sort of conclusion to be drawn.

—The memory of your adviser is not as precise as it might be if he had whatever information at his disposal. Would Senator McMullan be kind enough to check that and confirm the general comments he has made?
—Yes, I will see if there is anything to add.

—I go to the question of appeal mechanisms for athletes disqualified for drug taking. With due modesty, I refer Senator McMullan to the recently tabled report of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts and its conclusion drawn from the irrefutable evidence provided by a number of witnesses, including the generally recognised world leading figure on caffeine metabolism. My understanding is that the International Olympic Committee does not have an appeals mechanism in a formal sense which provides rights for athletes to seek redress for decisions made which, in their judgment, carry an element of a miscarriage of justice. Does the Government have a view about the failure of the pinnacle of world sport not providing even a basic appeals mechanism?

PARA.TAB: Given that the Australian Government has been generous in its funding of Australian athletes to participate in successive Olympic Games, not the least being its contribution for the athletes to participate in Barcelona, will the Government make what contribution it can to ensure that Australian athletes who go to the Games to contribute will not be scrubbed out, removed ignominiously from the village, placed on an aeroplane without even being able to make a telephone call to their parents, and sent back to Australia in disgrace without there being some sort of an appeals mechanism which allows them to prosecute their case?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give Senator Crichton-Browne an interim response and I may wish to add a piece of information. My understanding is that he is correct in that there is no appeals mechanism at that level consistent with the policies we have taken in Australia. It is the Australian Government's view that there should be such an appeals mechanism.

PARA.TAB: As the Opposition would know, the Australian representatives on the IOC are not Government representatives. As such, the Government is not taking any action through that mechanism. I do not know, but I am trying to discover whether we know what the Australian representatives on the IOC have been saying. I am sorry, I cannot add any information on that at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could add very vaguely to Senator McMullan's knowledge by telling him that Mr Gosper, who is now Vice-President of the IOC and at the time was President of the AOC, accepted prima facie that Watson had cheated and offered him no respite by way of an appeals mechanism because the AOC had no appeals mechanism.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, when the AOC chose, because of public pressure manifesting itself in the Channel 10 Page One program, to rewrite the rules of the AOC so as to give respite to some extent and allow Mr Watson to appeal, the AOC discovered that, in Mr Gosper's own words, there was no evidence that Mr Watson had consumed caffeine other than in the manner he claimed. This meant that he had not taken it either in its repository or tablet form, which were the grounds upon which the IOC expelled him from Seoul.

Following the AOC making that finding, no member of either the AOC or IOC sought to put right the disgrace that had been visited upon Mr Watson in Seoul by the IOC. There the matter rested; as Dr Fitch from the IOC said, `So be it'. If it helps the Government to know what contribution Mr Gosper has made, I put it on the record now. To my knowledge, from that day on, there has been no formal attempt by Mr Gosper to change that.

Having said that, I put on record the efforts that Mr Coates has made to set up a proper appeals mechanism in Australia to ensure that there is no repeat of that episode. I took it from what Senator McMullan was saying that the Australian Government, which does provide funding for our athletes to go to the Olympic Games and then be at risk of the same sort of conduct, will use whatever persuasive forces are within its repertoire to ensure that the IOC provides an appeals mechanism so that we do not have a repeat of that performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say yes, to the extent that there is any capacity for Government involvement. That will be the policy that will drive that involvement, although, as Senator Crichton-Browne would know better than I, it is not a decision that is finally in the hands of the Government. To the extent that there is a role for the Government, our policy will support the rights of citizens, including in this instance sportsmen and women, to have appeal rights in these matters.

—So I have it on the record and so I understand where we are at, has ASDA any reason to believe that any of the conclusions arrived at in the report in respect of the Watson case are other than impeccable?
—I understand that it has not actually had time to study that, but if it forms a view I will try to ensure that it is communicated to the Committee.
—Does it have a view at a preliminary blush?
—At 10.10 p.m., let us not start preliminary blushing. When we get a considered view, I will try to provide it to the Committee.

—While we are on the matter of general disqualification for drug taking—forgive me if I depart for a moment from the precise reference—Senator McMullan will be conscious of the recent exposure through a Government report and prosecutions of the enormous amount of trade and importation in anabolic steroids of both a human and veterinary nature, in part caused by a recommendation of a Senate committee that surveillance of the barriers by Customs be substantially upgraded.

PARA.TAB: Following that decision and an upgrading, Mr Peter Bowman of the Australian Institute of Sport complained publicly and bitterly that he and some athletes had been apprehended at the barrier. Have all AIS employees been counselled on the implications of using anabolic steroids, and do I take it that Mr Bowman now understands the reason why he may have been stopped at the Customs barrier?

TALK.START.PARA: —I stress that that particular contribution was outside the guidelines that we have in front of us at the moment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ELECTORATE: (Australian Capital Territory Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, given your counsel, I will be brief. I understand they have all been counselled. I cannot of course speak for Mr Bowman's state of mind, but I would be surprised if he was not aware in the circumstances.

—Senator Baume is not here, but I see that he has a matter on reciprocal protocols on drug testing, which I suspect he has not yet raised. I will ask a question. Could I have an indication of the status and extent of reciprocal arrangements in place between Australia and other nations? If my memory serves me correctly, Martin Vinnicombe was detected when tested overseas, because he had learnt, due to the diligence of Australian authorities, not to take drugs in Australia. To what extent do we have reciprocal arrangements with other nations?

—It is my understanding at this stage that there is a trilateral agreement between Australia, the UK and Canada on, I guess we would call it, the mutual recognition of standards. We have a bilateral agreement with New Zealand, and Norway is about to sign or has just signed what was previously that trilateral agreement. Those are the agreements in place at the moment and I understand there is an intention to take that further.

—Is there any reason why there is not some reciprocity with the United States? It seems to me that, until we can get reciprocal testing arrangements with the United States, it really is a farce. I take this moment to observe that anybody who suggests that the Barcelona Games are going to be clean games is uttering absolute nonsense.

—I understand that all the members of our current trilateral agreement would desire an agreement with the United States. It is a priority in our negotiations for future agreements, but it takes two sides to come to an agreement. It is not a reluctance on Australia's part to come to such an agreement.
—It is on the part of the United States.

—That would be slightly overstating the case. I think at this stage it has not got to the point of formal discussions, but it is possible to draw the conclusion that the United States does not share our enthusiasm for an agreement. It is not for me to interpret the motives of the relevant authorities in the United States, but it may be that they are moving in other directions which are higher priorities for them.
—They certainly are—the opposite direction.

—I do not want to make any provocative remarks of that sort here, true as they may be. It is a question for time to be the judge. Australia is enthusiastic about gaining such an agreement with the United States.
—Does Australia have a view about IOC out of competition testing and between games testing?

—The current situation, which I assume Senator Crichton-Browne would know of because of his involvement in this matter, is that between Olympic Games the responsibility is with the international sporting federations and the national bodies. Australia's view is that that seems to be appropriate, I understand, and that those bodies should pursue those responsibilities assiduously, as Australia does.

—Going back to Martin Vinnicombe, do I understand Senator McMullan to be saying that the Government will make whatever contribution it can to pursue with vigour litigation which may prevent Martin Vinnicombe, having cheated, from wearing Australian colours as either an amateur or a professional in the immediate future?

—I am not aware of any proposals to initiate any litigation, but that litigation which is currently under way between Mr Vinnicombe, ASDA and whoever else may be parties to that matter will be pursued vigorously, yes.

—I understand that Senator McMullan is really saying to me that there will be appropriate funding by the appropriate bodies who are already involved in litigation who have sought legal aid from the Commonwealth.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne would know, I have come to this matter somewhat late, but my understanding is that there is only one outstanding legal matter and that is between ASDA itself and Mr Vinnicombe. That will be pursued vigorously and, of course, given the nature of the agency, the funds will be provided by the Government to ASDA. I understand that that is the extent of the outstanding legal matters with regard to this.
—That covers Vinnicombe, Pate and Hall, does it?
—I am advised that there are no legal cases outstanding with regard to the other people to whom Senator Crichton-Browne referred.

—That is why I rather wonder whether I am confused. My understanding is that the Australian Professional Cycling Council has sought funding, and an answer to an earlier question was that the application would be treated favourably in due course.
—That is an application for legal assistance for the past matter.

—I point out to honourable senators that the additional estimates for subprogram 4.5 were for minor variations and lease costs and to cover taxation liability. There being no questions on subprogram 5.6, we will turn to subprograms 6.2 and 6.3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I recorded a reservation with respect to subprogram 6.2. This related to the submission to the Public Works Committee for a major civil works program of $132m on Christmas Island. Subsequent to the Senate Estimates, this matter has also been under investigation by the parliamentary Public Works Committee. As a result of a submission that I made to the Public Works Committee, the Department made a response to that Committee on a number of the issues that I raised here in the Senate Estimates and in subsequent press releases relating to that rebuilding and reconstruction program on Christmas Island. There are a number of issues that I want to take up as a result of those points.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I seek to establish that, with regard to the contributions of the developers of the casino on Christmas Island, who operate under the corporate title of Christmas Island Resort Pty Ltd, there is an agreement with regard to the provision of certain capital works on the island which are to be met by the developer company. I seek from the Minister any advice that he can offer as to whether the original agreements with the developer for the casino have, within the financial year, been varied in any way with regard to that company's liability towards contributions towards the capital works program?

I seek from Senator McMullan any advice he can offer as to whether the original agreements with the developer for the casino have been varied in any way within the financial year with regard to that company's liability towards contributions to the capital works program?

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the answer is no.

—I thank Senator McMullan for that answer. I asked some questions with regard to the operation of the casino, and one related specifically to the capital ownership and the extent to which the capital ownership is foreign ownership or Indonesian-based. The answer given to me through the Senate Estimates Committee states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Christmas Island resort/casino is being developed by an Australian registered company, Christmas Island Resort Pty Ltd (CIR). The principal shareholders of CIR include Mr Robby Sumampow an Indonesian business (63%), Lauw and Sons Holdings Pty Ltd a Singapore based company (27%) and Mr F.P. Woodmore a Perth businessman (10%).

What reassessment has the Department given with regard to this capital ownership structure? Is that in identical terms to what was originally approved by the FIRB when this project was put forward? Have there been any changes in the shareholding of the company Christmas Island Resort Pty Ltd?

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I do not think there is a reservation that covers this matter. I do not say that to seek to avoid answering this particular question, which I am happy to do. I simply draw Senator Tambling's attention to that because it is getting rather late and I do not want to open up new areas. My advice is that there have been changes of ownership and that those changes have been subject to the same scrutiny as the original ownership arrangements and have received the same approvals.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator McMullan refers to the same processes, does that mean it has been re-reviewed by the FIRB or has it been reviewed by Ministers of the Government? What written approvals have been put in place between the Government and the developing company?

—It is my understanding that FIRB has reviewed it in the same manner. We do not have anyone here from FIRB, so I will check and confirm that that is the case. Given that it is the understanding of the officers here that the processes were the same, I assume that that has been the case. If there is any further information, I will provide it subsequently to Senator Tambling.
—Senator McMullan did not answer the second part of my question as to what Ministers had been involved in the approval process to any changes in ownership since these original approvals were granted.
—I had better check that and get advice for Senator Tambling. I do not have any information about that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested to establish whether Senator Richardson, who was the senior Minister of this portfolio from July 1987 to April 1990, was involved in any of the processes. Similarly, I would be interested to know whether the Department has pursued any inquiries with the Australian Securities Commission with regard to this ownership.
