I would also be keen to know whether there are any hidden or phantom shareholders in either of the two named groups—the 63 per cent ownership group attributable to Mr Sumampow or the 27 per cent in the company named as Lauw and Sons Holdings Pty Ltd, which in an earlier document that was provided to me some 12 months ago by the resort was listed as a company which took up the 27 per cent in the name of a Mr Latief. I want to know whether Mr Latief and Lauw and Sons are the same person and why ownership in that respect has changed from Indonesia to Singapore.

—Before I call Senator McMullan, I might ask where we are in relation to reservations. To my mind, the reservations do not seem to have much to do with the Additional Estimates. Can we hang this particular question on any reservation?

—If I could be of assistance, Mr Chairman, I am quite sure that this is outside the Standing Orders; there is not a reservation. It seems to me to be absolutely obvious because there is only one very specific reservation. If Senator Tambling wishes to write to me with a series of questions I will seek to get answers for him. Notwithstanding that it does not come up in the Estimates process, they do seem to be legitimate questions in the public interest. This is not the time to pursue it, but if Senator Tambling wants to write to me with a list of his questions I will send it to the Minister and get an answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I wish to clarify your point. These questions are specifically related to the reservation I recorded on program 6.2. In my letter that is certainly listed as `Christmas Island, submission to the Public Works Committee for major capital works, $132m on Christmas Island', and then I referred to Hansard, pages 91 to 95. All of the issues I have raised are relevant to those same questions I asked that are recorded on pages 91 to 95 of the original Hansard of 2 April 1992. Therefore I do wish to pursue them. I think they are integral to the Estimates, to the back-up of this company, and to the operation of Christmas Island. I believe it is covered by my reservation under that listing of the Hansard reference. I certainly wish to pursue a number of questions, some of which Senator McMullan may or may not be able to answer.

—We will go ahead. The fact that the reservations are there does not necessarily mean that the reservations are in order. We have been so lax over the last couple of weeks that I suppose a little more does not matter.

—On the last question that came up before you raised that point, Mr Chairman, which seemed to me, on the face of it, to be correct—although I will not challenge Senator Tambling's words about what is on those pages of the Hansard because I am sure his recollection is more accurate than mine in that he was there and I was not—
—You have a recollection and you weren't there. That's not bad.

—That is why I said his recollection would be superior to mine. I would not admit such a thing very often; it would take an extraordinary circumstance such as that to persuade me. Let me not be diverted at 10.25 p.m. I will just have to take those detailed matters on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, as I said, I differ with your interpretation of what I intended in my reservation, and it certainly was to pursue this issue.

—I did not say that. I was suggesting that the reservation in itself probably was not in order in that it did not have anything to do with the particular matters that were before the Committee by way of Additional Estimates. I am not going to pursue that; we have ranged fairly widely with other senators and I am not going to do otherwise with you.
—In the Department's detailed response to the issues I raised on 2 April the Department has said:

SPEECH.PARA: Concerning the question Senator Tambling asked about approvals for the operation of the casino the Department engaged the Australian Federal Police to carry out security clearances on the Principals involved with the casino, including the operator, the investors and the developer and their companies. These checks, which are currently being reviewed prior to the casino's opening, were both intensive and exhaustive, and included inquiries conducted both in Australia and overseas. The checks were at least as extensive as those carried out on the Principals of other casinos.

Having regard to the fact that these checks concerning the casino's operation, et cetera, which were originally conducted are now very obviously being reviewed, I would be keen to ascertain from the Parliamentary Secretary by whom these reviews are being carried out, which government agents or authorities are involved, and whether the Department of the Treasury or the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade are also involved in these inquiries.

PARA.TAB: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department has engaged the AFP to carry out revised security clearances for all these parties. As to whether it liaises with Treasury, DFAT or somebody else is a matter for the AFP's procedures. I understand it has not reported to the Department on that level of detail about whom it is talking to, but the AFP has been engaged to carry out the revised security clearances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a letter forwarded to me by a constituent in which the following statement was made. It relates to the particular projects that are being looked at for government funding and states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . was the oft repeated justification that Christmas Islanders must be brought up to the same standard as the mainland and yet the source of the casino venture's funding has not borne the sort of scrutiny required in Western Australia or, for that matter, any other mainland state or territory casino operation.

Have the inquiries been as exhaustive and extensive as those conducted by any State or the Northern Territory with regard to the licensing of casino operations and the various security checks put in place elsewhere in Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer is yes.

—Have any of the inquiries to date indicated whether the interests of either Mr Sumampow or Mr Latief, or the people with whom they are associated, operate illegal casinos or other illegal activities anywhere else in the Asian subregion?

—I am advised that the relevant legislation specifies that the participants have to be fit and proper people to carry out these operations. Inquiries have been conducted and reports have indicated that they are such fit and proper people. Therefore, the appropriate clearances were given.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan did not answer the specific question I put, which was whether Mr Sumampow, Mr Latief or any principals associated with them in their company activities operate illegal casinos or illegal activities either onshore or offshore anywhere in the Asian subregion.

—My understanding of the process—it is not my primary responsibility—is that the Act requires the Department to be assured that these people are fit and proper people in accordance with the Act. The AFP, which everyone would consider is the appropriate body, was commissioned to investigate that matter and reported in the affirmative. Beyond that, the Department is not aware of the detail of its inquiries as to what it found out about those individuals or companies. I am not sure whether the AFP would be in a position to disclose that. I do not have any knowledge about that and it is not a matter we can pursue any further here. My understanding is that there was simply a brief to the AFP that it should investigate the matter and say yes or no, and it came back and said yes.
—Can the briefs of and the reports to the Department with regard to these investigations by the AFP be made available to the Committee or the appropriate Senate Committee?

—I do not think there is any problem with providing that information. I am not sure that it will satisfy the honourable senator's curiosity because, as far as I am advised, it is merely a letter from the AFP to the Department saying, `Yes, these people have received the appropriate clearance'. I am not sure it will help the honourable senator, but I am not in any way trying to prevent him getting the documentation. Whatever is available from the Department I will seek to present. I do not think it needs to go to the Committee. I guess it is appropriate for the Minister to table it at the end of Question Time one day. I will seek to arrange for that to take place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I referred to the fact that matters were currently being reviewed. Can any future reports of a similar nature, particularly with regard to any current activities of these principals, also be made available to the Senate? This is a most important matter. We certainly do want to see the development and encouragement of economically viable and good tourist industries operating in places such as Christmas Island.

PARA.TAB: The particular project is attracting a capital investment in excess of $50m. However, I would want to be guaranteed of the standards and principles that the Australian Government is to apply to the operation of any casino, particularly one that will operate in a remote external territory where very obviously the patronage will not be borne from Australian citizens. I am well aware that the casino on Christmas Island will attract what is colloquially or generally called in gambling circles the `high fliers'—the sorts of people who put up a commitment of at least $50,000 for what they wish to buy in gambling stakes before they turn up to invest. Therefore, the administration, regulation, enforcement and operation of a casino will at all times have to be beyond reproach and beyond question.

Similarly, if for some reason the Territories Reform Bill which is currently before the Senate does not get through the legislative program in time and in order to commence on 1 July—if the program of this Senate or the considerations which may take place in Senate committees with regard to that legislation means that the legislation cannot itself commence on 1 July—will there be sufficient regulatory and legislative controls in place to guarantee that any operation of a security or gambling nature which starts in the next six months will be sufficiently covered by what we would call first best Australian standards?

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of questions in that and I am not sure that I got them all. Most of it was a statement by Senator Tambling for the record, but he asked a couple of questions about further reports. I am happy to make all reports available, subject to the requirements of the AFP's legislation, for example. There must be some limits on the sort of information that a body such as the AFP can release. I do not think we want to be breaching that. Subject to those normal standards of what can and cannot be provided, I am happy to be as cooperative as can be with regard to that. I will forward those requests to the responsible Minister or Ministers. I am advised that the Department is confident that there is a satisfactory legal framework that would continue were the legislation not to pass. I hope the concern raised by Senator Tambling will encourage him to expedite the passage of the legislative program, which would be a very welcome change.
—Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 6.2 and subprogram 6.3?

—I have a question in relation to subprogram 6.3. It relates to a question on notice by Senator Tambling concerning children in schools with particular reference to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island. Firstly, has the Kelly kit with regard to the earth summit, et cetera, been sent to the schools on those islands?
—Are you speaking in relation to question D89R?
—D89R, yes.
—Where are we, Mr Chairman?
—It is an unanswered question on page 4 in the name of Senator Tambling.
—I have no idea, Mr Chairman.

—I will ask some further questions with regard to that. I would presume that it was. The press statements put out indicate that it was sent to all schools under Australian jurisdiction. What was the cost of sending these kits to Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands? There is a list on the back page of people or organisations which contributed to the propaganda material that was put out. What payments were made to the various organisations which are listed on the back page under `Resources'? I will not read them out. If necessary, I can table them. First, what was paid to them in terms of the total project? Secondly, what was the cost of getting the kits to the schools on those islands? In addition, have those kits been withdrawn from the schools on the islands?

—I have had a quick look at the Hansard. I know that the Hansard refers to schools, but I do not think that leads us to a situation where everybody who went to the schools, everybody who posted a letter to the schools, anybody who might have walked past the schools or an idea that might have been in the mind of someone who was in the schools therefore comes within the proper ambit of a reservation or a matter that is properly before Estimates Committee D. As I see it, there is nothing in that reservation that would in any way open up this line of questioning.

—I have to disagree with the Minister. This reservation relates directly to the schools on the islands. I have asked a question about material that was sent by the Department, as we understand it, without endorsement by the Minister, and without having been seen, as reported in a question which was answered in the other place, by her office. So the buck must stop with the Department. Somebody in the Department authorised that material—or was it authorised not by the Department but by the organisations? It raises some very serious questions with regard to not only those schools but also schools across Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Minister or the Department should be in a position to answer the particular questions I have asked him. It is not as though it has not been raised in the public arena. Not only does the material insult the farming community; it also insults the mining community and a number of foreign countries. I particularly refer to the situation in India. It describes how damming water for use is only for rich people. One could go through a whole list of particular aspects. As we understand it, this kit was sent to all schools in Australia. There are schools—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator McMullan

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. I have read again the nature of the unanswered question. It relates to whether the number of children attending the school is correctly recorded in some material presented. It is extremely specific and in no way provides a framework upon which this body of question can be built. The question is out of order and the speech accompanying it is accordingly out of order. The key sentence is the last sentence by Mr Blunn, which is the indication of what is taken on notice. He says:

INTERJECT.PARA: As to whether it relates to the numbers in the schools, I assume it would for that reason, but I would really have to take that—
that is, whether it relates to the numbers in the school—
That is what is on notice. I understand the enthusiasm of Senator Crane, but it cannot be brought within that matter, which is all that is on notice.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Blunn said, in part:

INTERJECT.PARA: As to whether it relates to the numbers in the schools, I assume it would be for that reason, but I would really have to take that on notice and check it.
We are really having a look at numbers in schools. So the reservation in relation to the question was in order, but it is only in order in relation to the question that was asked in the Estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, on the point of order: I would tend to disagree with the point put forward by Senator McMullan on this issue. I certainly raised the question, recorded on page 89 of Hansard, which sought information with regard to the number of students in schools. Subsequently, a very detailed answer was given. It was listed as an unanswered question, which allows it now to be raised. It was also raised in the debate in the context of both employment and the social security provisions that related to residents.

PARA.TAB: The detailed statistical information that was provided in the information to the question related, firstly, to Christmas Island, where it listed the total number of residents on the island as 1,291. It then listed the employed, the unemployed and the number of children. Specifically, with regard to children attending school, it listed 353 children and broke them up between their preschool, primary school and secondary school numbers of 51, 250 and 52 respectively. With regard to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, the supplementary information given related to the schools on Home Island, West Island and those children that obviously attended education facilities on the mainland and provided a break-up of 179 children.

In the context of the debate that was being pursued in the Estimates which related to their employment, I point out, as has Senator Crane, that it is very important that the principal activity that takes place on Christmas Island is the mining of phosphate. Phosphate has a very important contribution to make to the agricultural industries of Australia.

Similarly, on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands there is a very important quarantine station for animal husbandry and a market garden. That specific market garden would, I am sure, be—and I am not being patronising when I say it—very simple. When one looks at the Mrs Kelly kit that was floated around, I would presume that the issues are very important. The questions raised by Senator Crane are very important and should be answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The particular unanswered question is listed as D89R—Children in schools, Cocos and Christmas Island. I have read the question. It deals with numbers of children in schools, numbers of total residents and people in various groups of employment. The question actually related to numbers in schools. Honourable senators cannot talk about market gardens, fertiliser for Australia and goodness knows what when the question deals with numbers in schools. I am ruling that honourable senators may ask questions about that particular unanswered question—a question which was unanswered on 27 April—but they must ask questions in relation to the question which was actually in the Hansard.
—That particular answer identifies the—
—I am not concerned about the answer. I am concerned about the question which was asked.
—Mr Chairman, may I proceed? You asked me to preface my remarks with the answer to the question that was asked, and that is what I was doing.
—I asked you to relate it to the question that was asked. If you start to go into matters relating to fertiliser for Australia and Australian farms, it has nothing to do with children in schools.

—Mr Chairman, I am very sorry, but since I rose to my feet I have not mentioned fertiliser. I do not think I mentioned fertiliser beforehand. My question was not relevant to that; it relates to schools in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. My question relating to Christmas Island is: how many schools are there in terms of the number of children attending? Is there one or more?
—One.
—With regard to the school that has now been identified, and the other two, were they sent the Kelly propaganda kit?

—I am sure that that has nothing to do with the particular question. There being no further questions in relation to subprogram 4.5 and there being no reservations in relation to the Department of Tourism, which is the other department, I put the question that the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before you put the motion, Mr Chairman, Senator McMullan gave certain undertakings relating to the provision of information with regard to the questions that I was pursuing concerning the casino development. I ask for an indication as to when we can expect those answers to be made available to the Senate. I do not wish to delay the consideration of the committee stage, as long as I can be given an assurance that that information will be made available in a very quick and prompt response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —That which is currently available, we will make available as quickly as possible. Senator Tambling was asking for prospective information—information available when certain things are concluded. I cannot give him a time commitment on that but I will be as prompt as I can be. For that which already exists, I will do my best to make sure that it is available this week.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE B

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee resumes considerations of the motion that the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return to the questioning that we were pursuing with Senator McMullan and Senator Bolkus concerning the Australian Labor Party.
—Do you want me to table these documents first?

—Yes, I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to table them straight away and then I would like to get copies of them. Could he also state what documents he is tabling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the agreement for lease between John Curtin House Ltd and the Commonwealth of Australia. I table letters and associated correspondence between the National Audit Office, the Australian Property Group and other elements of the Department of Administrative Services and related bodies concerning the relocation of the Australian National Audit Office to Barton. In so doing, I make one statement with regard to additional information that was provided to me. On 28 May I said:

SPEECH.PARA: To the best of my knowledge, the Minister for Finance was not informed, and in the normal course of events he would not be, with regard to such matters . . .

Mr Willis's officers subsequently told me that he was informed by his Department on 3 February 1992 of the ANAO's intention to lease part of the ALP's new headquarters building, section 22, at Barton. This is in the context of his being advised that the Department of Finance and the Australian National Audit Office were about to finalise a resource agreement for that purpose. The Department was not requesting his approval, either for the terms of the resource agreement or the lease, only advising him that some long-standing issues between the Department of Finance and the Australian National Audit Office were about to be settled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the day, when Senator Bolkus was still answering questions on this matter, I outlined the fact that up to 4 March 1991 the Australian National Audit Office did not know that the Australian Labor Party was to be the landlord of the premises known as the yet unnamed Lend Lease site at Barton opposite the National Press Club.

PARA.TAB: Earlier in the day, when we on this side of the House had been taking note of an answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and I was talking about the Australian Labor Party's building in Barton, I said that we did not know who was providing the finance for that building. I said that the BWIU was involved in that building and that I thought that Multiplex was the builder of that building. Subsequently, in the evening we discovered that it was Lend Lease, not Multiplex, which was the builder of the building.

The same questions remain unanswered relating to the manner in which the Labor Party is financing that building. The Australian Labor Party, having already had one site known as John Curtin House given to it in Brisbane Avenue in earlier years, and having sold that to the ACTU, presumably for a profit, why and how has it been given a second site of land on which to build this second building?

TALK.START.PARA: —It hasn't.
—To whom then is the land given?

—It was not given to anybody. As I said to the Senate before, the Liberal Government of the ACT sold it to the Australian Labor Party at a commercial price. I think I provided that information to the Senate before. It is certainly on the public record. The then Liberal Government in the ACT sold the block to the ALP at a commercial price of $1m, or thereabouts. It really had nothing to do with the Commonwealth Government because it was not a decision in which the Commonwealth was in any way involved. To keep the record straight, that is my understanding of the situation.

—Is Senator McMullan saying that the Australian Labor Party site opposite the National Press Club was sold—I presume that it is a 99-year lease, like everything else—to the Australian Labor Party for $1m? Is he telling me that that is the commercial value of the land?

—I am telling Senator Bishop that it has nothing to do with the Commonwealth; it is a decision of the Territory Government. It happened to be a piece of information on the public record which I provided. It has nothing to do with the Commonwealth, and I do not have any further information.

—I understand the point Senator McMullan is making. Does he have any other information which is on the public record? Was it available for public tender or was it simply a transaction in which there was only one purchaser and a price was agreed upon between the parties?

—I do not have that detail. What I do know is that there were, I think, four blocks of land under the same conditions: one went to the Labor Party, one went to the Liberal Party, and I am not sure who got the other two. I understand that it all occurred at the same price and subject to the same provisions. Mr Kaine, the then Liberal Chief Minister, would be able to provide that information. He made the decisions, not the Commonwealth. I do not have any further information. I have read, I think in the newspaper, that the same provisions applied to the ALP, the Liberal Party and whoever the other two bodies were. I think they were industry associations, but I am getting beyond my recollection of what took place a couple of years ago.
—I noticed that when Senator McMullan was responding to a question from Senator Bishop he indicated that it was not normal for the Department of Finance to get involved in these sorts of agreements.
—No, the Minister.

—Well, the Minister for Finance. I suppose when he said `Minister' I thought `Department' as well. Is it a fact that the Department of Finance recently knocked back an application to lease a property in Mort Street in the city? Senator McMullan can correct me if I am wrong, but I understand that the rental escalation was to be 6 or 7 per cent per annum and that it was to be leased on behalf of DEET. The view was that the figure of 6 to 7 per cent escalation for the property in Mort Street was most optimistic in the current climate.

—This is not something about which I have any particular information, nor is it something that relates to the Estimates. To the extent that I can get any information, I am advised that there was some disagreement between the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Finance about a resource agreement to enable DEET to enter into such a lease. That is all I know.

—I am asking the question because of the correlation that exists between the documents just tabled with respect to the lease. I think it is worth commenting on one of those. The lease agreement was signed this year, yet the escalation applies from 1 January 1991—nearly 18 months ago—at a rate of 10.5 per cent per annum until completion. This seems to be an extraordinarily high figure. Why was it backdated—certainly 12 months from the date of signature of the lease—to 1 January 1991? What was the justification for the extraordinarily high figure of 10.5 per cent? Does this fit the norm of agreements entered into between the Commonwealth Government and private owners?

PARA.TAB: I have another question relating to the ongoing escalation of 9 per cent per annum from the date of occupation for a period of 10 years, with an option for another five; then at the option of the lessor—not of the lessor and/or the lessee—to review the rental to market; and that, having come to the determination, the actual rental paid will be the original rental as agreed, escalated, or the market, whichever is the higher. This seems to be a one-way street. I understand that since this agreement has been reached, the base rental, instead of being $280 per square metre, is more in the order, when we add the costs and outgoings, of $350 per square metre, which is approximately $70 more.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the process of setting an agreed commencement date and negotiating an escalator clause related to judgments about a market for commercial property in the area in question is a standard procedure that applied on this occasion as on others. I do not have anything to add. As I am advised, there is nothing extraordinary about that. When the discussion was conducted previously, Senator Bolkus outlined the judgments of the Department of Administrative Services about the circumstances it believed justified the escalation in the contract. It is not something about which I have anything to add.

—Can Senator McMullan give recent examples of similar leases where the contract period was 15 years; where the date of initial escalation went back 12 to 18 months—in other words, a retrospective date to the date of completion; where the ongoing escalation on a yearly basis would be 9 per cent per annum—that is, for the period going out to 15 years; and where the lessor had the right to review the rental to market price but the rent which would apply would be the maximum of market or the escalated figure of 9 per cent when, as everybody knows, we have a current inflation rate of about 2 per cent and the Government is wont to claim that we will lock it in at that sort of figure for the next five to 10 years? We hope it is right on the latter point. If it is right, how on earth can those sorts of escalation figures be justified in this market?

—Senator Bolkus advised the Senate last week that the rates and escalation provisions in the lease were set on Australian Valuation Office advice. I am advised that he actually tabled some information to that effect at that time. Senator Bolkus also gave an example of comparable leases concerning a 15-year term which related to, for example, the new buildings being constructed for the Tax Office in Adelaide. I am advised that the process for setting the rent at a particular date and then negotiating escalator clauses from that time is—I do not know whether it would be overstating it to say standard, because I am not familiar enough with the detail, but not uncommon.
—Is it common that Commonwealth Government lessees, in addition to high escalation factors—I think they are extraordinarily high in this climate—also pay all outgoings?

—I understand Senator Bolkus also tabled some information with regard to this matter. I am told that across the country there are many examples of net leases with additional elements such as, in this instance, the extra for outgoings. The outgoings, as I understand it, are based on an assessment by the Australian Valuation Office.

—I notice in a clause of the contract that has just been delivered that this agreement is subject to the condition that the lessor—which is John Curtin whatever it is—will not at any stage sell half its stock to or be owned by the Republic of South Africa. In the particular circumstances, I think this is a bizarre clause to put in. I suppose it shows the inflexibility of the bureaucracy. We have this exclusion on South Africa. What about Iraq and all the other places the Government has some complaints about? It seems to me that this is a ludicrous type of clause. It is the sort of thing that makes one a laughing stock when it becomes known publicly.

—I understand that this is a standard clause. Someone other than me would have to provide the detailed information. It is required either in terms of the United Nations sanctions of the time or, at the very least, Australian government policy of the time.
—I am just looking to see what the date of the lease is. Did the sanctions applicable on 23 April 1992 require such a strange and wonderful clause? That is less than a month ago.
—They have not been lifted, have they?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Owing to the complexity of the great copious documents that Senator McMullan has made available to us today and which, quite frankly, he indicated at 1.30 in the morning last Thursday he had in his possession and was ready to table, I really think it would have been reasonable for Senator McMullan to have made them available for people to at least have a look at in the interim. I have got as far as reading all the correspondence to 21 June 1991 and still there is not a single solitary message about, or mention of, the fact that the Labor Party is in fact to be the developer of this site and indeed the landlord. I ask Senator McMullan right at the outset: will the Australian Labor Party have its headquarters in that building which will also house the Australian National Audit Office?
—As far as I know, yes.
—I refer Senator McMullan to a letter written by the Acting Auditor-General, Mr Jacobs, on 27 May 1991 where he says, among other things:

SPEECH.PARA: Since my memorandum of 4 March, there have been some changes to the circumstances outlined in respect of likely accommodation options for the ANAO.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the date again?
—The 27 May 1991. We will run through the chronology of this in just a moment. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place, it is now proposed to draw all areas of the ANAO at one building at Section 22, Barton. This building will provide an area of approximately 6,000 square metres, which represents a reduction of some 1,400 square metres of total office space held by the ANAO in Medibank House . . .
The letter then goes on to state:
At the same time, the ANAO will be sole tenants of the new building and having co-located, could expect to have resolved accommodation concerns well into the future.

In other words, the Australian National Audit Office by 27 May 1991 not only did not know that the Australian Labor Party was the landlord, but thought that it was going to be in the building all by itself. Indeed, the Public Accounts Committee in its report The Auditor General: Ally of the People and Parliament recommended that it should be in a building of its own and that it should be called Audit House.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, I have been through the copious stuff that Senator McMullan has tabled this evening. Right up until 21 June the building was being referred to as section 22 in Barton, having been referred all the way through up until that description as the yet-to-be-named Lend Lease site at Barton opposite the National Press Club.

I see from these documents—some of which are expurgated, I must say; I do not know what has been left out—that on 2 May 1991, Mr Ian McPhee, the First Assistant Secretary, Financial Management Division, of the Department of Finance, wrote to the Auditor-General at the National Audit Office a letter of some 2 1/2 pages which, quite frankly, shows that the Department was not keen on the proposal for the Audit Office to move into these new premises. He concluded by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: In light of these likely changes in works processes—
and he outlines a whole list of reasons as to why the Department is not keen—

if you wish to proceed with the option of seeking a relocation of accommodation which cannot be accommodated within the proposed new arrangements, you would need to address the matter as a New Policy Proposal addressing the essential and unavoidable criteria and providing costing information (including the clarification sought above).

Mr Jacobs wrote back to the Secretary of the Department of Finance talking about the proposed site—as I said earlier, when reading from that letter of 27 May, the Audit Office thought it was going to be the sole occupant—and said:
I now seek, urgently, your agreement in principal to the location of the ANAO to the new building at Section 22 in Barton.

On 11 June, Mr J. Meert, Executive Director of the Executive Support Branch—I am not quite sure what it is the executive support branch of—wrote to the Department of Finance setting out the various offices the Australian National Audit Office has in Canberra, Sydney and Brisbane, and giving a summary. He said:

The move to Section 22 in Barton is seen as essential for operational reasons and is cost effective in the long-term. The change in Sydney's accommodation is unavoidable because the lease cannot be renegotiated. It is also cost effective in the long-term. In Brisbane, the relocation to Adelaide Street is seen as being cost effective once operational considerations are taken into account.
Your urgent support of this proposal would be very much appreciated.
The Property Group wrote back to the Auditor-General on 21 June, this time referring to the site:

Further to the recent presentation and discussions with Lend Lease and the joint venture developers of the office building in Barton in which you have an interest in occupying, I seek your agreement to proceed with negotiations on your behalf.

There was another interesting letter, dated 4 July, again from the Australian Property Group to the Auditor-General, helping the Auditor-General to meet some of the criticisms of the Department of Finance. It said:
I refer to our discussions this morning concerning the Department of Finance not supporting your move to Section 22, Barton.
Listed below are some points you should keep in mind when discussing the possible relocation of the Australian National Audit Office to Barton.

In other words, this documentation shows the following: the Auditor-General was keen to move out of what he calls `refugee premises'; the Australian Property Group placed an advertisement in the newspaper asking for registered expressions of interest for rental premises; the Australian Property Group received 14 expressions of interest; the Australian Property Group was well aware that the site opposite the National Press Club was owned by the ALP; the Australian Property Group sent only 13 of the 14 expressions of interest on to the Auditor-General, omitting—surprise, surprise!—the ALP expression of interest. That was on 21 November 1990. The Auditor-General wrote back, saying, `We have examined what you have sent to us. Here are our three options that we are happy with'.

PARA.TAB: A mysterious phone call emanated from Domonic Collins to a member of staff from the Australian National Audit Office in which he said: `There is another option. I would like to come and talk to you about it'. A meeting was scheduled for 29 November 1990. The people to whom I have spoken, who were actual participants on that occasion, have told me that there is no recollection of the ALP's ever being mentioned, there were no notes taken, there are no minutes and there are no records of that discussion, except the recollection that this person, Domonic Collins, described the physical attributes of the building.

On 7 December, the Acting Auditor-General, Mr Jacobs, wrote to the Australian Property Group, saying that the Australian Audit Office was keen to have the yet-to-be-named Lend Lease site at Barton opposite the National Press Club. On 4 March 1991, the Acting Auditor-General again wrote to the Australian Property Group saying that the yet-to-be-named Lend Lease site at Barton was an acceptable premises. There was no mention of the ALP. All through the correspondence, up to and including 4 July 1991, there is no mention of the Australian Labor Party.

My information is that at whatever time the Australian National Audit Office became aware of the fact that the Australian Labor Party was involved, the Auditor-General proceeded to take every precaution to ensure that there was separate egress and access in order to be totally separated from the Australian Labor Party. In other words, there was every indication that the Audit Office was not happy. Whether or not it was, I make it quite clear, as do an enormous number of people who have contacted my office since I raised the matter, that it is totally inappropriate for the Australian National Audit Office—which, like Caesar's wife, must be above suspicion—to be the tenant of a political party. I hope that it would have rejected the Liberal Party's submission out of hand too, because that was a political party's submission. When we discussed this matter last week I drew attention to the Australian Labor Party in particular as being a bad landlord but added that the principle remained constant for whatever political party was involved.

I am also concerned to know what conditions in the agreement to lease have yet to be fulfilled, because I gather in the very short time that I have had to quickly flick through it that there is provision for the agreement to be terminated. It depends on various conditions not being fulfilled by the lessor. I want to know what conditions are not fulfilled. I want to know what the date of this document is and who has signed it for and on behalf of the parties to the agreement. I beg your pardon; I have found the date; it is 23 April 1992. My particular concern is to know the following: what conditions are set out; what conditions have been fulfilled; what conditions remain unfulfilled; whether the agreement could be breached; and what penalty would have to be paid to the Australian Labor Party.

We have already heard my colleague Senator Parer and others in this place say that the 9 per cent annual increment is outrageous. We are in a position now where inflation is at an all-time low. We are looking at millions of taxpayers' dollars passing to the Labor Party as a permanent and secure source of funds, all by courtesy of the Australian National Audit Office.

To say it is a national disgrace and to say that there are many Australians who are just as concerned as we are about this matter, would be not to overstate it. I want to know whether any work has been done since this matter has been raised as to whether or not this agreement can, in fact, be terminated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Bolkus provided this information last week, but I will provide it again in case my memory is failing. Are these lease terms and conditions yet to be fulfilled? The lease terms and conditions have been fully agreed. As a requirement of the pre-lease agreement, the building must be delivered to specifications. That is the requirement that has to be fulfilled. Is there a penalty for not proceeding? Yes, if the Commonwealth does not proceed with these agreements, it would be in breach of contract and liable for damages in accordance with contract law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —That answer, I am afraid, is an oversimplification. For instance, there are provisions relating to disputes with the builder:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a dispute arises between the Lessor and the Builder, the Lessor must notify the Commonwealth of the nature of the matter in dispute and, so far as it relates to the Fitout Works, the Lessor must consult the Commonwealth to determine what, if any, action is to be taken to resolve the dispute in the most expeditious and least costly manner.

There are many conditions through here—dispute resolution, period of liability for rectification, a whole raft of conditions in this agreement—which I will take the time subsequently to go through. In other words, there are going to be many opportunities in my view when the agreement could be terminated.

PARA.TAB: I am told that Mr Hogg spent a long time during this period leading up to the signature of this agreement getting this agreement signed. People who wanted to talk to him could not get to him because he was so busy stitching up this deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who told you that?

—I have it on a very good authority. I ask the Secretary: where is the evidence, and as at what date, that the Australian National Audit Office was made aware by the Australian Property Group—which knew all the time—that the Australian Labor Party was, in fact, the owner of the building and not Lend Lease?

—There may be the possibility of some disagreement about earlier dates, but unquestionably the latest possible date is March of 1991. The document included in those documents which have been tabled, which is dated March 1991 from Civil and Civic, was provided at that time to the Audit Office and is an outline of the proposed new ALP headquarters at section 22 Barton.
—I presume that document was provided after 4 March. It is dated March 1991. It has on it `Civil and Civic'. Where is the letter that sent that document to the Australian National Audit Office?
—It was presented at a meeting in March.
—It is the first I have heard of any such meeting. On what date was that meeting heard, and where are the notes about it?
—I understand it was simply a routine meeting as one of a series of meetings as part of the constant consultation between the Audit Office and the Australian Property Group.
—Were no notes taken?
—Exactly.
—Surprise, surprise.
—Now you're part of the conspiracy.
—No, it is not a conspiracy. What I am asking is: did the Australian Audit Office keep any notes or minutes of these meetings and, in particular, of the meeting when this document was handed over?

—I have a copy of a minute from a senior director, resource management, at the ANAO, to the Executive Director, Executive Support Branch, outlining some conclusions that had been drawn with regard to the suitability of the accommodation, which I understand flows from the series of meetings to which I referred. I have not had much of a chance to look at it. I am not sure of how much value it is, but there is nothing secret about it.
—Does it mention the Australian Labor Party?
—I am happy to table the document, and I do so.

—My next question is: when was the Department of Finance told that the proposed landlord was the Australian Labor Party? In all the correspondence that I have managed to get through concerning the Department of Finance, there is no mention of the Australian Labor Party. On what date was the Department made aware of the fact that the Australian Labor Party was in fact the landlord, if ever?
—I do not know the answer to that question. There was no correspondence to that effect. As to whether the Department was told in some informal way, there is no information available.
—Are any officers from the Department of Finance present?
—No.
—Why not? This is the Department of Finance we are dealing with still, is it not?

—It is the Audit Office. In the normal course of Estimates and appropriations hearings, when the Audit Office comes on, the Department of Finance officers are not always present. That is the case again on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not the case when we met together on the last occasion; it is merely convenient. We will make it our business to find out from the Department of Finance when, if ever, it found out that the Australian Labor Party was to be the landlord. I might add that, on 9 August 1991, Mr Jacobs wrote to the Secretary saying:

SPEECH.PARA: For some time now officers from the ANAO have been in discussions with your staff regarding the move of the ANAO to permanent accommodation. A Works Technical New Policy proposal was submitted on 11 June 1991 which I understand is now with you for consideration.
Could we please see a copy of that works technical new policy proposal?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the date of the document to which you are referring?
—It is 9 August 1991.
—The submission is in the tabled documents. It is the document of 11 June to the Secretary of the Department of Finance headed `Works Technical New Policy'.
—Dated what?
—It is dated 11 June.
—Is the document the one that has a lot of blank pages attached to it?
—No.
—Does it say, `Canberra cost comparison over 10 years; Stay in Medibank and other Canberra locations versus move to section 22'?
—No. It is not that document.
—Which one is it?

—The document of 11 June 1991 headed `1991-92 Works Technical New Policy' from the Executive Director, Executive Support Branch, to the Secretary, Department of Finance. Senator Bishop referred to it earlier.
—That is the one that I am referring to that has the blank documents attached to it: Canberra comparison, Sydney comparison—there is no comparison—and Brisbane comparison.
—I was referring to the letter. They are attachments to that document.

—I say again that in that letter there is absolutely no mention at all of the Australian Labor Party. Until 11 June the Australian National Audit Office had not been advised of the involvement of the Australian Labor Party. As we continue to go through the correspondence, there is no mention of the Australian Labor Party. It is imperative that we find out from the Department of Finance—I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to inquire of the Secretary of the Department—when, if ever, the Department of Finance was made aware of the fact that the Australian National Audit Office had committed itself or wished to commit itself to becoming a tenant of the Australian Labor Party.

—It cannot have been later than 3 February this year, as I have already indicated to the Committee in my opening remarks today. Mr Willis was informed of this fact by his Department on that date. So it cannot have been later than that; but it may have been earlier.

—Because we have only just received these documents, I would be pleased if the Parliamentary Secretary could find out the method by which the Department of Finance and, in particular, the Minister was told on 3 February. This really is subterfuge. First of all, the Australian National Audit Office is not told who the landlord is until such time as it selected the building and desperately wanted to get in. I find that desperation a little disappointing. From some time in March 1991 until February 1992, in the correspondence that the Department of Finance has entered into with the Australian National Audit Office and the Australian Property Group there is no mention of the Australian Labor Party. I want to know the manner in which, any correspondence in which and any discussions in which the Minister for Finance became aware that the Labor Party was going to be milking the taxpayer of millions of dollars—$1.9m per annum, with annual increments of 9 per cent.

—I feel it is time to respond. It has taken a lot of time with people making speeches about things they want to get on the record. I have not sought to reply except to specific matters. It is appropriate at this stage to say that if we now have an allegation of subterfuge—a deliberate attempt by people to deny information to somebody who should properly have it—it means that we have a conspiracy between a reputable company, the Lend Lease Group—
—No, don't blame them.

—That company must be part of it. The Lend Lease Group, the Australian Property Group and the Australian National Audit Office must have been colluding for this bizarre conspiracy theory to have any credibility. On every occasion that anybody makes an allegation to Senator Bishop, she believes the allegation. Nobody has ever made an allegation to her that she has not believed.

PARA.TAB: We are asked to accept that the Lend Lease Corporation, the Australian Property Group and the Australian National Audit Office have conspired in a subterfuge so that the Department of Finance would not find out that the landlord of the Australian National Audit Office was going to be John Curtin House Ltd, a company owned by the Labor Party. I have to say that that stretches the bounds of credibility beyond any reasonable standard. In my view, it is just beneath any reasonable person to conclude that any of those organisations would be involved in such a subterfuge. I cannot see why one would think any of them would be, and it is neither likely nor reasonable to assume that they would.

To come in here and assume that they somehow all did it is an absurd, extreme and unreasonable proposition and a reflection on a large number of responsible, decent individuals and the organisations they represent. Allegations are lightly thrown about in regard to people who do not have the capacity to defend themselves here. I think it is time something was said about the fact that those are most unreasonable accusations and propositions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan is great at putting a spin on things. So that we get it straight, the fact of the matter is this: nobody is saying that it was Lend Lease which tried to camouflage the ALP, because Lend Lease wrote to the Australian Property Group and disclosed, right at first instance, that the ALP was its client and the owner of the development. When I finish I will ask this question very specifically through you, Mr Chairman: why did the Australian Property Group leave the ALP expression of interest off the list that was sent to the Australian National Audit Office?

PARA.TAB: If we go back to the facts and the spin that Senator McMullan puts on them, the allegation is that the Australian National Audit Office was kept in the dark right up until March 1991 as to who was the true landlord. The Department of Finance was kept in the dark right up until 3 February 1992. The Parliamentary Secretary can answer if he likes, if he purports to have an answer, as to why that was so. If this was so open and so up and down, firstly, why did the Australian Property Group not let the Australian National Audit Office know right at first instance that the Labor Party had registered an expression of interest and, secondly, why did the APG do it by a secret method, if you like, not putting the ALP on the list, as the expressions of interest were all received, despite the fact that every applicant or every company that registered its expression of interest received the same letter? It was deliberately left off, added in later. At no stage in any of the correspondence is the Labor Party mentioned until the Government had it on the hook and it knew if it did not take that proposition it was not going to get a building at all. The Department of Finance made it quite clear that it was not keen on the move. It was kept in the dark that it was the Australian Labor Party.

At what stage, further from the documentation, can Senator McMullan show me that the Department of Finance agreed to allow the Australian National Audit Office to enter into an agreement which would have been considered binding, at least morally binding if not legally binding? At what stage did the Department of Finance feel that the agreement had been struck, that is, prior to its knowing that it was the Labor Party that it was dealing with? Those are two very specific questions for the Parliamentary Secretary to answer. Why was the Labor Party submission left off the initial list sent to the Audit Office on 21 November 1990? Why was reference to the Australian Labor Party left out of all correspondence? Precisely at what time and how did the Department of Finance find out it was the Australian Labor Party? Had authority to the Australian National Audit Office already been given to enter into a contract for an agreement to lease?

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the first question, Senator Bolkus answered that and tabled a minute from the Australian Property Group.
—It is dated today. It is not worth a crumpet.

—Obviously the honourable senator is assuming that this person is conspiring as well. She may assume that. It is written by a person I do not know, but I have no reason to doubt his integrity. It was tabled today by Senator Bolkus. That document is before the honourable senator and that is the answer to that question.
—No, it is not the answer to the question I asked. It relates to a period after the 21st.

—As I said before, we do not know the answer as to when the Department of Finance was informed; but the Audit Office discovered it in March and negotiations did not commence with Lend Lease until June. So it is clear that the Audit Office was not locked in before it became aware that the Labor Party was the owner of the proposed building.

—Will the Parliamentary Secretary please ask the Department of Finance to advise him by what means and on what date it was advised that the Australian Labor Party was to be the landlord? As for the Australian National Audit Office, the comment I made about its being locked in related to the proposal that if it did not take what it was offered it would not be granted new premises. One could call it some sort of moral suasion.

—My understanding of the documents, which is confirmed by the officers, is that there were other options open to the Audit Office but it preferred this one because it met its needs more satisfactorily, which is why both the Australian Property Group and the Audit Office chose it. I will of course ask the Department of Finance for that information.

—I would like to respond briefly to what Senator McMullan said earlier about the propriety of the Government entering into negotiations to put any government department in premises owned by the Australian Labor Party—in other words, the political party of the Government in power. I think one has to have a sense of balance in matters such as this. What would have been the reaction of the Labor Party—whether it be State of Federal—if, for instance, when the National Party was in power in Queensland a major government department in that State had been ensconced in Bjelke-Petersen House? There would have been absolute outrage from the Labor Party. I have heard more outrage about lesser things that have been done in Queensland. That is the reason why I queried this matter on 15 January.

PARA.TAB: What did it bring forth? It brought forth responses from people such as Mr Hogg. In fact, at one stage Mr Hogg said that what I had said was `potentially malicious and libellous'. At that stage the lease document had not been signed. There was also a scurrilous report in the newspaper to the effect that what I had said had earned the ire of the Auditor-General. This was a plant—probably by the aNiMaLS—because I received a letter from the Auditor-General by fax within 24 hours advising me that in no way did he feel slighted by the fact that I had raised the matter and that he hoped that out of it would come more commercial rental for the Australian National Audit Office. He said that I was quite within my rights and responsibilities to raise a matter which I believed was wrong as far as the taxpayers of Australia were concerned—or words to that effect.

I very much appreciated that response from the Auditor-General. Neither I nor any of my colleagues at any time in this whole episode have impugned the Auditor-General in any way. We hold him in very high regard. What we did object to was the changed atmosphere—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan of all people would know this. Whether it be disclosures or anything else, there is a changed atmosphere in this country. What might have been okay 25 or 30 years ago one now has to be more sensitive to—or, apparently, we on this side of the chamber have to be more sensitive to it, but the Government does not. The Government has put one of its major departments into premises owned by the ALP under terms and conditions which are very bankable. The ALP has been able to take a document signed by the Government to the bank and say, `Here is a 15-year lease'. It has a $1.68m base rental plus all outgoings, making it approximately $1.8m per year, plus 10.5 per cent retrospective to 1 January 1991, and then, from the date of occupation, at 9 per cent per annum for the next 15 years.

PARA.TAB: What the Government has done is at odds with all probity and honesty. It is the sort of thing that is not tolerated in today's society. It is just tough luck for the Labor Party and even for the Liberal Party, but it is one of those things. If the Government is going to give a lead to the rest of the community and hold itself up as a guide as to how people should act in society, it is just tough. The Government cannot do something which is to the advantage of its own Party at the expense of the Australian taxpayer. The Government would have been the first cab off the rank if that had happened in Queensland under the Bjelke-Petersen Government and someone had put a major department into Bjelke-Petersen House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support Senator Parer and Senator Bishop in what they have said this evening. I too wish to express my displeasure at the National Audit Office being the tenants of a political party—and I would not care if it were the Liberal Party, the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats or the National Party; it applies to any political party. Senator Parer perhaps went a stroke further than I did by saying `any major government department', because he was able to draw attention to the position the Labor Party has put itself in where it is now able to raise enormous sums of finance on the basis of a 15-year lease at approximately $1.8m per annum, rising at 9 per cent per annum.

PARA.TAB: To think that that could happen in 1992! People in Victoria would be turning themselves inside out about this, with all the vacant office buildings in Victoria. But that was not my point. I understand and support Senator Parer and Senator Bishop on that point. I make my point in looking at the matter from the other aspect. In my view, the National Audit Office ought not to put itself in a position where it is a tenant of a political party. The National Audit Office ought to be seen to be squeaky clean, and it ought to act squeaky clean. It ought never put itself in a position where someone could say, `What on earth is happening here?'

It is no good Senator McMullan saying that the Auditor-General says it is all right, the documents are at arm's length or it is being done through lawyers. It does not matter; there is no way that deal can be cleaned up. It will appear forever to be some sort of a sleazy deal. I say to the National Audit Office that it appears to be a sleazy deal and there is no way it can avoid it. If the Audit Office goes ahead with this lease and the Labor Party holds it to the lease, it will be seen to have been involved in a deal which smells.

I suggest to Senator McMullan that, on the basis of the indications that we have had that the tenant did not know who the landlord was until very late in the piece, that tenant may very well have a right in equity to withdraw from the lease—and I think it ought to be allowed to get off the hook.

I say to the Labor Party—I agree with what Senator Parer said—that if this had arisen in Queensland we would never have heard the end of it. Honourable senators opposite would have been alleging that Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and his Government were up to absolutely no good because the Queensland Auditor was in premises owned by the Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen fund, or whatever it was, and they would have gone on and on. But, with the Labor Party, it is perfectly all right. It has no qualms or no morals about this sort of thing. It is perfectly all right for the Labor Party to enter into such an agreement which, as I say, at the end of the day will be seen by the public of Australia as a sleazy deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I want to move a motion which I think will be a more welcome contribution than some of the others this evening. But, before I do, I simply say that what distinguishes our contribution in this matter from that of honourable senators opposite is that we apply the same standards to others as we apply to ourselves, which is more than can be said for anybody else. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Committee report progress and seek leave to sit again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Committee have leave to sit again on the next day of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, just shortly prior to the Committee reporting progress, Senator McMullan made a statement. I am not sure precisely what he meant by it, but I think it was an attempted slur on us. I am not too sure; I will read the Hansard. But my interpretation is that what he was saying is that the Labor Party is a bunch of crooks and that it is placing that interpretation on everyone else—that we are all a bunch of crooks. Let me say to Senator McMullan that if that is what he was saying, then I deny it on behalf of the Liberal Party and the National Party.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak tonight because of two essential principles in liberal democracy. One is the responsibility of senators in using parliamentary privilege to weigh the facts and avoid injustice to individuals; and, the second, to fight political censorship, is even more basic.

PARA.TAB: In speaking on 27 May, Senator Chamarette accused Perth broadcaster Howard Sattler, and the radio station for which he works, Radio 6PR, of promoting racism and tabling a document that called, in effect, for the political censorship of Mr Sattler. He was accused of having referred to the deaths of three young Aboriginal car thieves as `good riddance to bad rubbish', when it is a fact—and Senator Chamarette knows it to be a fact—that he made this statement without knowing the racial origin of the three youths.

Senator Chamarette, on radio on Friday, 29 May, had to admit this fact as well as her lack of knowledge of several positive initiatives that the Sattler File, which is the name of Mr Sattler's program, has taken in regard to Aboriginals. She did not know that his program had publicised the cause of a disabled Aboriginal who had been denied funding for a necessary overseas trip or that the brother of an Aboriginal man in Broome who was the victim of a racist murder had been given air time. She did not know that Howard Sattler had sought to publicise the case of the tragic and disgraceful story of Louis Johnson, to which she referred in the Senate, by seeking to interview his family—an opportunity which they chose not to exercise. That is their freedom; that is their right. But it is certainly not Senator Chamarette's right to come in here and slam Mr Sattler in the way in which she did. Mr Sattler had also strongly criticised the apparent lack of satisfactory or appropriate action by ambulance officers in this same case.

Senator Chamarette was not aware of the efforts of the station to provide education to a young Aboriginal footballer and its granting journalism cadetships to three young Aboriginal trainees. All that Senator Chamarette could say was, `I personally don't listen to your program', and that she had chosen not to listen to the program.

It is not just a matter of unfair criticism being made under privilege, serious and all as that is; what is far more sinister is an obvious attempt by the Murdoch University Centre for Research in Culture and Communication and so-called progressive thinkers to drive Howard Sattler from the airwaves and to censor and suppress the views that he promotes.

A serious campaign has been launched to influence and intimidate advertisers on 6PR in order to force the station to change its editorial policy. A 69-page report is being sent to advertisers in order to convince them that they should withdraw their custom or presumably face the same kind of vilification that is now being directed against the Sattler File. They are told that they are not good corporate citizens and that Aboriginal organisations and communities in receipt of government funding will boycott the sponsors of the program. This is blackmail. While individuals can always exercise such a choice, I regard it as sinister that government funds and government agencies are blatantly advocated as being tools in such a boycott.

It is also pertinent to ask how much public money has been consumed in this exercise in political censorship, in the production of this report and its extensive circulation. Who paid the researcher time? Who paid for the production and distribution of the report? Taxpayers have an assumed duty to subsidise `politically correct' propaganda.

The paper by Steve Mickler, which was tabled by Senator Chamarette, is not only an example of a slanted accusation of racism, whereby populist anger against criminals is falsely equated with continuing genocidal pressure against Aboriginal people; it is also an example of how that despicable American doctrine of `political correctness', whereby the values of the left wing intelligentsia are imposed without hindrance, is to be foisted on the Australian media. When it is recommended that the Western Australian Government use its control of the Totalisator Agency Board to enforce what, in the view of the writer, is a non-racist, non-discriminatory policy, we have a crude demand for political censorship. I am absolutely and utterly astonished that Senator Chamarette wishes to be associated with that form of censorship.

Furthermore, the ABT is called upon to institute censorship by regulating program structures and editorial practices that allegedly amount to gratuitous vilification. Advertisers are threatened for complicity with a station with a reputation for racism. There is an unspoken but obvious premise that tough-minded comments about juvenile crime are racist because so many of the perpetrators of these crimes are Aboriginals and that the suppression of racism as an all-encompassing and heinous offence takes precedence over such archaic notions as freedom of speech or allowing the Western Australian public to exercise their free choice by voting with their radio dials. I regard these premises as intellectually contemptible and highly dangerous.

A racist is a person who propagates the view that other human beings are inferior because of their racial characteristics and should suffer discrimination. A racist is not a person who criticises other Australians, fairly or unfairly, for their actions or who attacks government policies seen as favouring a particular group. I would have thought that Senator Chamarette would have understood these facts. It is a gross misuse of the term to apply it to anyone who dissents from the `politically correct' line.

It is so obvious why Howard Sattler has attracted the wrath of these people. He is a populist who has taken a strong line on crime and has given voice to the understandable and legitimate fears and concerns of a large number of Western Australians. His real crime is not to have attacked Aboriginals, but to have expressed deep seated anger against car thieves who cause the deaths of innocent people, with the result that a State Labor government bowed to public opinion and instituted tougher legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sattler is a decent, honourable man.

—Senator Baume is quite correct. It is admitted that the Federal Executive of the Australian Journalists Association found that its rules had not been violated by these comments on the Sattler File but, in Senator Chamarette's eyes, he remains guilty of expressing politically incorrect views. Clearly, according to Senator Chamarette, any broadcaster who questions the validity of Aboriginal sacred sites or sides with the mining industry in public debate must be silenced.

PARA.TAB: Howard Sattler is not necessarily a political conservative. He is a vociferous republican and he never hesitates to castigate the Liberal and National parties over issues and personalities. These are his views and he is entitled to promote them. We can disagree with him and we can criticise his style, while always defending his right to express political opinions. He is described as rude and overbearing in the long report being circulated to 6PR advertisers. If that were to be so, so what? When has total objectivity hitherto being demanded from talkback radio? This, surely, is a description that can be applied to many Australian broadcasters, including his 6PR colleague, Robert Maumill. Has Senator Chamarette tried to silence him? No, she has not.

One would think that in a democratic society those who object to the style would ignore the program and perhaps the ratings would suffer. If the numbers that Senator Chamarette alleges are so large, on this basis alone Mr Sattler would have been taken off air years ago.

The quoted `victim' of Mr Sattler's bias, Rob Riley of the Aboriginal Legal Service, is certainly no stranger to the cut and thrust of public debate and has no trouble in finding a media voice when he needs it. According to the report, it seems to be an offence for Howard Sattler to have a listening audience of middle aged and elderly people who supposedly have an exaggerated fear of crime. I know a lot of people who listen to the program, and I am certain that they would not like to consider themselves either middle aged or elderly. But so what, if that is the majority of the audience? Obviously, those who seek to impose a politically correct agenda do not believe that these people are entitled to a voice—certainly not one that is listened to.

I would add that it is an insult to listeners and callers to allege that Howard Sattler has manufactured public opinion, with the implication that their views, therefore, have no validity, as being sectional and prejudiced. Such adjectives could equally be applied to the other side of the debate, particularly to this grubby document to which I refer. It is a measure of the venom and bias of this report that Mr Sattler is castigated by Senator Chamarette for emphasising the fact that the rally against sterner State legislation on juvenile offenders attracted 400 people as against 30,000 who attended an earlier rally calling for higher penalties, or 12,000 who attended a candlelight vigil for the innocent victims of crime.

I wonder what the authors and sponsors of this report, and the campaign to remove Howard Sattler from the airwaves, hope to achieve in the long run. There is no place for any broadcaster to incite racial violence, but Howard Sattler has faced no such charges. We have a legal system that will curb any such action. The view that Mr Sattler and his callers express may be regarded as offensive by some, but it is a view that is entitled to be expressed.

As a Western Australian senator, I remain conscious that only three years ago there was a campaign of racial violence and the most vicious propaganda unleashed in Perth by the Australian Nationalist Movement, whose leading lights are now in gaol. That is the kind of true racism that should concern us. Mr Sattler regularly spoke out very strongly against these real racists. Did we hear a squeak from these very same people who are now yelling today? No, we did not.

Nothing better wins support and credibility for the real racists than censorship of the hard-nosed, populist but essentially responsible views expressed by Howard Sattler and many of his callers. Nothing will create public resentment faster than Senator Chamarette's call for the broadcasters to be silenced because Australia has signed human rights treaties. Whatever happened to the right of freedom of speech? Would Senator Chamarette like to see that go altogether, except for her parliamentary privilege? I suppose she would. Nothing is more calculated to drive people with a genuine fear of crime and concern as to inappropriate treatment of Aboriginals to political extremes than the type of censorship advocated in this report and promoted by Senator Chamarette.

Muzzle the social democrat and learn to deal with the Marxist revolutionary. Silence the populist and ultimately we will be hearing from the fascists. Is that what we want for Australia? It is certainly not the type of Australia I want. If the new political correctness is allowed to enforce its own terms of radical debate on the popular media, it will not stop there. We can look forward to the censorship within our universities of academics such as Geoffrey Blainey, who from scholarship and conviction opposed the received wisdom of the political Left. It will become impossible to have a rational debate about crime or policy towards Aboriginals without fear of intimidation—infinitely more pervasive than anything alleged against Mr Sattler. Genuine fears will be driven underground and Aboriginal Australians will attract a far greater resentment from the wider community than ever could be aroused by a radio program.

We need to question the assumption that Steve Mickler and his ilk necessarily speak for Aboriginal Australians, many of whom want effective action against crime and are not interested in the Western Australian Aboriginal Media Association, are not anxious to use sacred sites to stop development, and do not accept the constant propaganda that they are victims of colonialism and white society. Indeed, there is no worse denigration of Aboriginal Australians than this constant ascribing of victim status so that they become diminished moral beings who must be constantly excused all responsibility for their own actions. After the interview with Senator Chamarette last Friday, one of the first of many callers who rang 6PR to voice support for Howard Sattler was Aboriginal.

I will keep on fighting to make sure that Australia remains a democracy where controversial opinions can be expressed without intimidation from the agencies of government. If my fellow Western Australians disagree with Howard Sattler and dislike his programs, they remain free to tune in elsewhere, like Senator Chamarette. I hope that Senator Chamarette will try to inform herself more thoroughly before she comes into the Senate and makes the sort of outrageous statements she made last week.

I notified Senator Chamarette's office this evening that I was going to make these comments. I do not know whether she has gone home or has chosen not to come into the chamber tonight. I certainly hope that she will seek to make a formal apology in the Senate to both radio 6PR and to Howard Sattler. I know that my fellow Western Australians who disagree with Senator Chamarette would have the decency to refrain from bucketing Howard Sattler on biased second-hand evidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.
