TALK.START.PARA: —I do not plan to detain the Senate for long. I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a table I have had prepared by Mr Terry Brown, the Acting Clerk Assistant. It concerns an issue that has been of concern to you, Mr President. Certainly Senator McMullan has spoken on the issue in this chamber from time to time. It concerns the vexatious matter of the number of questions being answered at Question Time in the course of a day. I am pleased to report to the Senate that the figures that have been prepared for me by Mr Terry Brown are the most comprehensive set of figures to date and take the record back to 1970.

PARA.TAB: The table is particularly interesting. It shows the comparative performances of the Whitlam Government, the Fraser Government, the Hawke and Keating governments, and as far back as the McMahon Government. Mr President, I think you would be particularly interested to know that the average number of questions asked each Question Time in the McMahon Government was 29. When we went to the period of the Whitlam Government, in the Senate the same figure was produced—29 questions per day on average were asked and answered.

During the seven years of the Fraser Government—again, based on the figures which Mr Terry Brown produced—intriguingly the same number of questions were asked. On average, 29 questions were asked per day. Of course, this varied marginally from year to year but the overall average during the Fraser period was almost the same as that for the Whitlam and McMahon periods.

Mr President, we now come to the period during which you have been in the chair—during the Hawke Government and Keating Governments. I have worked out that, over this period, the average number of questions asked per day is just under 22. In other words, seven fewer questions have been asked per Question Time during the Hawke and Keating Governments as compared with the previous governments. There has been debate as to why this has occurred. Mr President, on a previous occasion, you have put forward

SPEECH.PARA: some views as to why you believe this has occurred. I am aware that Senator McMullan has also put forward some views.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that in recent days when we have been dealing with the so-called Marshall Islands affair, on one day the number of questions asked fell to 15. I believe that that is a record low. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the table to which I have been referring.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the time has perhaps come, Mr President, for you to have another look at the number of questions being answered during Question Time. I have had the opportunity to read the papers which are presented at annual Presiding Officers and Clerks conferences. I was interested in the debates and discussions at those conferences which dealt with the role of Presiding Officers and the choices they make during Question Time. I was intrigued to read—this is something which I had not appreciated—that Mr Browning, a former Clerk of the other place, pointed out at the 1990 conference, as he has done on many occasions, that the powers of the Presiding Officers to make rulings at Question Time are virtually unlimited. The limit comes when this chamber says, `Thus far and no further'.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I think the time has come for you to look again at the number of questions being answered in Question Time. On the basis of the figures that I have, we are back to the bad old days with a vengeance. In short, the answer to the vexatious question of the number of answers which are being given at Question Time is for the Presiding Officer—you, Mr President—to show a greater willingness to bring a lengthy answer to an end, as you have done from time to time on previous occasions. Mr President, I hope that when you look at these figures you will be more inclined to use the powers which you have. TALK.START.PARA: —I moved a motion earlier today concerning the increasingly desperate position of farmers in western New South Wales. The announcement on the weekend that 59 per cent of the State is in drought has brought on the latest crisis. Drought has been a part of some farmers lives for the past two or more years. As everyone in this chamber knows, droughts are dreadful things. For those who live in cities, drought might affect only a social or sporting event. It might mean a slight drop in shoppers for a shopkeeper—but nothing too serious.

PARA.TAB: Drought is the most devastating thing one could imagine for farmers. Of course, one never knows how long it will last. Invariably, one moves into drought ready for short term measures—hand feeding and conserving water. The next step is usually to cut back on the numbers of stock. The farmer has to guesstimate how many and what type. If he sells in the down market and it rains the next week, he will lose a lot of money; if he does not de-stock and it does not rain, his situation becomes even more critical.

He might decide to take a gamble on sowing a crop without the necessary moisture in the soil for germination, hoping that rain will come to kick it off. The alternative to not planting a crop is no crop, and definitely no chance of income at the end of the season. For those in the western districts of New South Wales there are few options and choices when the rain does not come. Numbers are cut back, ewes are not joined and some stock is sent away on agistment. Then it is pretty much a case of sitting it out and hoping the break comes before the feed reserves or the money run out.

Drought affects good and bad farmers and there is often no great difference between how each survives. For people to suggest that good farmers can predict drought and can manage it easily just highlights the ignorance of those who make such statements. The definition of drought as compared with merely a dry spell has exercised the minds of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for a while. Certainly, good farmers ought to be prepared for the regular dry spells which afflict much of this country, but the prolonged drought cannot be budgeted for and farmers cannot be realistically expected to battle it out on their own.

I remain concerned that the Federal Government is stalling on the question of a national drought strategy. I remain concerned that it is trying to opt out of its responsibilities in this regard. I do not believe that farmers—especially in the western districts—can afford to carry on for much longer without knowing how much help they can expect from the Government, State or Federal. It is impossible for these farmers to make any forward plans because they do not know whether they ought to be selling their stock, sending them away on feed, selling the farm or just giving up and walking away from their debts.

I cannot begin to understand the emotional strain that this must place on families, yet they survive, largely, better than city families in meeting crisis. I make that comment not from my own bias, but from a Coopers and Lybrand study which shows that in rural areas more people remain married, and families are more stable, despite the fact that the stresses on rural families are greater.

This Government needs to become aware that there is a serious revolution going on in rural Australia. Small towns are shrinking and disappearing. Rural areas are becoming more regionalised. Some towns with ageing populations are becoming ghost towns with no income generated to sustain them. There is little or no work force as such. Young people are abandoning these towns and moving to regional cities in the hope of getting better employment prospects. That has serious implications for the future for the provision of education, health and welfare services, and for the infrastructure to sustain those activities. It also has serious implications for the standards of education for rural dwellers, for service industries, banks, machinery and seed dealers, mechanics, transport and all the public services.

It has serious implications for the future of the family farm—how it will operate, who will service it and who will want to do it. More than ever, farmers today are terrified to encourage their children into farming because of its uncertainties and its difficulties. Many see no future for the family farm, notwithstanding the obvious benefits of a rural family lifestyle—the family values, the quality of life and the statistics that show that rural marriages are more stable than city relationships.

All this is happening now in New South Wales. It has the potential to accelerate in the western areas of the State where drought is just one of the mountain of problems facing the people in those areas. The Government can do little about the weather, it has shown that it can do little about the price of wool, but it can do a lot more about what assistance it is prepared to give those farmers facing a genuine crisis through a disaster of nature. It is incumbent on this Government to move the process a lot quicker than it has done. The rate of farmers moving into non-viable situations cannot be allowed to continue unabated. I implore the Federal Government to examine what is happening in western New South Wales now and not stall any longer on setting down strategies for assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not seek to delay the Senate too long, but unfortunately I understand one of the news media is to `knock off' some material that I wished to present to the Parliament at a later date. As a result, I want to present it to the Senate now instead. This relates to an extraordinary investment by the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating) when he was still Treasurer amounting to something like $430,000. We all know about the right wing of the Australian Labor Party being keen to get its snouts in the public trough, but now its leader has gone and spent $430,000 to get his share of snouts in a much more private trough—a piggery. Just a month before he ceased being Treasurer last year, Mr Keating sent the note I am about to read to the Registrar of Members Interests, the Clerk of the House of Representatives. I believe it is a fairly misleading note. It is dated 7 June 1991 and it states:

SPEECH.PARA: I advise that on 15 May 1991—
that is while he was still Treasurer—

my family company Pleuron Pty Limited and I made an investment by way of acquisition of shares in Euphron Pty Limited, a company, which has interests in a piggery and a refrigeration fabrication business.

The interests acquired by both Pleuron Pty Limited and me in Euphron Pty Limited do not constitute a controlling interest in that company, nor do I or any member of my family hold a directorship of that company.

At the time, the Sydney Morning Herald reported that this was a $50,000 pig deal. Its heading was `$50,000 pig deal reveals a rasher Keating' and referred to the matter that he had intended at one stage to `bring home the bacon' in one of his failed Budgets.

PARA.TAB: The facts are that that massively understates the level of the investment. In fact, the family company, Pleuron Pty Ltd, in which Mr Keating and his wife are shareholders—Mr Keating is by far the majority shareholder—has a total paid up capital of $478,500. That is a pretty substantial company. I think a lot of politicians would be very pleased indeed to have been able to save anything like that sort of amount of money to put into a company. I can think of very few who from their parliamentary salaries would be able to save any more than a fraction of that. That $478,500 paid up capital is according to the latest return with the Australian Securities Commission which was released today. That family company, Pleuron Pty Ltd, is represented on the board of Euphron which is in itself a major shareholder in the Brown and Hatton group of companies by Pleuron's Company Secretary, a Mr Christopher Steven Coudounaris, a solicitor with Gadens, who has no personal interest in the Pleuron and Euphron companies.

This creates some interesting questions. In fact, the whole structure creates a whole lot of interesting questions. It is clear that, for example, Mr Keating's family company, Pleuron, holds an interest in Euphron. In fact, it is a half interest in Euphron—not just a modest one that does not carry any control. It is quite clear that the interest in Euphron Pty Ltd represents half the shareholding. It is half ownership of Euphron. Mr Keating skirts around that by saying, `It does not constitute a controlling interest'. Who on earth has the controlling interest if they are equal shareholders?

The point I make is that Mr Keating directly holds 100 ordinary shares in Euphron and his family company, Pleuron, owns 430,000 A shares in Euphron. Another company, called Sephrenia Pty Ltd, has a similar 430,000 B shareholdings, and Mr Archilles Constantinidis holds 100 ordinary shares. In other words, Mr Keating's 100 ordinaries and Mr Constantinidis's 100 ordinary shares match, as do the 430,000 A shares and B shares that Pleuron, in the first instance, and Sephrenia, in the second instance, hold in Euphron. Okay—he does not have a controlling interest; he just shares ownership. One would have thought that the Prime Minister might have thought it worth while to at least concede that he shares what appears to be a controlling interest in a major company with assets around the $850,000 mark, as I recall.

He also says, `Neither I nor any member of my family holds a directorship in that company'—that company being Euphron. But the shareholding of his family company, Pleuron, in Euphron, which is a major shareholder in the Brown and Hatton group of companies, is represented on that board by Pleuron's company secretary, Mr Christopher Steven Coudounaris, a solicitor with Gadens who has no personal interest in the Pleuron and Euphron companies. This means that Mr Keating's statement to the Parliament on 7 June hides the fact that, while no-one in his family held a directorship in Euphron directly, there is a nominee acting for them, Mr Steven Coudounaris, who has no personal interest in the Pleuron and Euphron companies. He is a nominee acting, clearly, as a director of Euphron for Pleuron.

One would have thought that in this situation, where the Government has been trying to make a virtue of declarations of interest, Mr Keating would seek to make it clear that he does have a major interest and that, even though he is not a director, he has a nominee on that board. It is interesting to note, too, that, while Pleuron's annual return has been made to the Australian Securities Commission—a copy of which came out today—Euphron, in which he is a joint shareholder with Sephrenia, has not yet filed its annual return to the Australian Securities Commission for the year to 30 June 1991, although it was due for filing on 1 January 1992. Many people say that it is normal for these things not to be sent in on time, but I would have thought there might be some special merit in a company in which the Prime Minister holds a 50 per cent interest—

TALK.START.PARA: —Complying with the law.
—complying with the law—
—Setting an example.

—and, as Senator MacGibbon says, setting a good example. I admit that he did not set much of a good example with the Taxation Office, but maybe Prime Ministers are not required to put in their tax returns on time. Obviously, they are not obliged to make certain that the companies in which they hold a 50 per cent interest put in their company returns on time.

PARA.TAB: I would hope that when Mr Keating hears of this he will encourage his nominee on that board to do something about that and to get that company return in, even if it is only to allow stickybeaks like me to see what is in the return, as well as providing the people with whom that company may do business—creditors and so on—with some indication of what that company is all about. It would also be nice if the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, in which I understand Euphron is a major shareholder, also put in a return, because that has not had a return put in for some time.

These are the vehicles by which Mr Keating has an interest in the piggery. The piggery was bought by the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd when it had another name. All these companies seem to change their names with incredible enthusiasm. This one was called Denvalt at the time. I hope that some attempt will be made to fill in the returns.

The report in the Sydney Morning Herald of this pig deal indicated that Mr Keating had bought Mr J.J. Brown's interest in that group. Mr J.J. Brown was a former Minister in the Hawke Government, a member of the right wing of the Labor Party of New South Wales and, in that sense, I suppose, one of the `mates'. There are other companies in the group, such as Jensay Pty Ltd and Olympia Refrigeration Sales Pty Ltd—both at the almost notorious address that crops up everywhere of 48-54 Meeks Road, Marrickville—and neither company has filed returns with the Australian Securities Commission for the financial years ended 30 June 1989, 1990 and 1991. I do not know why they have not been struck off the register, but one would have thought that that kind of delay is not appropriate.

I was also interested to note in my searches that, while a company called Olympia Refrigeration Sales Pty Ltd is a member of the group, there is another company called Olympia Refrigeration Pty Ltd which has gone into liquidation, owing considerable amounts to creditors including an amount for workers compensation insurance. Naturally, it no longer carries on business. I wonder to what extent Olympia Refrigeration Sales Pty Ltd is carrying on business formerly carried on by Olympia Refrigeration Pty Ltd. I suppose that creditors of Olympia Refrigeration Pty Ltd may well be interested to know whether they could have done a better deal and got money out of the collapsed company had this situation not obtained.

It is a very complicated company structure. Because these companies do not put in their returns in anything like good time—in fact, they are sometimes years behind—it is very difficult to establish the Brown and Hatton structure. I cannot guess. All I can say with confidence is that the annual return of Pleuron Ltd, Mr Keating's company, shows that it is in a very healthy state. It has current assets of $480,000, total assets of $481,460 and a shareholders equity of $474,438. I look forward to the Prime Minister explaining to the Parliament whether he has joint ownership of this major company—at least major as far as most people are concerned as something worth around $1m is not chickenfeed—whether he has an equal control in it; whether he has a nominee as a director of it; and whether he will encourage it eventually to file its annual return.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What were the reasons that the Minister refused funding for aged care beds at Evandale Hospital in northern Tasmania.

(2) Did the Minister, or his office, tell Mrs Christine Milne (Member, House of Assembly, Tasmania) that his office would welcome applications for a capital grant to refurbish or rebuild Evandale to meet Federal Government standards.
(3) On what basis would any such grant have been approved and are applications for capital grants still 'welcome'.
(4) In what way(s) does the Evandale Hospital fall short of Federal Government standards for nursing homes.
(5) On what basis or conditions did the Federal Government agree to the permanent transfer of 24 nursing beds from St John's Park in Hobart to the Evandale Hospital.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Recurrent funding is in fact being provided for aged care beds at Evandale Hospital. The State Government has, however, indicated its intention to close the hospital.

(2) This part of the question is not representative of discussions that occurred between Ms Milne and the Minister or the Minister's office. Ms Milne did not speak to Minister Staples on this issue or any other issue. No member of the Minister's staff said the Minister's office would welcome an application for a capital grant to re-build or re-furbish Evandale Hospital.

(3) Capital grants are provided to eligible organisations (charitable or community based organisations) to provide residential services in areas of demonstrated need for frail aged accommodation. Advertisements are placed each year seeking applications from eligible organisations to provide aged care services, in areas of greatest need. Organisations are free to apply at these times.

(4) Commonwealth officials undertook a quick examination of the premises. This is an old building and a purpose built hospital and shows the features of such facilities. These features are not desirable for a nursing home and are not characteristic of currently constructed nursing homes. Nevertheless, the Department would not rule out premises solely on the basis of architecture. Architecture is a significant determinant of homelike environment and quality of life, but by no means an exhaustive one.

(5) The 24 nursing beds were relocated from St John's Park to Northern Tasmania at the request of the State Government. As there were a number of long stay nursing home type patients already at Evandale (the majority of whom were admitted from Launceston), the beds were transferred to this site. Approval of the beds was granted only on the understanding that the bed approvals were to be located at Evandale Hospital for a temporary period, before their relocation at Toosey Hospital.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, on notice, on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the department at present conducting a review of the policy and practice relating to so called `common-user contracts'; if so (a) what are the terms of reference for the review; (b) who is conducting it; and (c) what timetable has been adopted for the review:
(2) Has the public been invited to submit proposals relating to desirable improvements in the system of common-user contracts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes
(a) The Terms of Reference are:

"Current policy on the role of purchasing generally dates from the Purchasing Reform initiatives of 1988: that the prime objective of Commonwealth purchasing is to support Government programs by achieving value for money in the acquisition of supplies; and that practices and procedures are directed to that end. In this context DAS administers the Commonwealth's Common Use Purchasing service which seeks to:

ANSWER.PARA: achieve savings for client agencies, and the Government as a whole, through aggregating the Government's purchasing power;

provide administrative savings for agencies through streamlining the sourcing and evaluation efforts required—thus saving agencies expending resources on duplicating background research and developing market expertise before inviting and evaluating bids;
reduce transaction costs for buyers and sellers (to the buyers' advantage); and
assist agencies in the implementation of all relevant government policies that impact on purchasing.

PARA.TAB: Against this background, and without limiting its generality, the review is to consider and make recommendations on the following issues:
1. How to ensure that the system is responsive to its client agencies and Government?
2. Whether, and if so how, departments should continue to be tied to using arrangements made or approved by DAS?
3. What mechanisms should be used to achieve cost recovery from users?
4. What criteria should apply in decisions to establish or continue "common use contracts", including setting their duration?
5. How, and to what extent, the system should involve cooperation with other governments?, and
6. What should be the relationship of DAS service providers to the system? e.g.:

ANSWER.PARA: whether they should be exempt from any tying arrangements that applied generally;
whether they should have to bid for admission to relevant business covered by common use arrangements and, if so, what cost recovery arrangements should apply; and
what measures should be used to avoid conflicts of interest within DAS and to assure clients and suppliers of the integrity of its approach?

PARA.TAB: "The review should have regard to experience in other systems, to the views of stakeholders and in particular to the emerging outcome of the Australian National Audit Office review of common use purchasing undertaken by DAS Purchasing Services.
"Recommendations should identify any areas requiring further study before decisions can be taken. The review is to report by 22 April".

ANSWER.PARA: (b) The Review of Common Use Purchasing is being conducted by a Steering Committee comprising the General Manager of the Australian Office for Better Buying (Chair); senior executives from the Department of Finance and two client agencies, the Department of Defence and the Department of Veterans' Affairs; and a representative of the Australian Public Sector and Broadcasting Union (PSU). The committee is assisted by a project officer with extensive policy and practical knowledge of the common use system.
(c) The review was to have reported by 22 April 1992 but has been granted an extension until the end of May 1992.

PARA.TAB: (2) No. Suppliers' views were surveyed as part of the Australian National Audit Office review currently under way.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What date was the original application made by the Western Australian State Government for funding under the Better Cities Program for Bunbury.
(2) What are the full details of the application by the Western Australian State Government for funding under the Better Cities Program.
(3) Was Bunbury the subject of a specific application by the Western Australia State Government; if so, what are the details.
(4) Does Bunbury fall within the criteria necessary to attract funding under the Better Cities Program; if not, why not; if so, what level of funding is it likely to attract.
(5)When will a formal program agreement for Better Cities funding with the Western Australia State Government be announced.
(6) Will that agreement specify how much is to be spent on Bunbury.
(7) Will the Western Australia State Government, under the Better Cities Program, be able to determine exactly how much of the entire funding package is to be spent on Bunbury.
(8) Has the Western Australia State Government applied for funding under the Better Cities Program for (a) Albany; (b) Manjimup; or (c) Busselton.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Western Australian Government's formal proposal for funding under the Building Better Cities Program was provided on 25 October 1991.
(2) This original Western Australian Government's proposal sought support for a number of area strategies, the main features of which are:
(a) Perth: Redevelopment of a number of inner city sites for mixed use development including residential, commercial, educational, retail and recreational purposes.

(b) Fremantle: Redevelopment of a public housing estate; development of underutilised land for residential purposes; a study of rapid transit system; and enhanced community services and sewerage services.
(c) Northern Corridor: Development of a strategic approach to meeting the needs of the area including development of an urban village at Stirling.
(d) Bunbury: Redevelopment of the Bunbury Harbour area and a public housing estate, and provision of a new septage facility.
Subsequent discussions led to some modifications to these area strategies.
(3) Yes. See 2 (d).
(4) Yes (as modified). See (6) and (7).
(5) A Commonwealth/State agreement covering agreed Building Better Cities area strategies for Western Australia was signed on 15 April 1992.
(6) The agreement includes reference to a Building Better Cities contribution of $10.654 million over five years. This figure is indicative only.

(7) Under the terms of the agreement, Western Australia will receive an addition to General Purpose Capital Assistance of up to $78.3 million in respect of its agreed area strategies over the five years to 30 June 1996. The actual amount will be determined taking into account: area strategies that meet the agreed criteria; progress towards achieving area strategy outcomes in the previous year as assessed jointly by Commonwealth and State Ministers; and the estimated cash flow and cost projections for area strategies. The actual expenditure on Bunbury will be determined by the Western Australian Government, from within the total amount provided by the Commonwealth and subject to the provisions of the agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 30 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the National Food Authority Act 1991:
(1) What are the Commonwealth and State/ Territory agencies that have been prescribed as appropriate Government agencies under sub-section 3(1) of the Act.
(2) What specifications, if any, has the Authority issued, under sub-section 12(3) of the Act.
(3) What applications, made under section 13 of the Act, have been rejected by the Authority under paragraph 13(2)(b) of the Act.
(4) In relation to which inquiries undertaken by the National Food Authority have public hearings been held under section 29 of the Act.
(5) What persons have been appointed as members of the National Food Authority and, in each case, under which paragraph of sub-section 40(1) and 40(3).
(6) What persons have been appointed as members of the Food Advisory Committee and, in each case, under which paragraph of sub-section 42(4).
(7) Has the National Food Authority established any committees under section 43; if so: (a) what committees; and (b) with what membership(s).
(8) What consultants have been engaged by the National Food Authority under section 54 of the Act, for what purpose(s) and what amounts were paid in each case.
(9) What appeals, if any, have been made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal relating to decisions made under the Act.

(10) What specific cases have been caught by the provisions of section 71 of the Act (as amended by section 31 of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Act 1991) and which of these cases would not have been caught by section 71 had section not been amended.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No regulations have been made under section 70 of the National Food Authority Act 1991, and so no Commonwealth or State/Territory agency has been prescribed for the purposes of the definition of `appropriate government agency' in section 3(1) of that Act. Draft regulations are being prepared by the Office of Legislative Drafting in the Attorney-General's Department.
(2) None.

(3) An application from Just Juice Corporation Pty Ltd to seek variation to Standard O2 to allow the use of a single label carrying a statement such as "A blend of Australian or of Australian and imported juices".
(4) To date only one application has passed through the inquiry stage. No public hearing was held on that occasion.
(5) Ms Gae Pincus—paragraphs 40(1)(a) and 40(3)(e);
Mr Michael Jackson—paragraph 40(1)(b);
Ms Barbara Smith—paragraphs 40(1)(c), 40(3)(c) and 40(3)(f);
Professor Michael Rand—paragraphs 40(1)(d) and 40(3)(b); and
Dr John Keniry—paragraphs 40(1)(d), 40(3)(b) and 40(3)(d).
(6) Ms Gae Pincus—paragraph 42(4)(a);
Dr John Loy—paragraph 42(4)(b);
Mr Digby Gascoine—paragraph 42(4)(c);
Dr Gavin Frost, Dr Graham Rouch, Dr Gerry Murphy, Dr Ian Rouse, Professor Ian Calder, Dr Avner Misrachi, Mr Michael Thompson, Mr John Huntley and Mr Dick Hubbard—all under paragraph 42(4)(d).
(8) See Attachment A.
(9) There have been no appeals made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal relating to decisions made under the National Food Authority Act.

(10) Section 71 as amended, allows applications and proposals for the development of a standard or the variation of a standard, that were under consideration in the National Health and Medical Research Council's (NHMRC) system of food committees, to continue in force as if those applications and proposals had been made under the National Food Authority Act. These applications and proposals are listed below.
If the section had not been amended, the cases listed would not have continued in force.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 5 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the draft report by the Chairman of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Working Party to Prepare Report on Cyclodiene Insecticides entitled Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia:

(1) On what page(s) in the full report are the data to substantiate and/or support the statement in the report's Executive Summary (p.17) that 'the concentration required to exert a biological effect is many orders of magnitude away from achieving its potential'; if not in the report: (a) what is the definition of `biological effect' as used by Dr Duggin; (b) what is the definition of `potential' as used by Dr Duggin; (c) how is it known that the concentration required to exert a biological effect is many magnitudes away from achieving its potential; and (d) what are the cyclodiene concentrations in the Australian environment.

(2) On what page(s) in the full report are the data to substantiate and/or support the statement in the report's Executive Summary (p.18) that the interpretation of hepatic changes in chlordane-exposed rats 'remains somewhat controversial'; if not in the report, what is the basis for the statement in the Executive Summary.

(3) On what page(s) in the full report are the data to substantiate and/or support the statement in the report's Executive Summary (pp.18-19) the cyclodiene insecticides produce 'no recognisable adverse human health effects with the current levels of exposure'; if not in the report: (a) what are current levels of exposure; (b) do any studies showing 'no adverse human health effects' at these levels of exposure exist anywhere; if not, is Dr Duggin's statement misleading; if not, why not; (c) is it possible to conduct studies that would detect carcinogenic effects in humans attributable to low level exposure to the cyclodienes; if so, what would the research design of such a study be; if it is not possible to conduct such a study, is Dr Duggin misrepresenting the unavailability of human evidence and the impossibility of obtaining it as safety; and (d) what case reports documenting adverse effects following domestic exposure by cyclodienes has Dr Duggin examined; if none, why have none been examined.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The matters raised by the honourable senator relate to a draft report entitled Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia approved by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) at its 112th Session for release for public consultation.

I believe it more appropriate for these points of detail to be taken up by the Panel on Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia, which the NHMRC has appointed to review the outcome of the public consultation process. I have accordingly arranged to draw to the attention of the Panel the need to clarify the points raised by the honourable senator in the final report.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 12 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the 1991 Defence personnel census which states on page 15 that, `Over forty per cent (41.5 per cent) of married personnel have been separated for Service reasons for periods of one month or longer since being married; 11.4 per cent of those in recognised de facto relationships have been since ADF recognition of their relationships. Over one-tenth of married ADF members (10.6 per cent) have been separated for a total time in excess of three years since being married, a further 10.4 per cent have been separated for a total of two to three years, and a further 21.0 per cent for between one and two years (12.3 per cent of those in recognised de facto relationships have been separated for a total time of at least one year). One in eight (12.7 per cent) were separated for Service reasons for at least six months in the year leading up to census day', will these people be considered as `living in a domestic and bona fide relationship' for the purposes of the definition of `widow' or `spouse' in the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits and Military Superannuation Benefits Scheme Acts respectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: If an ADF member dies while separated from a legal or de facto spouse solely because of Service reasons, the spouse is regarded as coming within the definition of `living with the deceased person on a bona fide and domestic basis' for the purpose of payment of reversionary benefits in both the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act and the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme Rules.
